title: Why there was a 'leap second' added to the end of 2016?
text: Imagine we have a super-duper perfect clock that always ticks at the exact same speed, like a robot that never gets tired. This clock helps us know exactly when a day starts and ends. But then there's our Earth, the big ball we live on, and it spins around and around to make day and night. Sometimes, the Earth spins just a teeny, tiny bit slower than our super-duper perfect clock expects it to, like when you're running and you get a little bit tired and slow down for just a second. When the Earth is just a little bit behind our perfect clock, we add a "leap second" to the clock. It's like giving the Earth an extra tiny moment to catch up, so that our clocks and the real spinning Earth stay perfectly in sync. We added one at the end of 2016 because the Earth had gotten just a tiny bit behind, and we wanted to make sure everything matched up perfectly again. It's such a tiny amount of time, you wouldn't even notice it – it's like adding one extra blink to your day!

title: How is property in outer space valued? If the earth colonized Mars what government/organisation would technically own it

title: Why is it that we calm down when we take a deep breath, hold it for a few seconds and exhale?
text: You know how sometimes when you're super excited or a little bit worried, your heart goes 'thump-thump-thump' really fast? That's your body getting ready to run or be super alert, like it has a 'go-go-go!' button turned on. But when you take a big, slow breath, like you're smelling a yummy flower, and then hold it for a tiny bit, and then let it all out slowly like a quiet sigh... it's like you're sending your body a secret message! You're telling it, 'Hey body, everything is okay! You don't need to be in a hurry anymore.' And your super smart body listens to that calm breath and says, 'Oh, okay! Time to turn off the 'go-go-go!' button and turn on the 'ahhh, relax' button instead.' It helps your heart slow down, makes your tummy feel less fluttery, and helps your brain feel quiet and happy again, just like that!

title: Why does 1080p on a 4k TV look better than 1080p on a 1080p TV?
text: Imagine your TV screen is like a giant board made of tiny, tiny colorful lights, like lots of little sprinkles! A regular 1080p TV has a good amount of sprinkles.

title: Why does lights make a "blinking" effect when looking at them from far away?
text: Imagine the air between you and the light is like a big, invisible, wobbly jelly! It's not still, it's always moving and swirling around, like when you blow on your hot chocolate. When the tiny light from far, far away tries to shine through this wiggly air to reach your eyes, the air makes the light wiggle too! Sometimes the wobbly air pushes the light a little bit away from your eyes, so it looks a little dimmer, like it's hiding. Then the air wiggles again and pushes the light right back to your eyes, and it looks bright again! Because the air is always doing this little dance, the light keeps wiggling and changing how bright it looks, making it seem like it's blinking or twinkling just for you.

title: How are pop-up and generally annoying web ads viable?
text: Imagine you have a really cool new toy, and you want everyone to know about it so they can buy it! You ask your friend, "Hey, can I put a little sign for my toy right in the middle of your drawing? Even if it covers a tiny bit of your drawing, maybe someone will see my toy and want it!" Your friend says okay because if someone *does* buy your toy, you'll give your friend a tiny piece of candy. Even if lots of people just close the sign right away because it's in the way, a few people might see it and get curious, or maybe even accidentally touch it. If enough people do that, even just a few, it means you sold enough toys to make it worth giving your friend that candy. So, even if it's a bit annoying sometimes, it still works for the toy maker and the friend who let them put the sign there!

title: why does it hurt when you swallow a beverage "wrong" ?
text: Okay, imagine you have two special tunnels in your throat, right next to each other! One tunnel is like a "food slide" that takes your drink safely down to your tummy. The other tunnel is like an "air slide" that only wants air to go to your lungs so you can breathe. When you swallow normally, a clever little door quickly closes the "air slide" so your drink *only* goes down the "food slide." But sometimes, if you're talking or laughing or just being super quick, that little door doesn't close fast enough, and a tiny bit of your drink accidentally splashes into the "air slide"! The "air slide" gets very surprised and says "Hey! No drinks allowed here!" and makes you cough super hard to push the drink right back out. That big, sudden cough and the tickle of the drink in the wrong place makes your throat feel funny and hurty for a moment, like when you bump your elbow. It's just your body being very smart and trying to keep your "air slide" clear for breathing!

title: Why would a drug dealer lace their product with carfentanil, which is causing so many OD deaths? Aren't they reducing their own customer base?
text: Imagine you have a regular cookie, and then there's a super-duper, extra-mega strong cookie that costs almost nothing to get. Drug dealers sometimes put just a tiny, tiny crumb of that super-duper strong cookie into their regular cookies because it makes the whole cookie feel really, really powerful, and it's much cheaper for them to make a lot of cookies this way. They think if their cookies are known for being super strong, more grown-ups will want to buy them, and they'll make more money because they didn't spend much on the super strong crumb. The very sad problem is, that super-duper strong crumb is so powerful that even a tiny bit can make grown-ups get too sleepy and not wake up, which is a terrible accident. The dealers are mostly thinking about making money and making their product seem the strongest, even if it's super dangerous and means some customers won't come back.

title: Why do the instructions on pasta call for you to measure out water?
text: Imagine your pasta is going for a swim! If you only put a tiny bit of water in the pool, all the noodles would bump into each other and get sticky, and the water would get yucky super fast. The instructions tell you exactly how much water to use so your pasta has a big, comfy pool to swim around in. This way, every noodle gets cooked just right, they don't stick together, and your yummy dinner comes out perfect every time!

title: Why is ventilation needed for indoor or underground rooms?
text: Okay, imagine your room after you've been playing in it for a super long time, or if you're eating yummy snacks. The air inside can start to feel a little... sleepy or not as fresh, right? That's because when we breathe, we use up the good, invisible air that makes us feel strong, and we breathe out air that's not as good anymore. Also, tiny invisible bits from cooking or even just being in a room can make the air feel a bit yucky. When you're outside, the big wind blows all the old air away and brings in lots of super fresh air, like a giant invisible fan! But inside a room, especially underground where there are no windows or wind, the air just sits there and gets all used up. So, we need special air helpers, like a friendly air pump or a fan, to push all the tired, old air out and pull in lots of new, happy, fresh air so we can breathe easily and stay super healthy and awake!

title: Why is ♡ considered a heart when a heart doesn't look like that? Also, how does it relate to love?
text: Okay, imagine your real heart is like a super important muscle inside you that goes 'thump-thump' all day to send blood everywhere, like a little pump! It's kind of lumpy and squishy, right? The ♡ shape is like a fun drawing we all agreed on a super long time ago. Maybe it looked like some leaves, or maybe it was just easier to draw than a real lumpy heart! It's like how we draw a stick figure for a person, even though people have arms and legs that bend more. And how does it relate to love? Well, when you feel super happy and warm and fuzzy inside because you love someone, like your mommy or your favorite toy, sometimes you feel that happy feeling really strong in your chest, right where your heart is! People long, long ago thought that special warm feeling *came* from their heart, even though it actually comes from your brain. So, they started using that cute ♡ shape to show all those big, happy, loving feelings! So, when you see a ♡, it's a special secret code for 'love'!

title: Why do vitamin C tablets say stuff like 800% your daily value? Does that mean the rest gets wasted?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool little car that needs special fuel called vitamin C to run really well and help you stay strong and not get sick! The "daily value" is like saying your car needs just one small cup of this special fuel every day. But sometimes, when you take a vitamin C tablet, it's like putting a really, really big jug of fuel in your car, way more than just one small cup! Your car is super smart, though. It takes all the fuel it needs to run perfectly, but because this special vitamin C fuel is like water, the extra doesn't get stored up in your car's fuel tank like some other things. Instead, when you go pee-pee, all the extra just washes out of your body, like water going down the drain. So it's not really "wasted" in a bad way, it just means your body got all the good fuel it needed, and then let go of the rest because it didn't need to keep it inside.

title: Why is it so difficult to smell ourselves?
text: Imagine your nose is like a little guard at the door of your house, and its job is to tell you about *new* and exciting smells, like if Mommy is baking cookies or if a stinky dog walks by. Now, your own smell, like the smell of your favorite blanket or your own special toy, is *always* there, right next to you, all day long! The guard sees it constantly, every single second. After a little while, he gets super used to it and doesn't think it's new or interesting anymore, so he stops telling you about it. He's too busy looking for other, newer smells! That's why it's hard for your nose-guard to notice your own smell, because it's always been there.

text: Okay, imagine you're singing your favorite song, like "Wheels on the Bus"! Singers, like Mariah, need to hear their own voice very clearly to make sure they'

title: Why do comedians repeat phrases of their jokes/stories every so often while performing on stage?
text: Okay, imagine a funny person telling you a story, like when your grown-up tells you a silly tale! Sometimes, they say a funny part or a funny word again, just like when you sing a song and a part comes back. They do this for a few reasons! One reason is to help you remember the funny thing they said earlier, so when you hear it again, you giggle even more because you remember the first time it was funny! It's like a special reminder to make you laugh extra hard. Another reason is to get you ready for an even bigger laugh, like when you're waiting for a surprise. It helps build up the fun, making the whole story super-duper funny!

title: What is happening when one commercial is interrupted by/for another?
text: Imagine you're watching your favorite cartoon! Sometimes, the cartoon takes a little nap, and that's when commercials come out to say 'hi!' The TV show needs money to keep making new episodes, and commercials give them that money. So, when you see one commercial, and then another one starts right after, it's just like different friends taking turns to play. One friend (commercial) finishes their turn, and then the next friend (another commercial) starts their turn right away to help the TV show. It's not really interrupted, it's just the next helper coming on the screen!

title: Why is it when we chew/swallow food or drink, we don't gag but if we have to have a medical procedure that involves something going down our airway or dentist, we don't gag?
text: You know how when you eat your favorite yummy snack, your mouth is happy and knows exactly what to do? That's because *you* put the food there, and your brain knows it's yummy and safe to swallow. You're in charge and your body is expecting it! But sometimes, when a grown-up doctor or dentist needs to put a long stick or a little camera down your throat to look inside, your body gets a little bit surprised and thinks, 'Whoa! What's *that*? I didn't ask for that!' It's like your throat has a tiny little guard that gets scared and tries to push it back out, just in case it's something yucky or not supposed to be there. Your body is just trying to protect you, even if the doctor is trying to help!

title: How does Spotify and Apple Music pay artists?
text: Imagine Spotify and Apple Music are like a giant candy store, but instead of selling candy, they let you listen to all your favorite songs! When grown-ups pay their monthly money to listen, all that money goes into a big piggy bank at Spotify or Apple Music. They take a little bit of that money to help keep their candy store running, like paying for the lights and the people who work there. Then, they

title: Why do newspapers often have random sentences where a l l t h e w o r d s a r e w r i t t e n l i k e t h i s?
text: Imagine you have a row of toy blocks, and you want them to go all the way to the end of a shelf, but some of your words (the blocks) are a little bit too short to fill the whole space perfectly. If they just left it, there would be a big empty gap at the end, and it wouldn't look neat. So, what the newspaper makers do is pretend to put tiny invisible springs between the letters in some words. This makes those words stretch out just a little bit, like pulling a rubber band, so they fill up the whole line perfectly and everything looks tidy and even, instead of having big empty gaps. It's like making sure all the blocks fit just right!

title: how does someone like bill gates keep all of his money?
text: Imagine you have a piggy bank, right? When you put your pennies in, they're safe! Bill Gates has a super-duper giant piggy bank, but it's not a real piggy bank you can hold. It's called a **bank**! It's like a very safe house where grown-ups keep their money, and the bank keeps it super safe for him. But he doesn't keep all his money as coins or paper bills; that would be too many! Instead, a lot of his "money" is like owning tiny little pieces of big toy companies or big buildings. Imagine if you owned a tiny piece of the candy store – every time someone buys candy, a tiny bit of that money comes to you because you own a piece of the store! That's what Bill Gates does. He owns parts of lots of big grown-up companies. So his money isn't just sitting there; it's like

title: I just read that it takes 26 hours for New Year to pass all time zones, how can that happen?
text: Imagine our Earth is like a giant, giant ball, and the sun is like a big flashlight shining on just one side of it. When it's nighttime where you live, that's when your part of the ball is facing away from the sun, and that's when you get to celebrate New Year at midnight! But because our Earth ball is so super big and round, not everyone on the ball has midnight at the exact same time. It's like a wave of midnight going all the way around! Some friends on one side of the Earth get to celebrate their New Year super, super early, even when it's still daytime for you on December 31st! And then, after almost everyone has celebrated, there are still some friends on the other side of the Earth who are just getting to their midnight. So, if you count from when the very first friends start their New Year party to when the very last friends finish theirs, it takes a super long time – like 26 hours! That's because the Earth is so wide, and everyone gets their own special turn to have midnight and say 'Happy New Year!'

title: How does overuse of antibiotics actually lead to antibiotic resistant bacteria?
text: Okay, imagine there are tiny little monsters inside your body called germs that make you feel yucky. We have special superhero medicine called antibiotics that go inside you to fight these monsters! Now, some of these monsters are really weak, and the superhero medicine can beat them up super fast. But some monsters are a little bit stronger, like they have tiny shields, and it's harder for the medicine to fight them. If we keep taking the superhero medicine when we don't really need it, or we stop taking it too soon, the strong monsters with shields get to stay alive. Then, these strong monsters have baby monsters, and all their babies also have shields, making them super tough! So, next time you get sick, the superhero medicine can't fight those strong monsters anymore because they've learned how to be super tough, and the medicine just bounces off their shields, so it can't help you get better. That'

title: How can the heart not tire out?
text: Imagine your arm muscles, if you lift a big toy over and over, they get tired and sore, right? They need a nap! Your heart is like a super-duper special muscle, different from your arm or leg muscles. It's built like a super-engine that never stops because it has its own special food delivery system that constantly brings it yummy fuel and oxygen through tiny tubes, so it never runs out of energy. Plus, it's a special kind of muscle that's made for going and going, not for getting tired easily, and it even takes a super-quick mini-rest in between each beat, like a tiny blink, which is just enough to keep it pumping strong forever and ever!

title: How to type Korean?
text: You know how your toy box has different kinds of toys, like cars and blocks? Your computer keyboard is kind of like that, but instead of toys, it has letters! Right now, it's set up to make English letters, like 'A' and 'B'. But Korean letters look like super cool, swirly shapes, totally different from ours! To type Korean, you tell your computer to switch its 'toy box' from English letters to Korean letters. It's like pressing a magic button on the screen or on your keyboard that makes all the keys change their secret job! So when you push 'A', it doesn't make an 'A' anymore, it makes a Korean shape instead. It's really clever, and you just have to learn which key makes which new shape, like learning to draw new pictures!

title: Why are the atomic numbers of elements unique?
text: Imagine all the different kinds of things in the world, like water, air, or the metal in your bike, are made of tiny, tiny special building blocks we call 'elements.' Each different

title: Why can't devices (phones, laptops, etc) make our headphones noise-cancelling?
text: Imagine your special noise-cancelling headphones are like a superhero! They have tiny little ears (called microphones) that listen very carefully to all the loud noises around you, like a barking dog or a noisy car. Then, super-duper fast, they make a *new* sound that's exactly the opposite of the noisy sound, like a magic spell! When the noisy sound and the magic opposite sound meet, they crash into each other and poof! They both disappear, and it becomes quiet for you. Your regular headphones, though, are like a simple toy that only knows how to play the songs or stories you tell it. They don't have those tiny listening ears to hear the outside world, and they don't have the special brain inside to make the magic opposite noise. Your phone or laptop is like the grown-up who tells the simple toy what song to play, but it can't magically give the toy ears or a special brain to become a superhero. The headphones themselves need to be built super special to do that clever trick!

title: why is wearing something bright orange when hunting recommended? Doesn't that defeat the purpose of blending in?
text: Imagine you have special glasses that make everything look a little different. Animals, like deer, have special eyes that are like those glasses, and they see colors differently than you and me! When you wear a super bright orange jacket, you see it as really, really bright, like a big juicy orange or a pumpkin. But to a deer, that bright orange doesn't look bright at all! It looks more like a boring grey or brown, just like the trees and dirt around them. So, the deer doesn't even notice you very much because you just blend in with the forest to them! But guess what? Other people, like your dad or other hunters, *do* see your super bright orange. This is super important because it helps them see *you* and not accidentally think you're an animal. So, the orange helps you hide from the animals, but it helps other people see you so everyone stays safe and no one gets hurt!

title: What is the point of Gerber Life? How does taking a life insurance policy out on your baby give them a good financial start?
text: Imagine Gerber Life is like a special company that helps grown-ups save for when their little ones get big! Life insurance is kind of like a special piggy bank. Grown-ups put a little bit

title: Why is Norton hated so much? What makes an antivirus/antimalware program good or bad anyway?
text:
Okay, imagine your computer is like your toy box, and sometimes yucky sticky monsters (we call them computer viruses or malware) try to sneak in and mess up your toys or even break them! An antivirus program is like a superhero guard dog for your toy box.

Now, Norton is like a guard dog that barks *a lot*, even when there are no monsters around. It might bark so much that it makes it hard for you to hear your own music or play your games, and sometimes it even makes your toy box feel super slow, like when you're trying to run but your shoes are stuck in mud. It also keeps asking your grown-ups for more and more treats (money) and tries to sell them extra leashes or squeaky toys they don't really need, and once you invite it in, it's super tricky to make it leave!

A really good guard dog for your toy box, though, is one that's super smart and *only* barks when a real monster tries to get in. It stays quiet most of the time so you can play, and it doesn't make your toy box

title: If you were travelling faster than the speed of sound, what would happen if you screamed?
text: Imagine you're a super-duper fast superhero, zooming through the air! Sound is like little invisible whispers that travel through the air to people's ears, but it's not as fast as you are. If you scream while you're going super, super fast, faster than your own voice can travel, something funny happens. For anyone *in front* of you, they wouldn't hear your scream until *after* you've already zoomed past them! It's like your voice is trying to run after you but can't catch up. So they'd see you first, then hear your scream a little bit later, or maybe not at all if you kept going really far away. But *you* would still hear your own scream! That's because your voice starts right at your mouth, and your ears are right there on your head, so the sound doesn't have to go far to reach *your* ears. It's like your voice is always with you, even if you're too fast for everyone else to hear it right away!

title: When and how did green generally get associated with positiveness, and red as negativeness?
text: Imagine when you're playing outside! The grass is green, the trees have green leaves, and it feels happy and safe, like it's okay to run and play. We see green lights that mean 'GO!' and it's safe to cross the street. Green is like when your grown-up says 'yes!' or 'good job!' because it means things are growing, safe, and good to go. But then, think about a stop sign, it's red! Red means 'STOP!' or 'NO!' It's like when your grown-up says 'don't touch, it's hot!' for fire, or 'be careful!' Red is like a warning, telling us to wait or that something might be dangerous. So our eyes and brains learn that green means 'go, it's good!' and red means 'stop, be careful!' from all the things we see and are taught every day.

title: Why is it "bad" to make tea in the microwave vs a kettle?
text: Imagine your tea leaves are little sleepy friends who need a warm, bubbly bath to wake up and share all their yummy flavors! When you use a kettle, it's like filling a whole bathtub and making all the water super-duper hot and bubbly from top to bottom. All your sleepy tea friends get to swim in the perfect warm water and make the best, happiest tea. But when you put your cup in the microwave, it's like only making a tiny spot in the bathtub super hot, and the rest is still just warm. Some of your tea friends get too hot too fast, and others don't get warm enough at all! This makes them confused, and they can't make your tea taste as yummy and happy as when all the water is perfectly warm and bubbly together from the kettle.

title: What's that clicking sound in your ears everytime you yawn?
text: Imagine your ear has a tiny, secret door, like a little gate! This gate helps air go in and out of your ear, so the air inside your ear is always just right, like when you let a little air out of a balloon so it doesn't feel too tight. When you do a super big yawn, your mouth opens wide and some muscles in your face give that little gate a tiny push. That push makes the gate open for just a second, letting a little bit of air rush in or out, and that fast little whoosh of air is the "click" sound you hear! It's just your ear making sure everything is comfy and balanced inside.

title: How do Youtubers earn money? I mean, how is revenue generated by simply watching a video. I understand it has something to do with the advertisements, but that is my question, how do ads help Youtubers earn money.
text: Imagine your favorite YouTuber is like a friend who builds amazing LEGO castles or sings silly songs. They work hard to make those fun videos for you! Now, sometimes, before you see their video, or maybe in the middle, a tiny little commercial pops up. It might be for a new toy, or a yummy snack, or a place where grown-ups buy things. Those commercials are put there by big companies, like the toy company that makes your favorite action figures. They *pay* YouTube money to show you their toys, because they want you to know about them and maybe ask your grown-ups to buy them. YouTube is like the big playground where all the videos live. When those companies pay YouTube, YouTube then gives a little piece of that money to your favorite YouTuber. So, the more people watch the videos and see those little commercials, the more money the toy company pays YouTube, and the more money YouTube shares with the person who made the fun video. It's like a thank you for making a great place for companies to show their ads!

title: How does Shutterfly make profit when it gives away so many discounts and free things?
text: Imagine Shutterfly is like a candy store that gives you one yummy gummy bear for free! Why do they do that? Because they want you to taste how good it is and come inside their store. Once you're there for the free gummy bear, you might see a big chocolate bar or a whole bag of lollipops and decide to buy those too! Shutterfly gives you a free magnet or a small picture book so you can try making something fun with your photos and see how good it looks. After you make that free thing, you might think, "Oh, I want a *bigger* book!" or "This book needs *more pages*!" or "I also want a mug with my picture on it!" So, you end up buying the bigger

title: What is a tensor?
text: Okay, imagine you have a simple number, like "3." That's easy, right? Now, imagine you have a number *and* a direction, like "walk 3 steps forward!" That's like a little arrow pointing somewhere. A tensor is like a super-duper special kind of "number-thing" that helps grown-ups talk about things that are even trickier, things that need *lots

title: What determines the borders where each timezone starts? If I live on the line which timezone do I follow?
text: Imagine the world is a giant spinning ball, and the sun shines on different parts as it spins. To make sure everyone doesn't have a totally different "morning" time from their neighbor, grown-ups drew invisible lines on the map. These lines mostly follow countries or big areas, so everyone in one country usually knows what time it is, like having a shared rule for bedtime. Sometimes they go around mountains or big rivers too, so towns stay together. It's like drawing lines on a playground to say "this is your spot" and "this is my spot" for playing. If your house is right on one of those invisible lines, it's a bit like having one foot in one spot and one foot in another! But grown-ups are smart, so they usually make sure the line goes *around* towns or cities. So, everyone in your town will follow the *same* time, usually the time decided by the country or state you're in. You just follow what all the other grown-ups in your town say the time is, so you're not confused about when to eat lunch or watch your favorite show!

title: Why is there a separate security code on credit cards? If the three extra digits make it that much more secure, why not just make the number three digits longer?
text: Imagine your credit card is like a special magic key to buy things. The long number on the front is like the main part of your key, and it tells the shop who you are.

title: How do rebreathers work?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special juice box. Normally, when you drink some juice, you throw the whole box away, right? That's a bit wasteful! A rebreather is like a super clever juice box for your breath when you're underwater. Instead of just breathing air from a tank and blowing out all your used breath as big bubbles, this special machine catches your breath! When you breathe out, your breath has less good air (oxygen) and more yucky air (carbon dioxide). The rebreather is like a magic cleaning machine: it takes out all the yucky air, adds just a tiny bit of fresh, good air back in, and then gives it back to you to breathe again! This means your air tank lasts a super, super long time, like your juice box never running out, and you don't make any noisy bubbles to scare the fish! It's like recycling your breath!

title: Why do non-fighters collapse when they get elbowed in the head, but MMA fighters can take it with the punches so to speak?
text: Imagine your head is like a yummy, wobbly jelly inside a bowl! When someone who doesn't fight gets elbowed, it's like someone suddenly bumps your bowl super hard when you're not ready! The jelly (your brain) gets really jiggled and confused, and your body says, "Whoa! Too much! Time for a quick nap!" and you just flop down. But MMA fighters practice a lot! They make their neck muscles super strong, like a strong bouncy spring that helps hold their head steady so the jelly doesn't jiggle *as much*. They also learn how to move their head *with* the punch, like letting a swing go with a push instead of stopping it suddenly, which makes the hit feel less bumpy. Plus, they expect it, so their body is a little more ready. But even with all that practice, if a punch is super, super strong, or hits just the right spot, even *their* jelly gets too jiggled, and they fall down too!

title: How do card readers know that a card has a chip?
text: Imagine your toy box has two special ways to play with your toys! One way is if you slide a toy quickly, and it just makes a little "beep!" (That's like the stripe on your card.) The other way is if you push a special toy *into* a slot and leave it there, and that toy actually starts talking to your toy box, saying "Hello! I'm here!" (That's like the shiny chip on your card.) When you put your card into the reader, it's like your smart toy box. It always *first* tries to see if you've pushed a "talking" chip toy into its slot. If it feels the chip and hears it say "Hello!", it knows right away, "Aha! This is a chip card, let's play the chip game!" If it doesn't feel a chip, then it waits for you to slide the card instead, to play the "beep!" game. So, it always tries the "smartest" way first!

title: Why do we capitalize "Happy New Year"?
text: "Happy New Year" is like a special, important name for a very fun party day! Imagine your name, like [Child's Name] – you always start it with a big letter, right? Well, "New Year" isn't just any year; it's a special day when we celebrate and say goodbye to the old year and hello to the new one. Because it's such a special, important day that happens once a year, we give it big, capital letters, just like we do for special names of people, or cities, or even holidays like Christmas or Halloween. And "Happy" goes with it to make the whole greeting super special, so it gets a big letter too! It shows everyone how important and exciting that day is!

title: Why do most spiders have many eyes, but poor vision?
text: Imagine you have lots and lots of tiny little windows all over your face, not just two big ones like us! That's kind of like a spider, they can have six or even eight little eyes. But even with all those tiny windows, they don't see things super clearly like when you watch your favorite show on TV. Instead, each little eye is really good at one special job. Some eyes are good at seeing if something is moving, like a wobbly fly. Other eyes are good at just seeing if it's bright or dark, or if a big shadow is coming. So, they have many eyes to help them notice different things happening all around them, like having many little helpers. But to really know what's going on, they mostly use their super-sensitive legs to feel the world, like feeling tiny wiggles on their web or vibrations on the ground, which is even better than seeing for them!

title: How was the canyon diablo meteorite, an object not from earth, used to determine the age of the earth?
text: Imagine our Earth is like a giant, super old cake, and we want to know when it was baked! It's hard to tell by looking at the cake itself because it's been squished, melted, and changed a lot over time. But then, we found a special little crumb (that's the Canyon Diablo meteorite) that fell off the same big bowl of batter (the space dust) when our Earth cake was being made! This crumb is special because it hasn't been squished or changed much, so it's like a perfect little timer. Inside this crumb, there are tiny "sand timers" that count down very, very slowly, turning one kind of sand (like uranium) into another kind (like lead). By looking at how much of each sand is in the crumb now, scientists can tell exactly how long the timer has been running. Since this crumb and our Earth cake were baked at the same time from the same stuff, the time on the crumb's timer tells us how old our Earth cake is too – super, super old, like 4 and a half billion years!

title: Why are kinder eggs banned in America, but knockoffs aren't?
text: Okay, imagine your yummy chocolate egg. The grown-ups in America have a special rule that says food can't have a toy *hidden right inside* it, like mixed into the chocolate itself. They worry that if you eat your chocolate too fast, you might accidentally swallow the toy, and that's not safe for little kids. That's why the original Kinder Eggs, with the toy *inside* the chocolate, can't come to America. But the other eggs, the ones that look similar, are okay because their toy isn't hidden *inside* the chocolate. Maybe the toy is in its own little plastic container *next to* the chocolate, or in a separate part of the package. That way, you can easily see the toy and take it out before you munch on your yummy treat, which makes it safe!

title: Why do mobile games suck, even though phones are more powerful than good handheld gaming systems like Gameboy?
text: Imagine your old Gameboy was like a special toy car made *just* for racing – it was super, super good at that one thing! Your phone is like a big toy truck that can also carry your other toys, play songs, and show cartoons. It's super strong because it can do *lots* of different things. The grown-ups who make phone games often want you to keep playing and maybe even ask your grown-up for real money to get new sparkly things in the game, more than just making the game super duper fun all the time. Also, pushing real buttons on a Gameboy feels much easier for jumping and running than just tapping a flat screen with your finger, right? Gameboy games were made for long, exciting adventures, but many phone games are just for quick little plays when you're waiting for something, not for a big, amazing story that keeps you playing for hours.

title: Why is the golden ratio common to so many things of different nature?
text: Imagine you have a super special building block or a secret recipe that makes everything look just right and pretty! The golden ratio is like that secret number. Nature uses it a lot because it's a really good way to build things that work well, like how the seeds grow in a sunflower so they all get sunshine, or how a snail's shell curls up perfectly strong. It's like nature found the best way to grow things so they are strong and look nice. And then, people who make art or build houses saw how pretty things looked when they followed this secret recipe, so they started using it too! Our eyes just naturally like things that are built with this special "pretty rule," even if we don't know why. It's like a secret trick for making things beautiful everywhere!

title: What causes your nasal cavity to sometimes "burn" when there is liquid entering it, but other times it isn't painful?
text: Okay, imagine the inside of your nose has super special, tiny little cells, like tiny balloons! These balloons are filled with a special kind of water, a bit salty, just like a tiny ocean inside your body. When you get liquid in your nose and it feels like a big ouchy burn, that happens because the liquid isn't like the special water inside your nose balloons. If the water is too plain, like tap water, your nose balloons try to drink *all* of it really fast, and they get too full and puffy, which makes your nose feel stingy! Or, if the

title: What is the pixel resolution of regular eyesight and what minimum resolution would be needed for VR glasses to match a normal person's vision?
text: Your eyes are super-duper amazing cameras that don't have "pixels" like a TV at all! They see everything super smooth and clear, like a perfect drawing with no

title: Why is ice-cream that's melted then frozen much harder to scoop than fresh ice-cream?
text: Imagine your ice cream is like a super fluffy cloud, full of tiny, tiny little ice sprinkles and lots of air bubbles that make it soft and easy to dig your spoon into. When your ice cream melts, all those tiny ice sprinkles turn into water, and the air bubbles float away like balloons. Then, when you put it back in the freezer, that water turns into big, spiky ice rocks instead of tiny sprinkles, and there's not much fluffy air left. It's like trying to dig through a pile of big, hard rocks instead of a soft cloud, which is why it's so much harder to scoop!

title: How do the police trace a bullet back to its gun?
text: Imagine your finger has little swirly lines, right? Those are your fingerprints, and everyone's are different! Well, inside a gun, there are tiny, tiny bumps and lines, kind of like the gun's own special fingerprint. When a bullet goes super fast through the gun, it gets little scratches and marks from those bumps and lines. It's like the gun leaves its unique mark on the bullet! So, when the police find a bullet, they look at those tiny scratches super close with a special magnifying glass. If they find a gun they think might have shot it, they shoot a new bullet from *that* gun into a big soft catcher. Then, they compare the scratches on the bullet they found to the scratches on the new bullet from the suspect gun. If the scratches match up perfectly, like two matching puzzle pieces, then they know for sure that gun fired that bullet! It's like finding a perfect match for a fingerprint, but for bullets and guns.

title: Why is the moment of death always associated with "the light going out from one's eyes"? Does this actually happen or is it just a metaphor?
text: When people say "the light goes out from someone's eyes," it's kind of like a story or a way to describe something, not a real light bulb turning off! When someone is alive and happy, their eyes look bright and shiny, right? They move around, look at you, and you can see them thinking and feeling things inside, almost like a little sparkle. That's because their brain is working, and they're looking at the world. But when someone dies, their body stops working, like a toy car when its batteries run out. Their eyes stop moving, blinking, and looking around. So, that bright, lively look, that "sparkle" that makes them seem so awake and aware, isn't there anymore. It's not that a real light goes out, but their eyes just don't have that active, alive look anymore, which makes people say the "light" has gone. It's a way to explain that the person isn't here with us and active anymore.

title: Does the question "what was before the Big Bang?" even make sense?
text: Imagine you're watching a super-duper long movie, but this movie isn't like regular movies, it's about *everything* in the whole wide world! The Big Bang is like the very, very first second that movie ever started playing. Before that, there wasn't even a movie screen, no popcorn, no movie theater, and no "time" for the movie to even be playing *in*. So, asking "what was before the Big Bang?" is a bit like asking "what happened *before* the movie even started playing?" It's a tricky question because "before" only makes sense once the movie (or time!) has actually begun. Scientists are still trying to figure out if there was anything *else* before our movie started, but for *our* movie, the Big Bang was the very first word.

title: How do life insurers make a profit?
text: Imagine lots of grown-ups give their piggy bank money to a special company. This company makes a promise: if one of those grown-ups doesn't wake up anymore, the company will give some money to their family to help them. Now, this company is super smart! They know that most grown-ups will stay awake and play for a very, very long time. So, they collect tiny bits of money from many, many grown-ups every month. While they hold onto all that money, they're super good at making it grow bigger, like planting a tiny seed

title: Why is your reflection upside-down when you look at a spoon on the side that is curved inwards?
text: Okay, imagine your face is like a bunch of tiny invisible lines of light, some coming from your head, some from your tummy, and some from your feet. When these lines of light hit the shiny, curvy spoon (the side that scoops soup!), it's like the spoon is a special slide for the light. The light from your head, which is at the top, hits the spoon and gets pushed *down* to the bottom part of where your reflection shows up. And the light from your feet, which is at the bottom, hits the spoon and gets pushed *up* to the top part of your reflection! So, it's like the spoon does a funny magic trick and makes all the light lines cross over, so your head and feet look like they've swapped places, making you look upside-down!

title: Why and how do Epsom Salts soothe sore muscles?
text: Okay, imagine you played super, super hard, and your muscles feel a bit "ouchy" or tired, like they need a gentle hug! Epsom salts are special little crystals you can put in your warm bath water, but they're not the kind of salt you eat with your food. When these special crystals melt in the warm water, your skin is like a little sponge, and it drinks up some of the good stuff from the water. This good stuff has something called magnesium in it, which is like a happy helper for your body! When your skin soaks up this happy helper, it goes into your tired muscles and helps them relax and feel much better, like they're getting a warm, gentle hug. So, the "ouchy" feeling goes away, and you feel comfy and ready to play again!

title: Bicameral legislatures - how do they work and why do they exist?
text: Imagine you have two grown-ups who make rules for your house, like if you can have cookies or stay up late. One grown-up might say 'yes!' and the other might say 'hmm, maybe not, let's think about it more.' For a rule to happen, *both* grown-ups have to say 'yes' and agree it's a super good idea. That's kind of like how some countries make their big rules, called laws! Instead of just one big group of people making all the rules, they have *two* big groups, like two teams. This is called a 'bicameral legislature' – 'bi' means two, like a bicycle has two wheels! They work by one team making a rule idea, and then the other team looks at it really carefully to make sure it's fair and good for *everyone* – not just a few people. If both teams agree, then the rule becomes a real law! They exist so that no one team can make a silly or unfair rule all by themselves, and so that lots of different people get to have their ideas heard and make sure the rules are the best they can be for all the people in the country. It's like having two sets of eyes to make sure everything is just right!

title: How do fetishes work/how do you get them?
text: You know how sometimes you have a favorite blanket or a special toy that just makes you feel super cozy and happy, even more than your other toys? And maybe it's not the whole toy, but just how soft it feels or the color of it? Well, grown-ups have special feelings too, like when they really, really like someone. Sometimes, our super clever brains connect those grown-up happy feelings to a very specific *thing* or a *part* of something, instead of just the whole person. It's like your brain learned that when *this specific thing* is around, it means happy grown-up feelings are coming! It's not something you pick, like choosing what flavor ice cream you want. It just kind of happens over time as your brain learns and makes these special connections, like how if you

title: Why does a mere air bubble in the circulatory system prove to be fatal?
text: Imagine your body is like a super busy city, and your blood is like tiny little cars carrying food and air (we call it oxygen) to all the houses (your body parts) and taking away the trash. These cars drive on tiny roads called blood vessels. Now, if a big, bouncy balloon (that's the air bubble!) gets stuck in one of the main roads, all the little cars get stuck behind it! They can't get past to deliver the food and air to the houses further down the road. If a very important house, like your brain (which helps you think and move) or your heart (which is like the engine for all the cars), doesn't get its food and air for even a little bit, it gets very sad and stops working. And if those super important parts stop working, your whole body can't keep going anymore, which is why it's so dangerous.

title: How do we know animals are not as self-conscious as humans?
text: Imagine you look in a mirror, and you know that's *you*! You know you have your own thoughts and feelings, and you are a special person. That's

title: why credit cards are safer than debit cards?
text: Imagine you have two special cards. One is like using money that a grown-up (the bank!) lets you borrow for a little while to buy something yummy. That's your credit

title: Does being out in the "cold" without a coat actually make you more prone to being sick?
text: No, not really! Being cold outside without a coat doesn't *make* you sick all by itself. The things that make you sick are tiny, invisible bugs called germs that fly around and get inside you. Your body is like a superhero that fights off these germs! If you get super duper cold, your body has to spend a lot of energy staying warm, and sometimes that makes it a little bit harder for your superhero body to fight off the germs if they are already trying to get you. So, it's always best to wear your coat to stay warm and cozy, so your body can save all its superhero energy for fighting off those naughty germs!

title: Why does driving long distances make people tired?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super important captain of a ship, and when you're driving, your captain brain has to watch *everything* very, very carefully for a long, long time! It's looking out for other cars, remembering which way to go, and making sure your hands and feet do the right things. That's a super big job for your captain brain, like playing a very long game where you have to concentrate a lot! Your eyes are also like two little cameras that have to stare at the road for hours without looking away much, and they get tired from all that looking. Even though your body is sitting down, it's not really moving around and playing like it usually does, and sometimes when your body stays still for too long, it starts to think, "Hmm, maybe it's nap time!" So, all that hard work for your brain and eyes, and your body not moving much, makes your whole self feel super sleepy, like your captain brain needs a big rest after being so busy!

title: Will sovereign states/countries ever shift from being republics to some different system of government just like how monarchies were slowly phased out? Why or why not?
text: Imagine your country is like a really big game, and the government is like the rules of that game. Right now, most countries play a game called a "republic." That means everyone gets to help choose the grown-ups who are the bosses, like how you might choose which game to play with your friends. A long, long time ago, many countries played a different game called a "monarchy," where one family always had the boss, like if only one kid was always the leader of every game just because they were born into it. People slowly changed that game because they wanted to pick their own bosses and have more say. So, will republics change? Maybe! If people keep being happy with choosing their bosses, they'll probably keep playing the republic game. But if people get unhappy, or if someone comes along with a really, really convincing new game idea,

title: Why is salt iodized?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool car, and your brain is the driver! To make sure your brain driver is super smart and can think really fast, it needs a special kind of tiny, tiny food called "iodine." It's like a magic brain vitamin! If your brain doesn't get enough of this magic food, it might get a little sleepy, or not grow as big and clever as it should. Now, lots of people eat salt, right? Like the salt on your yummy chips or popcorn! So, smart grown-ups decided to put a tiny bit of that special brain-magic iodine right into the salt. That way, when you eat a little bit of salt, your brain gets its special treat and can grow super strong and smart every day without even thinking about it! It's like sneaking healthy stuff into your favorite snack!

title: In the past, chopping off a hand was a common punishment for thieves. What exactly happens afterwards?
text: Okay, imagine you get a really, really big boo-boo where your hand used to be – it would hurt so, so much, and lots of red juice, like from a strawberry, would come out! People would try to stop the red juice from flowing out, maybe by wrapping it up super tight. After a while, if you were lucky, your skin would try to close up the big boo-boo, like when a scab forms on your knee. But your hand wouldn't grow back. So, you'd have to learn to do everything with just one hand, like eating your food, drawing pictures, or playing with toys, which would be super tricky and make many things much harder for the rest of your life.

title: What happens to our bodies when we don't get enough sleep over a long period of time?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool toy robot that needs to charge its batteries every night to work its best. If you don't let it charge for a long, long time, it starts to get really tired and slow. You feel super sleepy all the time, even when you're trying to play! Your brain, which is like the robot's control panel, gets all fuzzy and it's hard to think straight, remember things, or learn new games. You might even feel a bit grumpy, like when you're hungry. Also, your body has special little helpers that fight off yucky germs, and they get sleepy too, so you might get sick more often. And your body needs sleep to grow big and strong and fix little boo-boos inside, so if you don't charge it enough, it's harder for it to do all that important work. That's why getting enough sleep helps your body stay happy and ready to play!

title: Why does the face get so many more pimples when the hands/feet/arms are in much more contact with dirt etc.?
text: Imagine your skin has tiny, tiny little holes, like mini straws, all over it! These are called pores. Your face has lots and lots of these holes, and many of them are super busy making a special kind of slippery oil to keep your skin soft and happy. Sometimes, too much of this slippery oil, mixed with tiny bits of old skin that fall off (like dust you can't see!), gets stuck in these little holes. Then, super tiny invisible bugs, called bacteria, come along and say, "Ooh, a party!" and they make the hole get a little red and puffy, and that's a pimple! Your hands and feet touch lots more dirt when you play, but their skin doesn't make as much of that slippery oil that gets stuck in the holes and makes pimples. So, even though they get super dirty, they don't get as many pimple parties as your face does!

title: How come full siblings share only 50% genetic with each other and not 100% since they both have the same parents?
text: Imagine your mommy and daddy each have a big, big bag of colorful LEGOs, and these LEGOs are like tiny little instruction books that tell you what color your eyes will be or if you'll have a tiny nose. When you were made, mommy reached into her bag and pulled out *some* of her LEGOs, and daddy reached into his bag and pulled out *some* of his LEGOs, and those LEGOs made you! But here's the fun part: when your brother or sister was made, mommy and daddy reached into their *same* bags again, but they pulled out a *different* mix of LEGOs! It's like if mommy has a red LEGO and a blue LEGO, and daddy has a green LEGO and a yellow LEGO. You might get the red and the green ones. Your brother might get the blue and the yellow ones! You both got LEGOs from mommy and daddy, but not the exact same ones, just a different yummy mix each time. That's why you look a little bit alike, but not exactly the same, because you share about half of those special LEGOs, but the other half are different!

title: Why do we remember some dreams, sometimes for years, but tend to forget others right away?
text: Imagine your brain is like a big playroom where you play pretend games all night long! Most of the games you play are super quick and quiet, like a little whisper, and as soon as you stop playing and wake up, all those quiet games just poof! They disappear because your brain quickly puts all those toys away. But sometimes, your brain plays a really loud game, or a super-duper exciting one, or maybe even a little bit scary one! If you wake up *right* when that special, loud game is happening or just finished, it's like someone called your name while you were still holding the toys! You remember that game because your brain hasn't had time to put those special toys away yet. And if it was a *really* big, special game, like finding a treasure, your brain might keep that memory out for a long, long time, like a special drawing you made and put on the fridge, so you remember it for many days or even years!

title: In a box of tissue paper, how does the next piece of tissue come out when you pull out the one above it?
text: Imagine all the tissues inside the box are holding hands in a special zig-zag line, like a little paper snake. They're folded up so cleverly! When you pull one tissue out, it's like you're gently pulling the hand of the first tissue in the line. Because they're all connected in that zig-zag fold, when the first one comes out, it gently pulls the next one's hand, and that next tissue pops its head up just a little bit, ready for you to grab it! They always help the next one come up.

title: Why are floppy discs called "Floppy" if they're not floppy?
text: Okay, imagine your very first teddy bear. Maybe it was super soft and squishy, right? Well, a long, long time ago, the *first* floppy disks were like that! They were really big, like a dinner plate, and inside their protective sleeve, the actual disk part was made of a bendy, soft plastic that could really flop around if you held it. That's why people called them "floppy" – because they truly were floppy! Later, they made smaller, stronger ones that came in a hard, plastic box, which made them feel not floppy at all, like a toy car instead of a teddy bear. But because everyone already knew the name "floppy disk" from the old, bendy ones, the name just stuck, even for the newer, hard ones! It's a bit like calling all tissues "Kleenex" even if they're not that brand.

title: Why do roads have unnecessary bends?
text: Imagine you're trying to walk across your room in a perfectly straight line, but oops! There's your big toy box, or maybe your comfy couch, right in the way! You have to walk *around* them, right? Roads are just like that! Sometimes there are big hills, or squiggly rivers, or even people's houses and important trees that we can't just move. So, the road makes a little bendy-wiggle to go around them, because it's much easier and cheaper than trying to dig through a giant hill or knock down someone's home just to make it perfectly straight!

title: What happens with plane after emergency landing on water?
text: Okay, imagine a big airplane is flying, but oopsie, it has to land and there's no airport, just big water! So, the pilot makes it land super gently on the water, like a giant duck landing on a pond. For a little while, the plane floats like a big boat! Everyone inside quickly uses bouncy slides (they're called emergency slides!) to get out and into little boats called rafts, so they can be safe. But airplanes aren't really boats, so after everyone is out, water starts to sneak in. Slowly, slowly, the big plane gets heavy with water and goes down, down, down to the very bottom of the ocean, like a big, heavy toy that sank in the bathtub. It usually just stays there, super deep under the water, because it's too big and heavy for grown-ups to easily pull back up.

title: How do data collectors account for people who put random answers in surveys?
text: Imagine we're asking all your friends what their favorite color is. Most of them will say "blue" or "red" or "yellow." But then, maybe one friend says "banana!"

title: What are the "natural flavors" listed in some of these zero calorie drinks?
text: Imagine your favorite yummy strawberry! "Natural flavors" are like a special trick to get *just* that super yummy strawberry taste, or the taste of a lemon, or even a spice, without having to put a whole strawberry or lemon in your drink. Smart grown-ups look at real things that taste good, like fruits or plants, and they figure out what tiny, tiny parts make them taste that way. Then, they carefully take *just* those tiny taste parts out. So, when your drink says "natural flavors," it means they put those special taste parts, which came from something real like a fruit or a plant, into your drink to make it taste delicious and exciting, even if there's no sugar or real fruit juice in it. It's like getting the yummy taste of a real thing, made super small and put into your drink!

title: Why do we salivate and gulp when we are nervous or put on the spot?
text: When you feel a bit worried or shy, like when mommy asks you to sing a song in front of everyone, your body has a special alarm that goes off! This alarm makes your body get ready for *anything*. Sometimes, it makes your mouth feel a little dry first, like when you've been running a lot, and then your body tries to fix it super fast by making *lots* of extra spit, like a tiny waterfall in your mouth! All that extra spit makes you want to gulp it down, because there's suddenly so much of it! It's like your body is saying, "Whoops, too much spit, let's swallow it quick!" because it's still trying to figure out what to do when that worry alarm goes off.

title: How can Publishers Clearing House afford to give away $5,000 per week for "forever"?
text: Okay, imagine Publishers Clearing House is like a big toy store. They want lots and lots of grown-ups to come look at their toys and buy them, like magazines or things for the house. To get everyone super excited to come in, they have a special game where they give away a little bit of money every week, like a super fun party trick! When grown-ups come to play the game, they also see all the toys and many of them buy some. The money PCH makes from selling all those toys to so many grown-ups is much, much, much bigger than the little bit of money they give away for the game. So, they can keep giving away that money for "forever" as long as lots and lots of people keep buying their toys, because they always make more money than they give away!

title: Why does slow motion video of car headlights look like they are blinking rapidly?
text: Okay, imagine your eyes are like a camera that takes pictures. When you look at a car light, your eyes take pictures so fast that the light looks like it's always on, right? But guess what? Most lights, especially the ones in cars, are actually turning on and off super, super fast – like a tiny, invisible switch is flicking them on and off hundreds of times every single second! It's so fast that your eyes can't even tell. Now, a slow-motion video camera is like a super-duper fast eye! It takes so many pictures every second, way more than your own eyes. So when it looks at those car lights, it's fast enough to actually catch them when they are on AND when they are off. It's like it's finally seeing that invisible switch being flicked! That's why, in the video, it looks like they are blinking, even though to your regular eyes, they look perfectly steady. The camera is just fast enough to see the light's super-secret on-off dance!

title: What causes the feeling of weak muscles when you have a cold or a flu?
text: Imagine your body is like a big house, and sometimes tiny, invisible "bad guys" (germs!) try to sneak in and make you feel yucky. When that happens, your body's "superhero team" wakes up and starts fighting those bad guys to kick them out! Fighting is super hard work, just like how you get tired after running and playing all day. Because your body's superheroes are so busy using all their energy to fight the germs, there isn't much energy left for your muscles to run, jump, or even lift your toys. That's why your arms and legs feel so tired and weak – your body is just trying its best to get rid of the yucky germs so you can feel strong again!

title: Why do companies use such low amounts of natural juice in soda, is there a reason for this? And are all the other components really necessary in such amount?
text: Imagine soda is like a special, fizzy treat, not like your everyday apple juice. Companies don't put much real juice in soda for a few reasons. One, real juice costs more money

title: How does the Queen decide who to knight? There's 1000s of people on this year's honor list how are they aware of them all to know if they deserve an award? Also how do they decide who deserves a CBE vs an OBE vs an MBE etc?
text: Imagine the King (who used to be the Queen!) is like the head teacher of a super big school, and he wants to give out special gold stars to grown-ups who do really

title: Why is it that, during menstruation, the womb lining is broken down, only to be built up again almost immediately?
text: Imagine your tummy has a special little room inside, like a tiny cozy bed for a baby. Every month, your body works super hard to make this bed extra soft and squishy with lots of fluffy blankets, just in case a baby wants to come and sleep there – it's like preparing a beautiful, warm nest! But if no baby comes to sleep in the bed that month, your body thinks, "Oh, nobody used this bed, so let's clean it all up!" So, it takes away all those soft blankets – that's what your period is, like sweeping out the old blankets. And as soon as it's clean, your body starts making *new*, fresh, soft blankets again for the *next* month, just in case a baby decides to come then! It's always getting ready, just in case!

title: Why does the body crave bad/fatty foods after a night of drinking alcohol?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a little car, and when grown-ups have their special grown-up drinks, it makes the car work super hard to clean everything up. This makes your body-car really tired and extra thirsty, like it ran a long race! The next day, your body feels a bit sad and empty, so it really wants something quick and easy to make it feel better and give it energy super fast. Sugary and fatty foods are like a big, yummy cookie or a warm blanket – they make your body feel happy and full very quickly, even if it's just for a little while, because it thinks it needs lots of quick energy to fix itself and feel normal again after being so tired and thirsty.

title: What exactly is a Diplomat and why do we have them?
text: Imagine your house is one big country, and your friend's house across the street is another big country. A diplomat is like a very special grown-up friend who lives at your house but then goes to live at your friend's house for a long time. Their super important job is to talk to your friend's grown-ups for your grown-ups! We have them so that all the different countries in the world can talk to each other nicely, like talking about sharing toys or helping each other out, so they stay friends and don't get into big arguments or fights. They're like the friendly messengers who make sure everyone understands each other and gets along!

title: Why was amputation so common during the Civil War?
text: Imagine your arm or leg got a really, really bad boo-boo, not just a little scrape, but like a big, heavy rock fell on it and smashed the bones all apart. During the Civil War, the bullets were big and made huge, messy holes, and the doctors didn't have special tools to fix bones that were broken into tiny pieces, or magic medicine to stop invisible "germs" from getting into the boo-boo and making the whole body super sick, like a really bad cold that never goes away. So, to stop the sickness from spreading to the rest of the body and to save the person's life, just like you'd cut off a yucky part of an apple to save the good part, the doctors had to carefully take off the very, very hurt arm or leg. It was the best way they knew to keep people alive when they had such terrible injuries.

title: Why do potato chips' such as: Ketchup, All Dressed, and Dill Pickle sales tests perform so poorly in the US, but are among the top flavours in other countries?
text: Imagine you love apple juice, and it's your favorite drink ever! But your friend from a different town might love orange juice the most because that's what they always drank when they were little. Both are super yummy, but you just like what you know best! It's the same with potato chips. In some countries, like Canada, kids grow up eating chips that taste like ketchup, or a mix of all sorts of yummy things (that's "All Dressed"), or sour pickles. So, those flavors feel super normal and delicious to them, and they buy them a lot! But in America, most kids grow up eating chips that taste like plain salt, or cheese, or BBQ sauce. So, when they try a ketchup chip, it feels a bit new and different, like trying a super sour lemon when you're used to sweet grapes. It's not that one is better than the other, it's just what people are used to from when they were little, and what their tummies expect to taste! So, the chips that feel "normal" to kids in Canada feel a bit "ooh, what's that?" to kids in America, and they don't pick those ones from the store as much.

title: What would happen to astronauts in orbit if earth instantly disappeared?
text: Imagine you're spinning a toy car on a string around your head really fast. The string is like Earth, pulling the car to go in a big circle. If the string suddenly vanished, the car wouldn't just stop or fall down, would it? Nope! It would keep going straight, super fast, off into the room because nothing is pulling it into a circle anymore. That's just like the astronauts! They would keep zooming straight ahead, past where Earth used to be, out into the super-duper big, empty space. They wouldn't stop moving because there's nothing out there to slow them down, and they'd just float away into the cold, dark universe, forever and ever, unless something else bumped into them!

title: Why does boiling water soften pasta and vegetables, but harden eggs?
text: Okay, imagine your pasta and veggies are like a dry, stiff sponge or a hard cracker. They have tiny, tiny parts inside that are hard. When you put them in super hot water,

title: Why is the side order of fruit at American restaurants an overwhelming amount of cantaloupe and honeydew?
text: Imagine a restaurant is like a big kitchen, and they want to give you yummy things, but they also need to be smart about what they buy, just like when mommy goes to the store. Cantaloupe and honeydew melons are like super special friends for restaurants because they are not very expensive to buy a whole

title: Why does holding down the power button on devices work even when the system is frozen?
text: Imagine your toy robot is playing, but then it gets super stuck! It just freezes and won't move its arms or legs, and it won't listen when you tell it to stop. Its little robot brain is all mixed up and busy doing nothing. Now, the power button you hold down is like a secret, super-duper "off" switch that's not part of the robot's brain at all. It's like a special plug you can pull from the wall. Even if the robot's brain is totally stuck and can't understand anything, that special switch can still cut *all* the electricity going to it. It's a very simple, direct way to say "no more power!" so the robot has to completely stop and then can start fresh again when you turn it back on.

title: What is that feeling we get in our stomach when we're hungry? Why does it happen?
text: You know that funny rumbling, squishy feeling in your tummy, sometimes like a little ache, when you haven't eaten for a while? That's your tummy telling you it's time for more food! Imagine your body is like a toy car that needs batteries to go zoom. When the batteries are almost empty, the car slows down. Your body uses the food you eat as its special batteries. When your tummy is empty and your body has used up all the energy from the last food, your tummy muscles start to move and squeeze all by themselves, like they're looking around for more food to put inside. This squeezing and moving is what makes that rumbling sound and the funny empty feeling. It's just your tummy's way of saying, "Please, can I have some yummy food now so I can have more energy to play!"

title: When they say "we didn't have the technology then," what does that specifically refer to? Why were USB sticks only able to hold 500 MB a few years ago but are now able to hold hundreds of GB? What specifically changes in that time frame?
text: When grown-ups say "we didn't have the technology then," it's like saying we didn't know the best magic tricks or have the right special tools to build something yet! Imagine you want to build a super tall castle. A long time ago, we only knew how to stack big, clunky blocks. That's our old 'technology.' Now, think about your USB stick, which is like a tiny little library for your pictures and games. A few years ago, it was like a library that could only hold a few big books. But then, smart people learned how to make the 'pages' inside the USB stick super, super tiny, and they figured out how to fit millions and millions of those tiny pages into the same small space! What changed is that we got better at making things incredibly small and incredibly clever. It's like instead of clunky blocks, we learned how to make super tiny, super strong LEGO bricks that can fit together in amazing new ways. So, the 'recipe' for making the USB stick got much, much better, allowing it to hold hundreds of times more stories and pictures without getting any bigger!

title: Why does cabin depressurization cause a plane to crash?
text: Imagine a plane is like a giant, super strong bubble that flies way up high in the sky! Inside our bubble, there's special air that helps us breathe easily and keeps us warm, just like in your house. But way up high outside the bubble, there's almost no air to breathe, and it's super, super cold! Now, if our plane-bubble gets a boo-boo, like a little hole or a crack, all that nice, warm air inside rushes out super, super fast! This is called 'depressurization.' When that happens, suddenly there's not

title: how can the identity of icefrog, someone who makes dota 2, one of the biggest games in the world, be unknown?
text: Imagine your favorite toy designer, who makes the coolest toys ever! But instead of telling everyone their name and showing their face, they like to stay a little secret, like a ninja or a superhero who just makes awesome things and then goes back to their quiet home. Nobody knows who Batman really is under the mask, right? It's kind of like that with Icefrog, who makes Dota 2. He's super smart and good at making games, but he just likes to do his work quietly without lots of people pointing at him and saying 'THAT'S HIM!'. The grown-ups who help him with the game know, but they promise to keep his secret because it's his special wish. So, even though his game is super popular, he gets to have his own special quiet space, just like you might like to play with your toys by yourself sometimes.

title: A deer can eat poisonous plants like rhoderdendrons because they don't have a gall bladder. When a doctor removes a humans gall bladder, are they too able to eat poison without feeling ill?
text: Okay, imagine your tummy has a little helper called a gallbladder, and its main job is to help you break down yummy fatty foods, like the butter on your toast! Deer have super different tummies and bodies than we do. Their bodies are built in a special way that lets them eat certain plants that would make *us* feel very, very sick, even plants that have a kind of yucky "poison" in them. It's not really because they don't have that specific gallbladder helper, but because their whole body is just made to handle those plants in a way our bodies just can't. So, if a doctor takes out your gallbladder to help your tummy work better with food, it's like taking off your training wheels – it

title: What stops us from getting cell phone interference?
text: Imagine you and all your friends are playing in a big room, and everyone wants to talk on their pretend phone at the same time. If everyone just yelled, it would be super noisy, and you couldn't hear your mommy, right? Well, real cell phones are super clever! They use invisible "talky waves" to send your voice. To stop everyone's talky waves from getting all mixed up, each phone gets its own secret "talking channel," kind of like how different TV shows are on different channels, or how you and your friend might use different colored walkie-talkies. So, your phone only listens for its special channel, and your friend's phone only listens for *its* special channel. This way, all the invisible talky waves fly around, but your phone is super good at only picking up the ones meant for *you*, so you can hear your mommy clearly without hearing anyone else's conversation!

title: What determines your blood type and what's the difference between positive and negative?
text: Imagine your blood cells are like tiny little cars driving around inside you, and each car has special stickers on it! What kind of stickers your cars have comes from your mommy and daddy, just like how you get your eye color or hair color from them. Some cars have an "A" sticker, some have a "B" sticker, some have both, and some have no "A" or "B" stickers at all, which we call "O". Now, for the positive (+) and negative (-) part, it's like another super special sticker! If your cars have an extra little sticker that looks like a tiny plus sign, then your blood is "positive". But if your cars *don't* have that extra little plus sign sticker, then your blood is "negative". So, it's just about having or not having that one extra special sticker on your tiny blood cars!

title: When you have a good stare going on, what is actually happening and why does it feel so good to keep it going?
text: When you have a good stare going on, it's like your eyes get super sticky and glue themselves to something really, really interesting! Your brain is like a little detective, saying, 'Wow, what is that? Tell me everything!' It feels so good to keep staring because your brain loves to learn new things and see all the cool details, like when you're looking at a pretty butterfly or a big, spinning toy. It's like your brain is getting a happy treat because it's so curious and excited!

title: Why is the feeling of impending doom a real symptom and how does someone know they're dying?
text: Imagine your body has a special alarm system, like the smoke detector in your house! Sometimes, when something big and not-so-good is happening inside your body, even if you can't see it, that alarm can go off in your head or tummy, making you feel a big 'uh-oh' or a really bad feeling, like something important is about to happen. It's your body's way of trying to tell the grown-ups, 'Hey! Something important is happening here!' This is a real signal, just like a fire alarm is real even if you don't see the fire right away. Now, about knowing when someone is dying – that's when their body is getting super, super tired, like a toy car whose batteries are completely flat after playing all day. When people get very, very old or very, very sick, their body has worked so hard for so long, and sometimes it just can't keep going anymore. Doctors and grown-ups sometimes know because they can see that the body

title: As I lie here at 3am I wonder- why do people have trouble falling asleep at a reasonable time even when they wake up early and are tired during the day?
