title: Why do we need sea ice?
text: Sea ice is super important, like a superhero! First, it's a big, floating home and playground for special animals like polar bears and seals. They live on it, hunt for food from it, and even have their babies there! Second, it's like a giant, shiny mirror for the sun. When the sun shines on the white ice, it bounces the hot sun rays back into space, helping to keep our whole Earth from getting too, too warm, just like an ice cube keeps your juice cold. And sometimes, it acts like a big, strong wall for the land, stopping big, splashy waves from crashing too hard into the shore, which helps keep the beaches safe.

title: Does poetry in other languages rhyme the same way poems in English rhyme?
text: Yes, they do, but it sounds different! Imagine when you rhyme 'cat' and 'hat' in English, you're making the ends of the words sound like they're singing the

title: Why is it easier to take hot showers rather than cold ones?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cozy house! Inside your house, there's a special little heater that keeps you warm and happy, just the right temperature. When you take a hot shower, it's like someone is giving your house a warm hug, helping your heater do its job without much effort. That feels super comfy and easy! But when you take a cold shower, it's like someone suddenly opens all the windows and lets the chilly wind blow in! Your little heater inside has to work super, super hard and fast to make your house warm and happy again, and that feels like a big surprise and a lot of work for your body. So, hot showers are easier because they help your body stay warm and relaxed, instead of making it work hard to warm up from the cold.

title: Why do many TV advertisements seem to have nothing to do with their products?
text: Imagine you're watching a show and suddenly an ad comes on! Sometimes it shows a yummy snack or a cool toy right away. But sometimes, it shows a funny animal doing silly tricks, or people laughing and having a great time, and then *at the very end* it shows a little picture of a car or a new kind of soap. They do this because they want to make you feel happy or excited when you watch their ad! When you feel good, your brain remembers that good feeling, and it connects it to the thing they're trying to sell, even if the funny animal has nothing to do with soap. They just want you to remember *their* thing in a fun way, because boring ads are easy to forget, but happy feelings stick around!

title: why do surface antibacterials, like soap, not effect human skin cells?
text: Imagine tiny, tiny little bad guys called germs are all over your hands. They live in houses that are like super thin, easy-to-pop balloons. Soap is like a special magic potion that *only* knows how to pop those germ-balloon houses! Your skin cells, which are what make up your hands, live in houses that are like big, strong brick castles. They're built totally differently and are much tougher. So, when the soap magic potion comes along, it only knows how to pop the weak germ-balloon houses, but it just bounces right off your big, strong brick castle skin cells, leaving them perfectly safe and sound!

title: Why has no law been created to enforce News/media outlets to fact-check their news before release?
text: Imagine grown-ups making rules for everything you say. If you told a story, they'd have to check if every single part was true before you could even say it! That would be super slow and hard, right?

title: What is the House Ethics Committee and why is it (or not) significant that it is being done away with?
text: Imagine a very big house where lots of grown-ups work together to help our country, kind of like a big team. Sometimes, even grown-ups might forget the rules, or maybe not be super nice, or do something that's not quite right. The "House Ethics Committee" is like a special group of grown-ups, almost like a referee or a teacher, whose job is to watch over everyone in that big house. They make sure everyone plays fair, follows the rules, and is honest. If someone doesn't follow the rules, this group might give them a time-out or tell them they need to do better. Now, if we get rid of this referee group, it could be a big deal because then who would make sure

title: Why are we only able to accept blood transfusions of the same blood type?
text: Imagine your blood is like a big playground, and all the kids on your playground have a special "hat" on their head. Some kids have "A" hats, some have "B" hats, some have both, and some have no hats at all! Your body has special "security guards" that know exactly which hats belong in *your* playground. If a kid with a *different* kind of hat tries to come in, your security guards will say, "Hey! You don't belong here!" and they'll start making a big fuss, trying to get that kid out. This big fuss makes everyone sick and can be very dangerous. So, when doctors give you new blood, it's like bringing new kids to your playground. They have to be super careful to make sure the new kids have the *exact same hats* as yours, so your security guards will wave them in, saying, "Welcome! You belong here!" And then everyone can play nicely together, making you feel much better.

title: Why is forming chords on guitar different from other instruments, and how does it work?
text: Imagine a chord is like a happy group of friends all singing a song together at the same time! On a guitar, it's super special because your fingers are like little magic workers. You press down on the guitar's strings (which are like tiny ropes) in different spots called "frets" (they look like little metal lines). Each finger makes one rope sound a certain way, like giving each friend a different part to sing. So, you put many fingers down at the same time, each on a different rope and spot, and then you strum all the ropes together. It's like your fingers are building the whole song, note by note, before you play them all at once! On other instruments, like a piano, it's more like each friend already has their own button, and you just push many buttons at once to make them all sing. So, the guitar is different because your fingers have to *make* all the different sounds first by pressing the ropes, before you play them all together as one big happy chord

title: The main difference of a fruit and vegetable is that fruits have seeds. So, where the heck do vegetable seeds, used in gardeningand such, from?
text: You are so smart to notice that fruits have seeds inside them! That's how plants make more of themselves. Now, here's a little secret: to a plant, a 'fruit' is anything that holds seeds. So, things like tomatoes, peppers, and cucumbers, which we often call vegetables, are actually fruits to the plant because they have seeds inside! For other things we call vegetables, like carrots or lettuce

title: How did Crocodiles survive the extinction of dinosaurs?
text: Imagine a super, super long time ago, there was a very big boom and lots of dust filled the sky, making it cold and dark everywhere. This made it super hard for the giant dinosaurs to find food and stay warm, so sadly, they all went away. But crocodiles were super smart and tough! They loved to live in the water, which was a bit safer from all the dust and cold. They also weren't picky eaters like some dinosaurs; they could eat fish, bugs, or even things that had already died, so they always found something yummy. Plus, they could go a really, really long time without eating, like having a super long nap and not needing snacks! Because they were good at hiding, eating anything, and not needing much, they kept on living and are still here today!

title: Why do hot drinks soothe a sore throat? If my throat is inflamed, shouldn't cold drinks help?
text: Imagine your throat is feeling a bit grumpy and tight, like when you squeeze your hands really hard. When you drink something warm, it's like giving your throat a warm, cozy hug! That warm hug helps your throat muscles relax and feel softer, so it doesn't hurt as much when you swallow. It also helps make the yucky, sticky stuff that's making your throat scratchy a little thinner, like warm water helps melt honey, so it's easier for your body to get rid of it. Cold drinks can feel nice for a tiny second because they make things a bit numb, like when you get a little bump and put ice on it. But for your throat, sometimes cold can make those grumpy muscles tighten up even more, and the sticky stuff gets thicker, which isn't as comfy in the long run for your sore throat.

title: Why is it that when we think about our breathing we can forget how to automatically breath normally? Or when to blink? Has anyone ever died because they 'forgot' to breath?
text: Okay, imagine your body has a super-duper smart helper inside that does lots of important jobs all by itself, like making your heart beat or making you breathe and blink. It does these things without you even thinking about them, even when you're sleeping! But sometimes, when you *think* really hard about one of those jobs, like breathing, your brain tries to be the helper instead of letting your body's automatic helper do it. It feels a little funny or weird because your brain is trying to control something that usually just happens on its own, like when you try to walk super carefully instead of just walking normally. You can't actually forget how to breathe or blink though, silly! Your body's special helper is way too good at its job and will always take over again, especially if you get busy doing something else or fall asleep. So no, no one has ever died because they "forgot" to breathe; your body is much too smart to let that happen!

title: What causes mental fatigue while studying?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little runner! When you study, your brain is running a super long race, trying to learn all the new things. It has to think really hard, remember lots of stuff, and solve puzzles. Just like your legs get tired after running for a long time and need to sit down and rest, your brain gets tired too! It uses up all its energy trying to keep up with all the learning. When your brain is tired, it's called mental fatigue. It means it needs a little break, maybe a snack, or to play for a bit, so it can get its energy back and be ready to learn more later!

title: Why can a honey badger get bit by a poisonous snake, and be okay?
text: Okay, imagine a honey badger is super, super tough, like a superhero! When a snake gives it a little bite with its special sleepy juice (that's what snake venom is like), the honey badger's body is just built differently. It's like its blood has tiny, strong fighters that don't let the sleepy juice make it too sick. The honey badger might feel a little bit woozy or sleepy for a little while, like when you're super tired and need a nap. But then, after a short rest, it wakes up and is totally fine, ready to go play again! Its body is just really good at shaking off that sleepy juice.

title: Would a mummy left undisturbed eventually turn into a human fossil?
text: No, a mummy wouldn't turn into a fossil! Imagine a mummy is like a super old, dried-up apple that's wrapped up tight. It's already dry and kept safe. To become a fossil, something needs to be buried super, super deep under the ground, under lots of wet mud and dirt, for millions and millions of years! Then, special water and minerals slowly sneak in and turn the bones into a hard, stony copy, like turning a bone into a rock picture. Mummies are usually kept dry and safe, and they aren't buried in that special squishy, deep way that lets the rock-magic happen over super long times. So, they stay dried-up mummies instead of becoming a fossil.

title: With all the fancy digital and video audio effects on media devices these days, why is it so hard to get a "Make the action scenes the same volume as the dialogue scenes" button?
text: Imagine when you tell a story, sometimes you whisper a secret, and sometimes you shout "ROAR!" like a big dinosaur! You do that to make your story fun and exciting, right?

title: If heroin was available over the counter 100 years ago, why didn't most people become addicts?
text: Imagine you have a special juice that helps your cough, and a long, long time ago, some grown-ups put a tiny, tiny bit of a secret ingredient in it called heroin, but people didn't even know it was heroin! It wasn't like the scary stuff we hear about today; it was just a little bit mixed into other medicines for when you had a tummy ache or a bad cough. People only took a tiny sip when they felt yucky, not to have fun or feel super silly, and they didn't know it was something that could make them feel stuck to it like super glue if they took too much. So, most people just took their medicine, felt better, and then stopped, just like you stop drinking your juice when your cough is all gone!

title: how do stores like Poundland manage to maintain a consistent price even through recession or currency changing in value?
text: Imagine Poundland is like a super clever grown-up who has a special rule: everything in their toy box *must* cost £1! So, they have grown-up friends all over the world who help them find super duper cheap toys, yummy sweets, and other fun things. They buy *so many* of them at once, like a giant mountain of toys, and when you buy a super, super lot, it's much cheaper for them. If one toy or sweet suddenly gets too expensive for their special £1 rule, they don't sell it anymore. Instead, they find a different, just as fun toy or yummy sweet that they *can* sell for £1. They are like clever treasure hunters always looking for the best, cheapest treasures, so no matter if grown-up money feels a bit funny sometimes, they always make sure to have things that fit their special £1 rule!

title: what makes dreaming so much more vivid and memorable than just thinking?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a big box of amazing toys! When you're just *thinking*, it's like you're awake and picking out one toy, maybe a LEGO brick, and just looking at it or moving it around a little bit. You're in charge, and it's usually pretty quiet and simple. But when you're *dreaming*, it's like your brain turns all the lights off and suddenly builds a giant, super-duper amazing play

text: Imagine your eyes are like special glasses that let you see three main colors: red, green, and blue. Your brain mixes these three to see all the other colors you know, like yellow or purple

title: We're told not to trust major news outlets because they're manipulated by money, as with Facebook news and even Reddit news, so where do people get "real" news?
text: Imagine news is like stories about what's happening in the world, like what new toys are out or what games people are playing. Sometimes, the really big places that tell these stories, like big TV shows or big websites, get money from grown-ups who want to make sure *their* favorite toy or game gets talked about a lot, or only in a nice way. It's like if a toy company paid the toy store to only show their toys! So, to find out what's *really* happening, it's best not to just listen to one person or one big place. Instead, you can look at lots of different places that tell stories – maybe a few different TV shows, or different websites, or even ask different grown-ups what they heard. It's like looking at lots of different toy stores to see all the different toys, and then you can think about what *you* believe is the truest story, like picking your favorite toy after seeing them all!

title: What has made our internet faster over the last 20 years?
text: Imagine the internet is like sending a big toy from your house to your friend's house far away. A long time ago, about 20 years ago, we only had tiny, bumpy dirt roads, and the truck we used to send the toy was really slow, like a snail! It could only carry one small toy at a time. But over the last 20 years, we've built super-duper wide highways with lots and lots of lanes, and now we use giant, super-fast rocket trucks! These rocket trucks can carry hundreds of toys all at once, zoom incredibly fast, and they even know the quickest shortcuts to get where they're going. Plus, the people packing the toys got super smart and can fit much more into each box, and the big toy stores (which are like the internet's giant brains) got much closer to everyone. So, everything just moves much, much faster now!

title: if coughing is your throat's reaction to try to get rid of whatever is in there. How come we cough for days on end after getting sick with nothing coming out and then one random cough after a while the phlegm finally comes out?
text: Imagine your throat is a super clean slide. When a little crumb gets on it, your cough is like a quick push to get it right off! But when you're sick, your throat gets all gooey and sticky, like someone spilled thick, sticky mud all over your slide. Your coughs are still trying to push that mud off, but it's really stuck! It's too thick and heavy to move easily, even with lots of pushes. So, your body works hard to slowly add a little bit of water to that sticky mud, making it less sticky and more runny over time. Each little cough helps wiggle it a tiny bit, even if nothing comes out. Then, after many, many coughs have helped loosen it and your body has made it runny enough, suddenly one big cough is strong enough to finally push all that watery mud right off the slide!

title: How come things like turn signals and windshield wipers initially seem like they'll align with a beat of a song but then steadily fall off pace? Is there a certain time signature that can consistently match these items?
text: Imagine your turn signal is like a little drummer who always drums at the same speed, *tap-tap-tap*. And your windshield wipers are like another drummer who also drums at their

title: Why after not having pop for a few days does my body have such a visceral reaction?
text: Imagine your body is like a happy little car that loves to zoom! When you drink pop every day, it's like giving your car a super yummy, super speedy special fuel, full of sugar! Your car gets really used to having that special fuel all the time, and it makes it feel super energetic and happy. But then, if you stop giving it that special pop fuel for a few days, your car gets a bit confused and grumpy! It's like your car is saying, "Hey! Where's my yummy fuel? I'm feeling a bit slow and not so happy now!" This makes you feel a little tired, or maybe your head hurts, or you just feel a bit grumpy, because your body is missing its usual happy sugar boost. It's just your body telling you it's used to something, and it's taking a little bit of time to learn to be happy without it!

title: Why is absolute zero only 0 kelvin but absolute hot around ~1,4*10^32 kelvin?
text: Imagine all the tiny little bits that make up everything around us, even you! They are always jigging and wiggling. When it's super cold, they wiggle less, and

title: What causes the feeling of impending doom in a medical context, and why is it regarded as a reliable indicator of a patient's condition?
text: Imagine your body is like a super smart house, and you're inside! Sometimes, when something *really* big and bad is happening inside your house, like a very serious fire or a big wall is about to fall down, your house tries to tell you. It doesn't use words, but it sends a super

title: What does the Office of Congressional Ethics do?
text: Imagine you and your friends are playing a very important game, and there are special rules to make sure everyone plays fair and is nice to each other, right? Well, the grown-ups who work in Congress are like a big team playing a very important game for our whole country. The Office of Congressional Ethics (OCE) is like a special helper team, or a friendly referee, whose job it is to watch and make sure those grown-ups are always playing fair, being honest, and following all the good rules. If someone maybe isn't sharing their toys or is being a bit naughty, the OCE looks into it to see what happened and then tells the other grown-ups so they can figure out what to do. They help make sure everyone behaves nicely!

title: If the average human heart beats 72 beats a minute. How can athletes have a resting heart rate of 40?
text: Your heart is like a little pump inside you that pushes blood all around your body, like water through pipes! For most grown-ups, that pump needs to give about 72 squeezes every minute to get all the blood where it needs to go. But athletes, people who run and play sports a lot, have super-duper strong hearts! Imagine if you had really strong arms, you wouldn't need to try as hard to lift something, right? Well, an athlete's heart is so strong that with each squeeze, it can push out way more blood than a regular heart. Because it's so good at its job and pushes out so much blood with one big squeeze, it doesn't need to squeeze as many times in a minute. So, it can just chill out and beat slower, maybe only 40 times, because each beat is super powerful!

title: What causes us to rub our face when we are tired?
text: When you're super sleepy, like when you've played all day and your eyes feel heavy and a bit fuzzy, like they have a sleepy blanket on them, your body tries to help itself feel a little better! Rubbing your face is like gently tickling your skin and your eyes. It tells them, 'Hey! Wake up a tiny bit!' It makes the sleepy blanket feel a little bit lighter for a moment, and it feels nice and comfy, like a little hug for your face. It helps you open your eyes a tiny bit wider to see things better, even if you still really want to nap!

title: Why is there no visible/audible lightning during winter snowstorms?
text: Imagine electricity is like a special kind of tickle that makes lights flash! To make a big tickle like lightning, you need very, very special, super-tall clouds, like giant towers reaching way up high. These clouds get super busy inside, with lots of tiny ice pieces and water droplets zooming around and bumping into each other really, really fast. All that bumping makes the tickle, and when there's too much tickle, *zap!* a big lightning flash happens, and then *boom!* goes the thunder. In winter, when it snows, the clouds are usually flatter and not as tall. It's cold everywhere, so the air doesn't get super excited and zoom way up high to build those giant, busy towers. Because the clouds aren't tall enough or busy enough inside, they don't make enough of that special tickle to cause a big lightning flash. So, no lightning, no boom-boom thunder!

title: Why does massaging a sore muscle bring pain relief, but touching an acute injury hurts?
text: Okay, imagine your muscles are like little stretchy rubber bands that help you run and jump! When you play super hard, those rubber bands get a little tired and have tiny, tiny sleepy

title: Why can't a car give more details with a dashboard warning light?
text: Hey little friend! Imagine your car is like a big toy, and those lights are like little pictures that pop up. When a light comes on, it's like the car quickly saying "Uh oh, something needs attention!" It shows you a picture, like a little engine or a battery, because pictures are super fast to see with your eyes, even when you're looking at the road. If the car tried to write a whole story with lots of words, it would be hard for the grown-up driving to read it quickly and safely while driving! So, the light just gives a quick "heads up!" and then a grown-up knows to ask a car doctor (a mechanic) to look closer and find out the exact owie.

title: How can car insurance providers charge more simply for being male?
text: Imagine car insurance is like a big piggy bank that everyone puts money into. If your car gets a little boo-boo, like a scratch or a bump, the money from the piggy bank helps fix it. Now, the grown-ups who look after the piggy bank notice something: sometimes, especially when they are young, grown-up boys tend to have their cars get boo-boos a little more often than grown-up girls. Because their cars might need fixing more times, the piggy bank needs them to put in a tiny bit more money. It's not because they are naughty, it's just so there's enough money in the piggy bank to fix all the boo-boos that happen.

title: Why are zoos a thing?
text: Imagine you really, really want to see a big, striped tiger or a tall, spotty giraffe, but they live super far away in places like jungles or big open fields you can't visit! Zoos are like special homes that people made so some of these amazing animals can live closer to us. This way, we can come and visit them, learn all about what they eat, how they play, and where they come from, which is like a big animal school for us! Sometimes, animals in the wild get hurt or sick, or their homes disappear, so zoos also help take care of them, like animal doctors, and make sure special kinds of animals don't disappear forever. So zoos are a place where we can see cool animals, learn lots, and help keep them safe and healthy!

title: Why exactly does rubbing your tongue on another person's tongue (a.k.a. making out or French kiss) feel so good?
text: Imagine your tongue has super-duper special tiny feelers all over it, even more than your fingertips! When grown-ups really, really like someone a whole lot, like a best friend you want to be super close to, sometimes they touch tongues. And when those special feelers on your tongue touch someone else's, your brain gets super excited and makes happy juice, like a little party inside your head! That happy juice makes your whole body feel warm and fuzzy and really, really good, because it's a special way to show how much you like someone and feel close to them.

title: How did people decipher brand new languages and alphabets before technology?
text: Imagine you found a really old secret message written in squiggly lines you'd never seen before, like alien writing! Before computers, people had to be super detectives. First, they'd look for pictures next to the squiggles. If there was a picture of a sun next to a squiggle, they might guess that squiggle meant 'sun'! Then, they'd look for patterns, like seeing the same squiggle show up many times, guessing it might be a common word like 'the' or 'and'. The most helpful thing ever was when they found the *same story*

title: How can Newtonian physics be technically "wrong" , but still mathematically explain many natural processes?
text: Imagine you have a really good toy car that rolls on the floor. Newtonian physics is like a super smart rulebook that tells you *exactly* how your toy car will roll, how fast it goes when you push it, and where it stops. It works perfectly for your toy car, and for your bike, and for throwing a ball! It helps us build bridges and send rockets to the moon – it's really, really good for all the big things we see every day. But then, imagine there are also super-duper tiny things, like invisible dust, or things that go faster than a race car, like a beam of light! For *those* special things, our toy car rulebook isn't quite right. It's not that it's *broken* for your toy car, it's just that those tiny, super-fast things need a *different*, even more grown-up rulebook to understand them perfectly. So, for almost everything we do, the

title: Why is every major incident/disaster/accident a combination of numerous (maybe dozens) of tiny little insignificant things going wrong, that all link together in a perfect chain to make the big thing happen?
text: Imagine you're trying to build a super tall tower with your toy blocks! Most of the time, your tower stays up because all the blocks are strong and in their right place. But sometimes, one tiny block might be a little wobbly. And another tiny block might be a little bit crooked. And then maybe a third tiny block isn't pushed in all the way. By themselves, none of these little things are a big deal, right? But then, if a little breeze comes, or you accidentally bump the table just a tiny bit, that wobbly block might fall, which then bumps the crooked block, which then pushes the not-pushed-in block, and suddenly *WHOOSH!* the whole big tower comes crashing down! It wasn't just *one* thing that made it fall, it was all those tiny little wobbly, crooked, and loose blocks lining up perfectly to make a big mess. That's why big accidents happen – lots of little tiny things that weren't quite right all happened at the same time, like a perfect line of dominoes falling over!

title: How did we determine the order of operations in mathematics?
text: Imagine you and your friend are both building with LEGOs, and I tell you to put a red block *and then* a blue block. If you put the blue one first, and your friend puts the red one first, your towers will look different! Math is kind of like that. A long, long time ago, when people started doing bigger and bigger math problems, they realized that if everyone did the adding and subtracting and multiplying in their own way, they would all get different answers to the same problem. That would be super confusing! So, smart grown-ups from all over the world decided, "Let's make up some special rules, like rules for a game, so everyone does math the same way." They picked an order that made the most sense and worked best for most problems, so now, when we all follow those rules, we always get the exact same answer, like everyone building the same LEGO tower!

title: How does a high-risk investor predict if a certain company is going to generate profits? Does one have to be an expert in the field the company works in or understand the products it offers?
text: Imagine you have some shiny coins, and you want to make more coins! A "high-risk investor" is like a grown-up who is super brave with their coins. They give

title: How are there people who cant dream?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little movie studio that makes up fun stories while you're sleeping, and those are dreams! Most of the time, everyone's brain makes these stories. But sometimes, for some people, their brain's movie studio is just super quiet. Maybe it doesn't make any stories at all that night, or maybe it makes a story but it's so super fast and quiet that when you wake up, you don't even remember seeing it, kind of like forgetting what you had for a snack yesterday. Sometimes, a tiny part of the brain that helps remember the stories is just too sleepy to write them down in your memory. It's totally normal and not a big deal if your brain doesn't play movies every night!

title: Why does YouTube, a website which such high account security, have so many spam bots while Reddit, a website that seems to have low account security, has almost none?
text: Imagine YouTube is like a really, really big park where everyone is watching a super popular show! Lots and lots of people are there, so it's easy for a naughty robot (that'

title: How are all the Fate works by TYPE-MOON interconnected?
text: Imagine a super big, magical storybook filled with lots and lots of adventures! In the middle of this book is a special game about a magical cup that can grant any wish. Lots of grown-ups want this cup, and they fight over it with their special hero friends. That's the main game, and sometimes, when you play that game, you can make different choices, right? Like choosing to play with one friend or another, or going left instead of right. Each time someone makes a different choice in the game, it makes a brand new adventure in the storybook! So, all the Fate stories are like those different adventures. They often have the same hero friends, or the same magical cup, but because different choices were made, the stories are all a little bit different, exciting, and special in their own way. They're all part of the same super big, magical world, even if they don't always happen exactly the same way.

title: Can you get rid of depression forever?
text: Imagine sometimes your brain feels like it has a big, grey cloud over it, making you feel super sad and tired, like a rainy day inside your head. That's a bit like depression. Can we make that cloud go away forever and ever? Well, sometimes the cloud floats away for a very, very long time, and the sun shines super bright again, and you feel happy and like yourself! But just like sometimes you get a little cold, and then you get better, but maybe later you get another cold, sometimes that grey cloud might try to come back a little bit. The good news is, grown-ups know lots of ways to help chase those clouds away faster if they try to come back, like talking about it or doing special things. So while it might not be gone forever and ever like a magic trick, we learn how to make it go away and keep the sun shining most of the time!

title: What is the difference between methamphetamine and amphetamine salts (Adderall)? What makes amphetamine salts so much safer/less addictive?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little engine that helps you think and play. **Methamphetamine** is like a super-duper, extra-strong fuel that makes your engine go ZOOM! Super

title: If there were a mirror in deep space (light years away), would we see ourselves in the past if we looked into it?
text: Okay, imagine a mirror is like a special, super shiny wall that bounces light back, right? And when you look in a mirror here, the light from your face zips to the mirror and then zips right back to your eyes so fast you see yourself right now. But light, even though it's super speedy, still takes time to travel, like how it takes time for you to run across a big field. Now, if that mirror was super, duper, extra-duper far away in space, like farther than going to the moon and back a million times, your light would have to travel all the way from you, zoom to the mirror, and then zoom all the way back to your eyes. Because it takes so much time for the light to go on that super long trip, by the time it finally gets back to you, it would be light from a very, very, very long time ago when it first left you! So yes, you would see yourself from the past, like looking at an old picture of yourself, but it would be you right there in the mirror from long, long ago!

title: People Say Keeping the Lights on Drives up the Electric Bill, but Isn't It Simply Using the Electricity That Is Already on Standby?
text: Imagine electricity is like tiny invisible cars that live inside the wires in your house, waiting to go! They're there, but they're not driving anywhere until you tell them to. When you flip a light switch, it's like saying "GO!" to those cars, and they start zooming around, making the light bulb bright. The electric company, who sends all those tiny cars to your house, has a special counter that watches how many cars zoom by and get used up. The more lights you turn on, and the longer you leave them on, the more cars zoom by, and the more money your grown-ups have to pay the electric company for all the cars you used! So, even though the cars are always waiting, using them is what costs money.

title: What gas is inside blisters and how does it get there?
text: Imagine your skin is like a super strong shield! But sometimes, if you rub it too much or it gets too hot, your shield gets a little boo-boo. To make it feel better and keep it safe, your body quickly builds a tiny, clear bubble right on top of the boo-boo. This bubble isn't really full of a *special gas*, it's mostly full of a super clear, special kind of water from inside your body, like the clear part of your blood. Your body sends this special water to the bubble to make a soft, squishy pillow that protects the hurt skin underneath, like a little cushion to help it heal.

title: What's a single-nucleotide polymorphism?
text: Imagine your body has a super-duper long instruction book inside it, like a giant storybook! This book tells your body how to grow and what to do. The book is made of tiny, tiny letters. A single-nucleotide polymorphism is like when almost everyone'

text: Imagine a baseball player who gets a super big paycheck from his team! Sometimes, instead of giving him all his money right now, the team says, "We'll give you *some*

title: Why does the United States sell things like Milk and Water in gallons, but Soda in liters?
text: Okay, imagine you have two different kinds of measuring cups for your juice! One is called a "gallon" cup, and that's what we've always used for milk and water in America, for a super, super long time – it's like a family tradition! But then, when yummy fizzy drinks like soda started becoming popular, many of the companies that made them also sold their drinks to other countries all around the world. And almost all other countries use a different kind of measuring cup called a "liter" cup. So, to make it easier for everyone everywhere to know how much soda they're getting, the soda companies just decided to use the liter cup for their drinks, even in America! So, it's just because some things have been measured one way for a long, long time, and other things were made by companies that wanted to use the same measurement everywhere.

title: if cheese and wine take so long to age, how do manufacturers know how much to make ahead of time and the demand?
text: Imagine your mommy wants to make a really special cake for your birthday next year, but she has to start baking it *today* because it takes a whole year to get yummy! How

title: How does our body absorb creams? Which parts of our skin do they go to?
text: Imagine your skin is like a special, super thin blanket that covers your whole body! This blanket has super tiny, tiny holes, even smaller than a pinprick, so small you can't even see them. When you put yummy cream on your skin, it's like putting tiny, happy little helpers on that blanket. These tiny helpers are so small they can sneak right through those super tiny holes in your skin-blanket! They don't go all the way inside your tummy or your bones. Most of the cream just stays in the very top part of your skin-blanket, making it feel super soft and happy, like when you put lotion on. Some special creams can go a little bit deeper, like going down to the next floor in a building, to help even more, but they usually

title: How much power does the computer need to fully emulate human's brain?
text: Imagine your brain is like the most amazing, biggest, and fastest LEGO castle ever built, with a zillion tiny moving parts, and each part talks to all the other parts super-fast. To make a computer copy of that brain, so it thinks and feels just like you, would need a computer that is unbelievably powerful. It's like trying to make a tiny toy car do all the work of a giant rocket ship going to the moon! We don't have computers that strong yet. The computer would need so much electricity, maybe like a whole city needs to light up all its houses and buildings, just to make it work. It's a super-duper hard puzzle that grown-ups are still trying to figure out!

title: How your body reject all food and water when hungover knowing it's hungry and dehydrated?
text: Imagine your body is like a little house, and when you drink too much grown-up juice, it's like a big, messy party happened inside! Your tummy, which is like the kitchen, gets very upset and sensitive. It's trying really hard to clean up all the mess and get rid of the yucky stuff from the party. Even though your brain (the boss of the house) knows you're super hungry and thirsty because the grown-up juice made you lose a lot of water, your tummy is just too busy and sensitive trying to clean up. So, when you try to put more food or water in, your upset tummy says "No thank you!" and pushes it right back out because it's still feeling yucky and needs to finish cleaning first.

title: when hyperinflation occurs, are people with fixed interest loans or fixed interest mortgages able to pay off their debt without any issues?
text: Imagine your money is like a special toy coin. When hyperinflation happens, it's like suddenly everyone has a million toy coins, and new ones are made super fast! So, your

title: What is the difference between (for example) URL_0 as opposed to URL_1 ?
text: Imagine you have two very similar toys, like two red toy cars. They both look like "car" toys, right? But one car has a tiny sticker on it that says "0" and the other car has a tiny sticker that says "1". They're both cars, but the little numbers just help us know *which* specific car we're talking about! Maybe the "0" car is the one you played with first, or the one that stays in the toy box, and the "1" car is the brand new one, or the one you can take outside. The numbers just help us tell apart things that are mostly the same but have a small difference, like their version or where they go.

title: How where the Germans able to defeat France in such a short amount of time during WW2?
text: Imagine you and your friend are going to play a game. Your friend thinks you're going to play hide-and-seek, and they build a super big, strong fort on one side of the yard, thinking you'll try to get into it. But you decide to play a *different* game, a super-fast race! You have lots of speedy toy cars (tanks) and flying toy airplanes, and instead of trying to get into their fort, you zoom *around* it really, really fast, through the bushes where they weren't looking. Before your friend even realizes you're playing a race and not hide-and-seek, you've already won! That's kind of what happened. Germany had new, super-fast ways of fighting with their tanks and planes all working together, and they went around where France thought they would attack. France was ready for a slower game, like the last big war, and couldn't catch up to the super-fast new game Germany was playing.

title: Why did early pistol and musket designs have such unergonomic looking grips?
text: Imagine you're trying to build a strong toy with big blocks of wood, not soft squishy plastic. A long, long time ago, when grown-ups made guns, they mostly cared that

title: Why are conifers usually triangular while deciduous trees are usually 'circular' in profile?
text: Imagine a Christmas tree – it's pointy like a party hat, right? That's because it lives in places where lots of snow falls, and the pointy shape helps the snow slide right off so the branches don't break. Plus, these trees keep their green needles all year round, so the pointy shape helps them catch sunlight from all sides, even when the sun is low in winter, like a little sun-catcher. Now, think about the big trees in the park that lose their leaves in fall – they grow big and round like a giant fluffy cloud when they have all their leaves! They do this because when the sun is super bright in summer, they want to spread out their leaves like a giant umbrella to catch as much yummy sunshine as possible to make their food. In winter, they don't have any leaves, so they don't need to worry about snow breaking their branches, and they don't need to catch sun then either.

title: Why is it that we think of mirrors as being silver colored, even though they reflect the exact colors of objects around them?
text: Okay, imagine a mirror is like a super-duper special helper! Its job is to show you *everything* that's in front of it, perfectly, like a magic picture frame that copies things. It doesn't want to add its *own* color to the picture, because then it wouldn't be a good helper, right? We think it's silver because the special shiny stuff that's hidden *behind* the clear glass, which makes it so good at bouncing back all the colors perfectly, *is* silver-colored metal. If you look at the *very edge* of a mirror, or sometimes the back part, you can see that silvery grey color! But when it's doing its job, it's just showing you the colors of your cool toys and your happy face, not adding its own.

title: Before modern counterfeit measures how could people tell if their currency was counterfeit?
text: Imagine you have your favorite coloring book, and then someone tries to draw the same picture, but they don't have all the right crayons or they're not very good at drawing. That's kind of how people told if money was fake! They would look very, very closely at the pictures and numbers on the money. If the pictures looked blurry, or the lines were wiggly instead of straight, or the colors looked a little bit off, they'd think, "Hmm, this doesn't look quite right!" They would also *feel* the money. Real money feels special, usually a bit crispier or thicker, like a fancy piece of paper. Fake money often felt like regular, plain paper you draw on, which is thin and floppy, and sometimes the ink would even rub off if you touched it too much! So, by looking carefully and feeling it, people could often tell if their money was real or just a pretend one.

title: Why do some surgeries result in equipment being left behind in patients (e.g. scissors)?
text: Imagine you're playing with lots and lots of toys, maybe building a big castle or fixing a broken car, and you have tons of little tools all around you. When it's time to clean up, you try super hard to put every single toy back in its box, right? But sometimes, because there are so many toys, and maybe you're really tired, or you have to clean up super fast because dinner is ready, a tiny toy might get left behind under the couch. It's kind of like that with doctors when they do a big surgery. They are working inside someone's body to fix a very important boo-boo, and they use lots and lots of special tools, like tiny scissors or clamps. They are super focused on making the person better, and sometimes, because it's a very busy place inside, and maybe they have to work super fast to keep the person safe, or there's a lot of important stuff happening all at once, just like your tiny toy, a tool can get hidden or missed when they are cleaning up and closing everything back up. They try super, super hard to count everything and make sure no tool gets left behind, but sometimes, very rarely, it's like that one tiny toy that gets missed.

title: Why is ice less dense than water even though most solids are more dense than their liquid forms?
text: Okay, imagine you have a bunch of tiny little LEGO bricks. When they are water, they are all wiggling and jiggling around, kind of close together but not in a perfect line. When most other things get super cold and turn solid, like chocolate sauce turning into a solid chocolate bar, all their little LEGO bricks squeeze super, super close together, making the solid chocolate bar much heavier for its size. But water is special! When water gets cold enough to turn into ice, its tiny LEGO bricks don't just squeeze closer. Instead, they decide to hold hands and make a special pattern, like building a little house with lots of space inside! This "house" actually takes up *more* room than when they were just wiggling around freely. Because they take up more space, it's like having the same number of LEGOs but they're more spread out, making the ice lighter for its size than the water, which is why it floats!

title: Why do all old movie trailers have narration in them?
text: Imagine you have a super cool new toy, but it's still in the box and you can't quite see all the fun things it does just by looking at the picture! So, a grown-up tells you, "This toy can fly! It makes funny noises! You'll love playing with it!" That's kind of why old movie trailers had someone talking over them! Back then, televisions weren't in every house, and there was no internet to look up movie information. So, the person talking (the narrator) was like that grown-up

title: Both the sun and moon appear flat, with no cues that one is further away than the other. What is the maximum distance that variations in depth can be perceived at, and why?

title: Both of my Parents are type O blood type. I am AB+ how is that possible?
text: Okay, imagine your blood type is like a special color you get from your parents, like building blocks. Your mom has only 'O' blocks, and your dad also has only 'O' blocks

title: How do people in war zones have access to Internet?
text: Imagine the internet is like a super long invisible string that connects all the computers in the world so they can talk to each other, like a giant game of telephone! Usually, these strings go under the ground or through big tall towers, kind of like how your mommy's phone talks. But when there's a war, sometimes those strings get broken or the towers fall down, which makes it super hard to play the game! But people are very clever! Instead of strings on the ground, they sometimes use special big dishes, like giant bowls, that point *up* to the sky.

title: Why do we have imperial/metric units, and so many different languages, while time has a universally accepted measurement?
text: Imagine trying to measure how tall your tower of blocks is. Some people might use their hand to count, saying 'It's five hands tall!' (that's kind of like imperial units

title: Why are nuclear bombs detonated in the air instead of on impact?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper bouncy ball that makes a giant *BOOM!* when it goes off. If you drop it right onto the ground, some of its big *BOOM* power gets stuck in the dirt, like when you jump into soft sand and it doesn't bounce as high. But if you make it *BOOM!* high up in the sky, all its pushing power, like a giant invisible hand, can spread out in a huge circle and push down on *lots* of houses and trees and everything over a much bigger area, like a giant invisible pancake-maker squishing everything flat! It also makes a super-hot fire that burns more things from above, so more stuff gets broken and squished from way up high, making a much bigger mess for more things.

title: Is silver a real color or just an optical property of certain materials?
text: You know how red is just red, and blue is just blue? Silver is a little special! It's not a color like those that just *is* one color. When you see something silver, like a shiny spoon or a mirror, it's super good at bouncing *all* the colors of light that hit it right back into your eyes! It's like it doesn't pick just one color to show you; it shows you all of them at once, really brightly and shimmery. That's why it looks so shiny and sometimes even shows little bits of what's around it. So, silver is more about *how* light bounces off something really well, making it look special and bright, rather than being a single crayon color all by itself.

title: How are the quantity of standard SI units determined?
text: Imagine you want to measure things, like how tall you are, or how long it takes to eat your cookie, or how heavy your teddy bear is. We need special "measuring sticks

title: Why do many word pairs sound "correct" in one order, but not when reversed? Is it just cultural, or is there a linguistic explanation?
text: Okay, imagine you have two favorite toys, like a little car and a big truck. You always put them away in the same order, maybe the car first, then the truck,

title: How are new organs still being discovered? Shouldn't they have all been found with modern technology/direct surgical 'exploration'?
text: Imagine your body is like a super big, super cool toy box, and doctors are like detectives trying to figure out every single toy and secret compartment inside. For a long, long time, we knew about the big, obvious toys like your heart and your brain. But sometimes, even though we look really hard with our eyes and even with special magnifying glasses (which are like our fancy doctor tools!), we might miss a tiny, super secret drawer, or a very thin piece of paper stuck to the bottom, or even realize that a group of little toys actually work together like a brand new, special team! So, it's not like we suddenly find a whole new arm or leg hiding! Instead, we get better and better magnifying glasses (called microscopes!) and special cameras (called scanners!) that let us peek inside in super tiny detail. Sometimes we see a tiny little tube or a sheet of something we thought was just part of another toy, but then we realize it has its *own* special job, like a tiny secret helper! Or we realize that a bunch of little parts work together so perfectly that they deserve their own special name, like a brand new team. So, even though we've explored a lot, our tools get smarter, and we learn new things about how our amazing bodies work, finding little hidden treasures all the time!

title: How can airport scanners see through leather but not through skin?
text: Imagine you have a super special flashlight that can shine a little bit through your blanket or your shirt. When you shine this special light at your leather jacket or your clothes, the light can easily go right through

title: Does my stomach acid pass into the rest of my digestive tract when food leaves my stomach?
text: Your tummy is like a special blender with super strong juice to break down your food. When your food is all mushy and ready to leave your tummy, your body is super smart! It knows that the next parts of your tummy don't like that super strong juice because it would give them an ouchie. So, right when the mushy food starts to leave, your body squirts in some special 'oopsie-doopsie' liquid that quickly makes the super strong juice much, much weaker. It's like adding water to super sour lemonade to make it just right! So, the really strong acid doesn't go all the way through your body; it gets changed first so it's gentle and doesn't cause any ouchies.

title: How do the military counts and confirms kills?
text: Imagine you're playing a game, and someone is "out!" How do you know? Well, sometimes you *see* it happen with your own eyes, right? Or maybe your friend saw it too, so you both agree. After the game, you might even look around to see if they're really gone. It's a bit like that for the military, but super, super serious. When they are in a very dangerous game with bad guys, and they make a bad guy stop fighting for good, they try their best to *see* it happen. They might use their own eyes, or special cameras on their vehicles or planes. Sometimes, other soldiers or pilots are watching too, so lots of people can say, "Yes, we saw it!" After the fight, they also look around carefully to make sure the bad guy really isn't fighting anymore. Then, they tell their boss, "This happened," and the boss writes it down so everyone knows what happened in the very important game.

title: Why does fuel not ignite in cars?
text: Okay, imagine your car needs a special drink to go, just like you need juice! That drink is called fuel. This fuel is super sleepy and safe inside its special tank, like it's taking a nap in a closed bottle. For fuel to make a big "whoosh" (that's fire!), it needs two friends: lots of air to breathe, and a super hot tickle (that's a spark!). Inside your car, the sleepy fuel doesn't get enough air to breathe and no one tickles it with a spark, so it just stays quiet and safe. Only when your car wants to go "vroom vroom," it lets out a tiny bit of fuel, mixes it with lots of air in a super small space, and then gives it a quick, hot tickle. BOOM! A tiny, controlled fire happens super fast, which is like a little push that makes parts of the engine move and turn the wheels, making your car go! It's only a tiny fire at the right time, not a big, messy one.

title: How is it that we are able to remember a songs lyrics even when we haven't heard the song in a while?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super big toy box, and inside it, you have lots of smaller special boxes for different things. When you listen to a song many, many times, your brain puts all the words of that song into one of those special boxes and closes the lid really tight. Even if you don't open that box for a long, long time, like when you don't play with a certain toy for a while, the words are still safe and sound inside! Then, when you hear just a little bit of the song again, or even think about it, it's like your brain has a magic key that opens that special box, and *ta-da!* All the words pop right out, ready for you to sing along! Your brain is just super good at remembering things you've learned well, like a super smart keeper of all your favorite songs.

title: Why does nicotine enhance the realism of dreams? What are some other things that may have this effect?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a super-duper movie projector, and when you're asleep, it plays special movies called dreams! Sometimes, a thing called nicotine (which is in

title: Why do we expect technologically advanced extraterrestrial life to broadcast radio signals into space?
text: Okay, imagine you want to talk to your friend who lives super, super far away, like in another city. You can't just shout, right? So you use a phone! Radio signals are like invisible phone calls or invisible sounds that can travel really, really far, even all the way to space! We think that if aliens are super-duper smart, like grown-ups who build amazing toys and machines, they might also use their own kinds of "space phones" to talk to each other, or maybe their big space TVs and computers just make invisible noise that travels really far away by accident. So, we listen for those invisible space sounds because it's the fastest way for us to hear if anyone else is out there playing or talking with their own space phones! It's like listening for someone else's music playing really loud from far away.

title: Why do we like to raise two fingers (aka the "peace sign") when posing for a picture?
text: Okay, imagine you're super happy and you want to show it without saying anything! When you put up two fingers like that, it's called a "peace sign." "Peace" means everyone is friends, no one is fighting, and everyone is happy and calm. So, when people make that sign in a picture, it's like they're sending a happy message to everyone who sees it, saying "Yay, I'm happy and I wish everyone else was happy too!" It's a way to be friendly and show you're having a good time, like a little smile with your fingers!

title: The saying "feed a cold, starve a fever". Just an old wise tale or is it accurate? If so what is happening physically?
text: That old saying, "feed a cold, starve a fever," is like a story from long, long ago, and it's not really a rule we have to follow! When you have a cold, your body is fighting tiny invisible bad guys (germs) that make your nose runny or make you cough. Eating yummy food gives your body energy, like gas for a car, to help it fight those bad guys and get better. So, eating when you have a cold is a good idea if you feel hungry! When you have a fever, your body gets

title: Country borders are huge, how do they prevent people from sneaking past along the entire border?
text: Imagine your house had a super, super long fence, like all the way around your whole town! It would be really hard for your grown-ups to watch every single little spot all the time, right? Country borders are like that, but even bigger! So, they can't watch every single tiny bit. But what they *do* is put grown-ups called 'border patrol' to drive cars and walk around in the most important places, kind of like your parents watching you at the playground. They also build big fences or walls in some spots to make it harder to just walk over, and they use cameras, like the one on your tablet, to watch even when no one is there. Sometimes they even have special dogs with super sniffy noses or little flying robots called drones to help look! And sometimes, nature helps, like big mountains or super wide rivers that are too hard to cross. It's really, really hard to watch everywhere, so sometimes people still try to sneak past, but the grown-ups try their very best to keep everyone safe and know who is coming and going.

title: Why does one person singing out of tune sound like ass, but 50,000 people singing out of tune sounds amazing?
text: Imagine you have one crayon, and you try to draw a perfectly straight line. If your hand wobbles just a tiny bit, you can see that the line isn't perfectly straight, and it might look a little messy. That's like one person singing out of tune – your ears can hear that one voice making little wobbles, and it sounds a bit wrong. But now, imagine 50,000 kids all drawing lines at the same time, all trying to draw straight, but everyone's hand wobbles just a little bit differently. You don't see each individual wobbly line anymore! Instead, you see a giant, big, colourful scribble that looks super exciting and powerful because there are so many lines all blending together. When lots and lots of people sing together, even if each person is a little bit wobbly (out of tune), all those little wobbles mix up and blend into one giant, big, powerful sound. Your ears don't hear the tiny mistakes anymore; they just hear the big, exciting roar of all those voices together, and it feels really amazing and strong, like a big, happy noise!

title: How is it possible to move a house/building?
text: Imagine your toy house. You just pick it up and move it, right? Well, a real house is too big for us to pick up with our hands! So, smart grown-ups use super strong machines, like giant robot arms or very big jacks, that slowly, slowly lift the whole house up a little bit, just like magic! Once it's floating a little, they slide a special, super-duper strong bed with lots and lots of wheels underneath it. Think of it like a giant skateboard for a house! Then, a really big truck hooks up to this house-skateboard and very, very slowly pulls it to its new spot, like a snail going on an adventure. When it gets there, the machines gently put the house back down on its new special spot, and it's all ready to live in again!

title: What rule of sound waves makes sounds that are 12 half steps away from each other read as the same note to us?
text: Imagine sound is like a bouncing ball. When a ball bounces a certain way, our ears say, "Oh, that's a 'C' note!" Now, if you make

title: Why do we laugh more when we are around people witnessing something funny as opposed to being alone?
text: Imagine you see a really funny wobbly dog! You might giggle a little. But if your mommy or daddy or friends are there too, and they also see the wobbly dog and start laughing loudly, guess what? Their happy laughing sounds make *your* giggles turn into bigger, louder laughs! It's like when you're playing with your friends, and one person starts clapping, then everyone else starts clapping too, and it gets super loud and fun together. We laugh more when we're with people because it feels good to share happy feelings, and when you hear others laughing, it's like a special happy signal that makes your own happy feelings grow even bigger!

title: Why are economic ideas called theories?
text: Imagine you and your friends have a big pile of toys, and you're trying to figure out the very best way for everyone to share them so everyone is happy. Someone might say, "I have an idea! What if we take turns playing with the red car, and then everyone gets to play with the blue truck?" That's like a smart guess or a plan for how things *might* work best. In grown-up talk, when people have big ideas about how everyone should share their money, jobs, and all the things they make, and they think it's a really good plan but they can't *always* know for sure what will happen until they try it, they call those ideas "theories." It's like saying, "I have a theory that if we eat all our veggies, we'll get dessert!" It's a really smart guess based on what they know, but it's not a 100% promise until you see what happens.

title: Why is processed "regular" pasta cheaper than whole grain?
text: Okay, imagine wheat is like a tiny little apple! For regular pasta, we only use the soft, yummy white part inside the apple. It's super easy to get a lot of it, and it's easy to squish it all together to make pasta. So, it doesn't cost very much money. But for whole grain pasta, we use *all* of the apple – the soft yummy inside, the crunchy red skin, and even the tiny

title: Why do we cry? What is the connection of tears coming out of our eyes with sadness or even happiness.
text: Your eyes are like little fountains that can make special water called tears! When you feel a super big feeling inside, like when you're really, really sad because you miss someone or dropped your favorite toy, your body wants to let some of that big feeling out, kind of like a balloon letting out air. The tears are like little messengers that come out of your eyes to tell everyone, "Hey, I'm feeling a big feeling right now!" And sometimes, letting those tears out helps your body feel a little bit lighter. But guess what? Sometimes, when you're SUPER DUPER happy, like when you get a giant surprise present or see someone you love very much after a long time, your body gets so full of that happy feeling that it just overflows with happy tears! It's like your heart is so big and full, some happy water just spills out because it's too much good feeling to keep inside. So, tears are just your body's way of showing everyone how big your feelings are, whether they're sad or super happy!

title: Why do some people sleep like rocks, while others wake up at the sound of a pin drop?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little guard in a castle, and when you sleep, the castle doors close. For some people, their guard is super sleepy and strong, so they lock all the doors really tight and don't hear anything outside, even big noises! That's sleeping like a rock. Their brain just wants to rest, rest, rest. For other people, their guard is a bit more awake and curious, so they leave some doors a tiny bit open, or they just have really good hearing, and even a tiny whisper can make them peek outside. It's just how their special brain is built, or sometimes it's because they're not super duper tired, or their brain is just extra good at listening for things, like when they have to wake up early for school or if they're a parent listening for their baby. So, some brains are like super deep sleepers, and some are like super light sleepers!

title: Why are theatrical movies 2.40:1 or a similar aspect ratio but our TVs are only 16:9?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper wide coloring book, like a giant window! When you go to the movie theater, the screen is like that giant, wide page because the movie makers want to show you *lots* of things all at once, like a big, big castle or many, many people, to make you feel like you're right there inside the story, seeing everything around you. It's like having really wide eyes! But your TV at home is like a different, not-so-wide page in your coloring book; it's a good size for your living room. So, when a super-duper wide movie tries to fit on your not-so-wide TV, it's like trying to put a really long hot dog into a regular hot dog bun – it just doesn't quite fit perfectly side-to-side. To make sure you still see *all* the cool stuff from the wide movie without squishing it, your TV shows the whole wide picture but leaves a little empty space on the top and bottom, which are those black bars you sometimes see.

title: Why does coconut oil and other oils soak into some people's skin, and sit on top of others?
text: Imagine your skin is like a little sponge, and the coconut oil is like a yummy drink for it. If your skin-sponge is a bit dry, it's super thirsty! So when you put the oil on, *slurp*, it drinks it all up quickly and it disappears. But if your skin-sponge is already a little wet or full (maybe it has its own natural oils), it's not very thirsty. So when you put the oil drink on, it just sits on top like a little puddle because it can't drink any more right now. Everyone's skin-sponge is a little different, some are thirstier and some are not, and that's why it looks different for different people!

title: What is a trust fund and how do trust funds work?
text: Imagine a trust fund is like a super special piggy bank, but it's not just any piggy bank you keep in your room. This special piggy bank is set up by a grown-up, maybe your grandma or grandpa, who puts money or even special things inside just for you! But here's the fun part: you can't just open it up and take the money whenever you want. There's another grown-up, like a very careful helper, who is in charge of this special piggy bank. They are like the keeper of the key. The grown-up who put the money in tells this helper exactly when and how you can get the money out. Maybe they say, "This money is for when they go to a big school, like college!" or "They can use this money to buy a house when they're a grown-up!" So, the helper makes sure the money stays super safe and only lets you have it when you're older and for the special things the first grown-up said you could use it for. It's like a special promise from a grown

title: How does the liver work? Like mechanically?
text: Imagine your liver is like a super important cleaning station or a little factory right inside your tummy! All the blood from your body, which carries everything you eat and drink, flows through it like a river. Your liver acts like a big, smart sponge or a filter. It *grabs* and *sucks up* all the yucky or bad stuff that shouldn't be in your body, like a dirty dish rag soaking up spills. Then, it's super clever and *changes* that bad stuff into something harmless, or it *packs it up* so your body can easily get rid of it later when you go potty. It also *holds onto* good stuff, like energy and vitamins, and *sends them out* when your body needs them, like a helpful storage cupboard. So it's constantly filtering, changing, and storing things to keep you healthy and strong!

title: Does the placebo effect prove that our minds have a lot more power than we can directly utilize?
text: Imagine you have a little boo-boo, like a scraped knee. If someone gives you a special, yummy candy and tells you it's super medicine that will make your boo-boo feel better, sometimes, even if it's *just* candy and not real medicine, your knee starts to feel a little bit better! That's because your brain is super, super powerful. It hears that good news and tells your body, 'Hey, we're getting help!' and your body starts to feel better all by itself. It shows that your brain is always working hard inside you, helping your body feel good, and when it *believes* something good is going to happen, it can make your body help itself even more. It's not like your brain can make you fly or make toys appear just by thinking, but it definitely helps your body feel better sometimes just by believing things will be okay!

title: Why do fish herd together into schools for protection?
text: Imagine you're a tiny fish, and there's a really big, hungry fish swimming around looking for a snack! If you're all by yourself, it's super easy for the big fish to see you and gobble you up. But if you and all your fishy friends swim super close together, like a big, wobbly, sparkly ball, it's much safer! Here's why: it's like playing hide-and-seek, but instead of hiding, you all stick together. The big, hungry fish looks at the giant blob of fish and thinks, "Woah! That's too many fish to pick from!" or sometimes, all those little fish moving together look like one *giant* fish, and big fish don't want to mess with *other* giant fish! It also makes it super confusing for the bad guy to pick just one fish to chase, because they're all zipping and zooming together, making it hard to catch anyone. So, by sticking together, they make it really hard for the bad guys to get them, and they feel much braver and safer!

title: What makes Earth's core molten hot?
text: Imagine when Earth was first made, it was like a giant, squishy ball that got squished together really, really fast! All that squishing made it super, super hot, and the middle part (the core) is still holding onto a lot of that original heat, like a giant baked potato that stays warm inside for a long time. Then, imagine you squeeze a sponge really, really hard – it gets a little warm, right? Well, the Earth's core has the weight of *all* the rocks above it pushing down, squeezing it unbelievably hard, and all that squeezing makes it even hotter! Plus, deep inside the Earth, there are special rocks that are like tiny, tiny little heaters. They slowly break apart and make a little bit of warmth, and because there are so many of them all together, they keep the core super, super hot, like a melted chocolate bar in the sun!

title: Why is it impossible (very difficult) to reverse a password hash?
text: Okay, imagine your secret password is like a whole, yummy apple. When you tell a computer your password, it doesn't just keep the apple as it is. Instead, it puts your apple

title: How do we get headaches if the brain has no pain receptor?
text: Your brain is like a super important boss inside your head, or maybe like a superhero who's super busy thinking all the thoughts and making you move and talk! And guess what? This superhero brain itself doesn't have little "ouchy" sensors. It's too busy being amazing! But around your superhero brain, there are lots of other things, like the muscles on your head, the blood tubes that bring food to your brain, and the special blanket that wraps it all up. *These* things *do* have "ouchy" sensors! So when you get a headache, it's not your brain feeling the ouchy. It's like one of the brain's helpers around it got squished too tight, or stretched out, or got a bit angry. Maybe the blood tubes are pushing too hard, or the muscles are squeezed super tight. And when these helpers feel ouchy, they send a message to the superhero brain saying, "Hey! Something's not right out here!" And that's when your brain tells you, "Uh oh, you have a headache!" It's the brain getting a message from its surroundings, not feeling the pain itself.

title: Why would a computer replace a simple character (') into a complicated series of nonsense ( & #39;) when copying and pasting certain text?
text: Okay, imagine computers have their own secret language, just like you have your words! Sometimes, a little mark like an apostrophe (') can be a bit tricky in their secret language, because it can mean two different things: sometimes it's just a letter, and sometimes it's a special signal to tell the computer to do something. So, when computers are talking to each other, especially on the internet (like when you copy from a website), they want to be *super* clear. To make sure *everyone* knows it's just a regular little mark and not a secret signal, they spell it out in a very long, clear way, like writing "this-is-just-a-simple-mark-that-looks-like-this-'-and-it's-not-a-secret-command!" That long `'` is just the computer being extra careful so no one gets confused!

title: What is the circle of fifths and how do you read it?
text:
Imagine you have a super special clock, but it doesn't tell you what time it is, it tells you about music! This is called the "circle of fifths." It's like a secret map that shows us which musical sounds, like happy songs (we call them major keys) and sad songs (we call them minor keys), are friends and like to play together.

You read it like this: Each big letter on the outside of the clock is a "home base" for a happy song, like C, G, or D. Inside each happy home, there's a little letter, which is its best friend, a sad song that lives there too! If you go around the clock to the right, like turning the hands forward, each step adds a new "sparkly

title: what do we actually see at the edge of the observable universe?
text: Imagine you have a super big room, bigger than your house, bigger than your whole town! And you have a flashlight. When you turn on the flashlight, the light goes out, right? But it takes a tiny, tiny bit of time for the light to travel. The universe is like that super, super big room, and when we look really, really, really far away, we're seeing light that started its journey a super, super long time ago, when the universe was just a tiny baby! It's not a wall or an end you can touch, but like looking at a super old photo of the universe when it was very, very young and still glowing like a warm, fuzzy cloud, before all the stars and galaxies we see today were properly made. So, we're seeing the universe's baby picture!

title: What is the point of SMS Short Codes?
text: Okay, imagine your phone is like a special toy box. Usually, when you want to call your mommy or daddy, their number is super long, like counting all your fingers and toes many, many times! But sometimes, there are special, super-duper short numbers, like just "1-2-3-4" instead of "1-2-3-4-5-6-7-8-9-0"! These short numbers are like secret buttons. When you send a message to one of these short numbers, it's not talking to a person, it's talking to a special computer program that does quick, fun things! Maybe it tells you a joke, or helps you vote for your favorite singer on TV, or sends you a coupon for a yummy ice cream. So, they're just easy-peasy numbers to remember for when you want to get something quick or play a game with your phone!

title: Why is Facebook advertising it's "Facebook Live" feature so heavily?
text: Imagine Facebook is like a really big playground where all your friends hang out! "Facebook Live" is like a super cool, brand new toy they just put on the playground, maybe like a giant slide or a bouncy castle that shows you fun things happening *right now*. Facebook wants *everyone* to come and play with this new toy because if you play with it, you'll have so much fun and want to stay on *their* playground for a long, long time! If you stay longer and watch all the cool live shows, you might see other fun things too, and maybe even some yummy snacks being sold (that's like the grown-up ads), which helps Facebook make money so they can keep their playground open and add even more fun toys. They just want to make sure their playground is the most exciting place to be, so you don't go play at another playground instead!

title: How does the U.S. government owe money to itself?
text: Imagine your family is like the big government, and they have different piggy banks! One piggy bank is for all the grown-ups who are old (it's called Social Security), and it's like their special savings account. Another piggy bank is for everything else, like building roads or paying for schools. Sometimes, the "everything else" piggy bank needs more money, but it's a little empty. So, the grown-ups (the government) might borrow some money from

title: Why is there an enzyme in the human body that breaks down methanol into formaldehyde? How does this enzyme exist in the first place?
text: Imagine your body has tiny, tiny helpers called enzymes, kind of like little toy sorters. This particular helper's *real* job is to sort and clean up other kinds of

title: Why can a psychological condition/state (like stress) cause physiological effects?
text: Imagine your brain is like the super smart boss of your whole body. It's in charge of everything! When you feel something big in your head, like when you're super worried about something or really scared (that's stress!), your brain thinks, 'Uh oh, something might be wrong!' Then, your brain sends super fast messages, like little alerts, all over your body. It tells your heart to beat faster, so you could run away if you needed to. It might tell your tummy to feel a bit funny, like butterflies, because it's busy getting ready for something.
