title: Why do distant lights appear to "shimmer"?
text: Imagine a light far, far away, like a tiny star. Its light is like a straight, invisible string coming right to your eye. But between you and the light, there's lots of air, like an invisible blanket! This air isn't always still; sometimes it's hot in one spot and cold in another, or the wind is gently pushing it around. When the light string tries to travel through this wobbly, wiggly air, the air makes the string bend and wiggle just a tiny, tiny bit before it gets to your eye. So, the light looks like it's dancing or shimmering because the air is playing a little trick on it, making it wiggle as it travels to you!

title: Why do the drawstrings on sweaters and hoodies always try to come out of the hoods when they are run through a washer and dryer?
text: Imagine your drawstring is like a long, sleepy worm napping inside a tunnel all around your hoodie. When your hoodie goes into the washing machine, it's like a big, bubbly, splashy swimming pool! The water makes everything super slippery, and the machine tumbles and spins your hoodie all around, like a giant mixer. This makes the sleepy worm-string wiggle and slide a little bit. Then, when it goes into the dryer, it's like a warm, rumbly playground! The dryer tumbles and bumps your hoodie even more. All that spinning, wiggling, and bumping makes the slippery string want to squirm out of its tunnel, little by little, until it finally pops its head out and tries to escape! It's just like when you wiggle your finger out of a tight glove – all the movement helps it slide free.

title: How do TV advertisements earn so much money when it seems like no one pays attention to them?
text: Okay, imagine your favorite cartoon show! Lots and lots of kids and grown-ups watch it, right? Well, companies that make yummy snacks, cool toys, or fun clothes want *you* and your grown-ups to know about their stuff. So, they go to the people who make your TV channel and say, "Hey! Can we show our new robot toy for a little bit during the cartoon? We'll give you lots of shiny coins if you do!" The TV channel people say "Okay!" because they know if they show the robot toy, lots of kids will see it, even if they're just getting a drink or playing with another toy. Later, when you're at the store, you might see that robot toy and remember it from TV and ask your grown-up for it! When lots of kids ask for the toy, the company sells many toys and makes lots of money. Because they make so much money from people buying their stuff after seeing it on TV, they are happy to pay the TV channels *a lot* of shiny coins to show their ads again and again. It's like paying to put up a big, big sign where everyone can see it, even if they're just walking by!

title: How does the Magic Eraser work?
text: Okay, imagine your Magic Eraser isn't really magic, but it's a super special, very clever sponge! It's made of millions and millions of tiny, tiny, tiny hard little fingers, so small you can't even see them. When you rub it on a dirty mark or a scuff on the wall, those tiny fingers gently scrape off the dirt, almost like a super soft sandpaper that's only strong enough to take away the yucky stuff. And because it's working so hard to scrape all that dirt away, the tiny fingers on the sponge break off too, which is why your Magic Eraser gets smaller and smaller until it's all gone, just like a crayon gets smaller when you color a lot!

title: Why is it brighter outside at night went it is snowing?
text: Imagine the whole world puts on a giant white blanket when it snows! Snow is super good at being white, and white things are like little mirrors for light. So, even if there's just a tiny bit of light from the moon or a faraway street light, it hits the white snow, and the snow bounces that light up into the sky and all around, making everything look much brighter than when the ground is just dark. It's like having lots and lots of tiny little flashlights all over the place, helping the light spread out!

title: What's going on in Mexico right now with the raising of gas prices and other amenities? Why are people looting stores and pissed off?
text: Imagine your mommy and daddy's car needs special juice to make it go zoom-zoom. Before, that juice cost a little bit of money, like if you wanted to buy one yummy candy. title: Why can you hear the voices in the apartment above you so easily, but not the voices in the apartment below you?

title: Why does orange juice from Tropicana taste different from Simply Orange if they're both 100% Orange Juice?
text: Okay, imagine you have two different kinds of apples, a red one and a green one. Both are apples, but they taste a little different, right? It's kind of like that with oranges! Tropicana might use oranges from one kind of tree, and Simply Orange might use oranges from another kind, or a mix of different trees. Plus, after they squeeze the oranges, the grown-ups at each company do a few special things to make sure the juice stays yummy for a long time and tastes the same every time you buy it. They have their own secret ways, like a special recipe, to make their juice unique. So even though both are made from 100% oranges, because they use different oranges and different secret steps, they end up tasting a little different for your tongue!

title: What is that clicking sound in your ears every time you swallow something?
text: Imagine your ear is like a tiny secret room inside your head, and it has a little door! This door is usually closed, but every time you swallow your yummy food or drink, your body quickly opens and closes that little door for just a tiny second. It's like when you open a door quickly and it makes a little *click* sound. Your body does this to let a tiny puff of air in or out, which helps keep the air pressure inside your ear-room just right, like making sure a balloon isn't too squishy or too hard. It's a normal and helpful little sound!

title: Why are most circuitboards green? Does it make a difference if its any other color?
text: Imagine your special toys have tiny, tiny roads inside them, and these roads are super important for making your toy work! We put a special green "paint" on top of these roads to keep them safe from dust, bumps, and accidental pokes. This green paint was just the easiest and cheapest color to make for a long, long time, and it also helped grown-ups see all the little roads and tiny parts really clearly when they were building things. That's why so many of them ended up being green! But guess what? You can totally have circuit boards with blue paint, or red paint, or even black paint! They all do the exact same job of protecting those tiny roads inside; the color doesn't make the toy work any better or worse, it just looks different, like choosing a different color crayon for your drawing!

title: Can someone explain why a Government deficit is made out to be so bad, especially since it appears that most Governments are running them?
text: Imagine your piggy bank. Every week, your parents give you some allowance money to put in it. A "deficit" means you spend *more* money than you have in your piggy bank. So, if you only have $5 but you want to buy a toy that costs $7, you have a deficit of $2. Why is that bad? Well, if you keep spending more than you have, your piggy bank will become empty very quickly! Then, to buy things, you have to ask your parents or a friend to lend you money. And guess what? When you borrow money, you have to pay it back later, sometimes even a little bit extra for letting you borrow it. If you borrow *too* much, you'll spend all your future money just paying back old debts, and you won't have enough for new toys, or snacks, or even important things like clothes. Governments are kind of like that. They get money from people (taxes), and if they spend more than they get, they have a deficit. They have to borrow

title: Why do bread items always heat up so quickly in the microwave compared to any other food item?
text: Okay, imagine the microwave is like a special light that only likes to tickle water. When the light tickles the water in your food, the water gets super excited and starts to wiggle and jiggle really fast, and that makes it hot! Bread is like a sponge or a cloud, right? It has little bits of water spread out, but also lots and lots of tiny air bubbles inside it. When the microwave tickles the water in the bread, those little bits of water get hot really, really fast. And because there's so much air all around those hot water bits, the air gets hot super quick too, making the whole piece of bread feel warm almost instantly! Other foods, like a big potato or a bowl of macaroni, have much more water packed closer together, and not as much air, so it takes longer for *all* of it to get hot and for the warmth to spread all the way through.

title: Why does a weak am/fm radio signal result in a consistent static/fuzzy sound while a weak satellite radio signal results in intermittent high quality sound?
text:

Now, your other friend, like satellite radio, is sending you the story on tiny little pieces of paper, like puzzle pieces. They send a whole bunch of pieces at once. If your radio gets *all* the puzzle pieces for a moment, you can put them together and hear the story perfectly clear! Yay! title: What causes that "sinking heart" feeling when extremely sad?
text: When you're super, super sad, it's like a really big, quiet cloud comes inside you. Your brain, which is the boss of your whole body, knows you feel this big sadness. Because it's such a strong feeling, your body gets a little quiet and slow too. It might make your breathing feel a bit different, or make the part of your chest where your heart lives feel a little empty or heavy, like when a big sigh comes out. Your heart isn't actually sinking down, but it's just how your body tells you, "Whoa, this is a really big, quiet, sad feeling right now!" It's like your body is feeling all the big sadness right along with you.

title: What causes a beer belly?
text: Imagine your body is like a little piggy bank for energy! When you eat yummy food or drink tasty drinks, your body uses some of that energy to run and play and grow big and strong. But sometimes, grown-ups put *too much* energy into their piggy bank, more than their body needs right then. When that happens, your body doesn't just throw the extra energy away! It's smart, so it saves it for later, like saving a snack for after naptime. It turns that extra energy into something called 'fat,' and it often likes to store a lot of it right around your tummy. So, a 'beer belly' isn't just from drinking beer – it's just a funny name for when someone has put a little too much extra energy (from *any* kind of food or drink, like juice, candy, big meals, or yes, even beer for grown-ups) into their body's piggy bank, and it shows up as a rounder tummy!

title: How do scientists predict, down to the exact degree, what the temperature will be for the next week?

title: when a person has an electric shock that travels along their nerves, does the electricity travel the same way as normal nervous signals?

It doesn't go the same way as your body's gentle whispers; instead, it's so big and powerful it just pushes through everything, making all your body's little whispers get very confused and stop working right, which is why it hurts and makes your body jump.

title: How do waterfalls freeze?
text: Imagine your juice box! If you put it in the freezer, it gets super, super cold, and then it turns into a hard, cold block, right? That's what happens to the water in a waterfall! When the air outside gets colder than your freezer for many, many days, the water that's usually running down starts to feel that cold. The edges of the waterfall, where the water touches the cold rocks and air, start to get hard first, like little icy fingers. Then, more and more water gets super cold and sticks to those icy parts, getting harder and harder, until the whole waterfall turns into a giant, sparkling, frozen slide of ice! It's like the water is playing "freeze tag" and gets stuck in place.

title: How does a plan detect that missiles have been 'locked on'? What does this mean?
text: Imagine a missile is like a super-smart toy airplane that wants to follow your toy car. "Locked on" means the missile has found your toy car and is now trying its very best to always point right at it, no matter where your car goes, so it can catch it! It's like when you point your finger at your friend and keep pointing at them even when they run around. Now, how does your toy car (the plane) know this is happening? Well, some missiles use special "eyes" that send out invisible "light" or "beeps" to find the car, and your car has special "ears" that can hear these invisible beeps bouncing off it. Other missiles use "eyes" that look for warm things, like your car's hot engine. When your plane hears or feels these invisible "eyes" looking at it very, very closely, it makes a loud "BEEP BEEP BEEP!" sound or flashes a light in the cockpit to tell the pilot, "Uh oh, someone is trying to follow us super close!" That's how the plane knows it's being "locked on" to.

title: Why are houses in older communities so spaced out in age, compared to newer neighborhoods?(US)
text: Imagine a big empty field, like a giant sandbox! When grown-ups build a *new* neighborhood, they usually build *all* the houses there at pretty much the *same time*, like when you get a whole new box of LEGOs and build a whole city all at once. So, all those houses are almost the same age. But in really *old* places, it was different! First, someone built just *one* house, then many, many years later, someone else built *another* house next to it, and then even more years went by, and someone built a *different* house. It was like adding houses one by one over a very, very long time, like building your LEGO city slowly over many birthdays. That's why in old neighborhoods, you can see some houses that are super old, like grandpas, and some that are middle-aged, like moms, and even some newer ones, like little baby houses, all living on the same street! They weren't all born at the same time.

title: Why do erasers fail to fully remove pencil marks?
text: Imagine your paper is like a bumpy road, and your pencil mark is lots of tiny, tiny dark pebbles. When you draw, some pebbles sit right on top of the road, but some also fall into the little cracks and holes in the road. Your eraser is like a soft, sticky broom! It's really good at sweeping up all the pebbles that are sitting on top of the road, and it makes them stick to itself. But the pebbles that fell deep into the tiny cracks and holes in the paper road are much harder for the broom to reach and pull out without breaking the road itself. So, the eraser gets almost all of them, but a few super-stubborn, deep-down pebbles stay behind, making it look a little bit grey!

title: What is Obama Care?
text: Imagine you have a boo-boo or you feel yucky, and you need to see the doctor to feel better. Sometimes, going to the doctor or getting special medicine costs a lot of money, like buying a really big toy. A long time ago, when President Obama was the boss, he made a special rule, like a big helping hand, called Obama Care. It's a plan to help grown-ups and kids so that *more* people can go to the doctor and get the medicine they need without it costing too much money. It's like a big sharing system that helps make sure everyone has a chance to stay healthy and strong, so they don't have to worry so much if they get sick. It helps make sure everyone can get a doctor when they need one, just like everyone should get to play and feel good!

title: How does eating lots of fatty/fried foods lead to sore throat?
text: Imagine your tummy is like a big balloon where food goes. When you eat lots of yummy but greasy and fried foods, they are a bit heavy and stay in your tummy for a long, long time. Your tummy has a special, strong juice to help mush up the food. But sometimes, when the tummy is super full and working hard on those heavy foods, a tiny bit of that strong juice can splash up a little tube that goes from your tummy to your throat. When that strong juice touches your throat, it's like a little 'ouchie' or a tiny sting, and that makes your throat feel grumpy and sore, like it's been tickled the wrong way!

title: What is that 'beep' sound that submarines make in movies ?
text: You know how sometimes when you're in a dark room, you might clap your hands or shout to see if there's anything in front of you? And if you hear the sound bounce back quickly, you know something is close? Well, submarines are way under the water, and it's super dark down there, so they can't see with their eyes. That 'beep' sound is like the submarine shouting a special sound very loudly! Then, they listen very, very carefully. If the sound hits something, like another boat or a big rock, it bounces back to them, just like your shout bouncing back in a cave. By listening to how long it takes for the sound to come back, they can tell if there's something far away or really close, and even where it is! It's their special way of 'seeing' under the water, and we call it sonar!

title: What causes that "sick" feeling when you see your crush with someone else?

title: What is that whistling sound when an old TV turns on?
text: Imagine your TV has a special little engine inside, just like your toy car, but this engine helps make pictures! When you push the button, it's like turning on a tiny, super-fast water hose inside. This hose pushes something called "electricity" really, really quickly to get all the lights and colors ready. Sometimes, when that electricity rushes through a special part to make a bright picture, it makes a tiny, quick "WHOOSH" sound, almost like a little whistle, just for a second. It's just the TV saying, "I'm waking up and getting ready to show you your favorite cartoon!"

title: Why do clothes hung up to dry take over 8 hours to dry when my swimsuit is completely dry an hour after I leave the pool?
text: Your swimsuit is like a super-thin, slippery leaf, and it doesn't like to hold onto water at all! When you get out of the pool, the water just slides right off it, and because it's so thin, the sun and wind can quickly give it a big hug and make all the tiny water drops go away in just a little bit of time. But your other clothes, like your t-shirt or jeans, are more like a fluffy sponge! They're much thicker and have lots of tiny little holes that love to drink up water and hold onto it super tight, like a secret treasure. So, even when you hang them up, all that water is hiding deep inside, and it takes a very, very long time for the sun and wind to find every single drop and make it disappear completely.

title: what's the difference between brown sugar and "normal" sugar?
text: "Normal" sugar is like tiny, shiny white rocks that taste super sweet! It's very clean and pure. Brown sugar is almost the exact same tiny white rocks, but they have a little bit of a special, yummy, sticky brown syrup all over them, like a sweet sauce! This sticky syrup is called molasses, and it makes the sugar brown and a little bit moist, and it gives brown sugar a yummy, slightly different taste, like a warm, cozy caramel. So, one is just pure sweet white rocks, and the other is those same rocks with a special brown sticky sauce on them!

title: Why and how you need to clean out your ears?
text: Imagine your ear makes a special gooey yellow stuff called earwax, like a sticky shield! This shield catches tiny dust and dirt so it doesn't go deep inside your ear and make it ouchy. Most of the time, this old earwax just falls out by itself when you eat yummy food or talk a lot. But sometimes, too much sticky stuff can build up, like a big sticky jam, and it can make it hard for you to hear your favorite songs, or make your ear feel full or itchy. To clean your ears, it's super important to only clean the *outside* part you can see with a soft washcloth and warm water when you're in the bath or shower, just like you wash your face! **Never ever** put anything small inside your ear, like a cotton swab or your finger, because it can push the earwax deeper inside and hurt your ear, which would make it sad! If you feel like there's too much sticky stuff inside and it's bothering you, a grown-up can help put a special soft drop in your ear to make the wax fall out, or a special doctor can help clean it out safely so your ears can hear all the fun sounds again!

title: How do pharmacies have almost all medication in stock in such a small area?
text: Imagine a pharmacy is like a special toy store, but for grown-up medicine! They don't have *every single* type of medicine in the whole wide world, just like your toy box doesn't have *every single toy* ever made. But they have lots and lots of the medicines that many people need often, like medicine for a cough or a tummy ache, or special ones people take every day. Medicines are usually tiny, like little pills or liquid in small bottles. Because they are so small, you can fit a *whole bunch* of different kinds of medicine on shelves, just like you can fit lots of small LEGOs in a small box. The grown-ups who work there are super organized! They put all the same kinds of medicine together and know exactly where everything is, so they can find it super fast, like knowing where your red car is in your toy bin. And if someone needs a medicine they *don't* have right then, a special delivery truck can bring it to them super-duper fast, sometimes even the very next day! So it's like they have a giant warehouse far away that sends them exactly what they need when they need it, making it feel like they always have it.

title: Why are some allergies so common, like peanuts?
text: Imagine your body has tiny, friendly guards inside, like little superheroes! Their job is to keep you safe from yucky germs and bad stuff. Sometimes, these guards get a little bit confused. They see something totally harmless, like a tiny piece of a peanut, and they think it's a big, scary monster! So they shout and make a big fuss to try and get it out, and that's what makes you feel itchy or sick. Now, why peanuts? Well, peanuts are a food that lots and lots of people eat! So, there are many more chances for people's body guards to meet peanuts and get confused. Also, peanuts have lots of different tiny parts inside them, like many different shapes, and some of those shapes just happen to be extra confusing for some people's guards. It's like some guards just have a harder time telling the difference between a friendly toy and a real monster when it comes to peanuts, and sometimes, it's just how your body is made, like having a special rulebook that makes your guards extra careful about certain things like peanuts.

title: What happens to particle movement below absolute zero?
text: Okay, imagine all your tiny little toy blocks are always wiggling and jiggling, even when you can't see them! When it's hot, they wiggle super fast. When it's cold, they wiggle slower and slower. Absolute zero is like the very, very, *very* coldest it can ever, ever get in the whole wide world. It's so cold that those tiny wiggling blocks almost completely stop moving. They can't wiggle any slower than that! So, there isn't really a 'below' absolute zero, because once they've almost stopped, they just can't stop any more. It's the end of the wiggles!

title: What's a byte (gigabyte, megabyte) made of and how big is it?
text: Imagine you have tiny little light switches, and each one can be either ON or OFF. We call one of these switches a "bit"! A "byte" is like having 8 of these little light switches all together in a row, like a tiny team! So, a byte is made of 8 bits, and it's super tiny, just enough space to hold one letter, like the letter 'A'. Now, if you collect lots and lots of these bytes, things get bigger! A "Megabyte" (say "Mega-byte") is like having a whole big picture book with lots of pages and pictures, because it's a million bytes! And a "Gigabyte" (say "Giga-byte") is even bigger, like a whole library full of those picture books, or a really long movie you watch, because it's a thousand Megabytes!

title: If I call a friend from far away, how does my call find it's way to his/her cellphone?
text: Okay, imagine your voice is like a little invisible message you want to send. It knows exactly which other towers or special invisible roads (some even go under the ground or the water, like secret tunnels!) to send your message on so it can travel super, super fast all the way to where your friend lives. It's like a big relay race for your voice! When your message gets close to your friend's house, another big tower there catches it and then whispers it right into your friend's phone. And just like magic, they hear you!

title: How were scientists able to film and capture the stages of childbirth before/during the 90's?
text: Imagine grown-ups had special cameras, a bit like a big box, that had a special tape inside, kind of like a tiny movie tape. They needed lots of bright lights, like the big lights in your kitchen, so the camera could see everything clearly, and then it would record all the moving pictures onto that special tape. Later, they would put the tape into a special machine to watch it on a TV, like watching a cartoon, but it was real life! They did all this so doctors and nurses could learn how babies come into the world, to help them be super good at their job and make sure all the mummies and new babies were safe and happy.
