title: Why do you get a headache the day after a night of crying?
text: Imagine your body is like a big water balloon, and when you cry a lot, you let out a whole bunch of water from your eyes, like tiny waterfalls! If you don't drink enough water back, your body gets a little bit thirsty, and your head feels grumpy because it needs more water. Also, when you cry super hard, all the muscles in your face, especially around your eyes, get really squished and work very, very hard, like they're doing tiny push-ups! They get tired and a bit sore, and that can make your head feel achy. Plus, sometimes when you cry a lot, your nose gets all stuffy and puffy inside, and that can make a little bit of pressure inside your head, which feels like a headache too. So, it's like your head is tired, thirsty, and a little bit squished all at once!

title: Why do far away things appear small?
text: Okay, imagine your eyes are like tiny windows! When something is really close to your window, like your favorite toy right in front of you, it looks big and fills up almost the whole

title: Why do we get tired?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool toy car! All day long, you play and run and learn, which is like your toy car driving around and doing awesome stunts. But just like your toy car needs new batteries after a while because it uses up all its power, your body uses up its 'play energy' too! When your energy gets low, your body starts to feel sleepy and tired. That's its special way of telling you, "Hey! I need to stop and plug myself in to recharge!" So, when you sleep, it's like your body is charging its batteries back up, getting ready to play and have fun again tomorrow. Plus, while you're sleeping, your body also does important 'fix-it' work, making sure everything is strong and ready to go!

title: How much does illegal immigration really affect the United States?
text:
Imagine our country, the United States, is like a really big house or a giant playground. Lots of people live here and play here. Now, some people from other countries want to come live or play here too. Most people ask for a special "ticket" or "permission" first, like asking if they can come to your birthday party. But some people come without that special ticket, and that's what we call "illegal immigration."

When more people come, even without a ticket, it's like having more friends at the playground. Sometimes it's good because there are more people to help build sandcastles or play games – they might do jobs that other people don't want to do, like picking vegetables or building houses. They also bring new yummy foods and fun music!

But sometimes, if too many people come to the playground at once, it can be a bit tricky. Maybe there aren't enough swings for everyone, or the teachers at school have more kids to teach, or the doctors have more people to help. This means we need more money to build new swings, new schools, or have more doctors. Sometimes, people already living here worry there won't be enough jobs for everyone.

So, it's a little bit of both! It means some new help and new fun things, but also sometimes needing to figure out how to share and make sure everyone has what they need. Grown-ups talk a lot about how to make it fair for everyone.

title: Why do we feel extremely disoriented after waking up from a nap, but not as much from a regular night's sleep?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a little bear that goes into a cozy cave to sleep. When you take a nap, sometimes your bear just goes a little bit into the cave, but other times, it goes really deep, really fast, without meaning to! If someone suddenly wakes your bear up when it's super deep in the cave, it gets all confused and grumpy, like "Whoa, where am I? What time is it?!" It takes a little while for your bear to remember where it is. But when you sleep all night long, your bear goes on a long, full journey through the cave, and then it slowly, slowly starts waking up and coming back to the entrance by itself. So when you finally open your eyes, your bear is already waiting at the door, ready to play, and it's much easier to know where you are! Naps can sometimes trick your brain into going too deep too quickly, making it a bit wobbly when you suddenly wake up.

title: Why is a horse's height measured in hands?
text: Imagine you want to know how tall a big dog is, but you don't have a ruler! A long, long time ago, when people didn't have tape measures, they would use their own hand to see how tall a horse was. They'd put their hand flat, one on top of the other, all the way up to the horse's shoulder (that's the bumpy part near its neck). Because everyone's hand is a little bit different, they decided a "hand" would always be exactly four fingers wide, which is like four inches. It was an easy way to measure when there were no rulers around! And even though we have rulers now, we still measure horses in "hands" because it's a special tradition, like how some old stories are told the same way every time.

title: Why do so many people have a penicillin allergy during childhood?
text: Imagine your body is like a little superhero fighting off bad germs when you get sick, and sometimes when your body is working hard, you get little red spots on your skin, like tiny bug bites. Then, the doctor gives you special medicine, like penicillin, to help your superhero body win faster. Sometimes, those red spots show up *right when* you start taking the medicine! So, grown-ups might think, "Oh no, the medicine gave you the spots, you must be allergic!" But often, the spots were actually from the sickness itself, not the medicine. It's like if you eat a cookie and then trip – the cookie didn't make you trip, you just tripped! Kids get sick a lot and get rashes easily, so this misunderstanding happens a bunch. Most of the time, when kids get bigger, they find out they aren't really allergic to that medicine at all, and it was just the sickness playing a trick.

title: Why do names of electronics often end in a seemingly random number?
text: Imagine you have your favorite toy car! When the toy company makes a *new* one that's a little bit better or has a cool new color, they put a number on it, like "Car 5" instead of "Car 4." This helps grown-ups know it's the newest one! Sometimes, the number just means it's a *different kind* of the same toy, like a really big truck version or a smaller, speedy car version, but they are both from the same toy family. So the numbers help grown-ups tell apart the newest toys from the older ones, or the big ones from the small ones, even if they look a little bit alike!

title: Why do certain foods (i.e. vanilla extract) smell so sweet yet taste so bitter even though our smell and taste senses are so closely intertwined?
text: Imagine your nose and your tongue are like two best friends who love to play detective with food! When you smell yummy vanilla extract, your nose detective only finds the happy, sweet-smelling clues that float in the air, like tiny invisible candies. It's like smelling a yummy cake! But when your tongue detective tries to taste it, oops! It's super, super strong, like a giant, super concentrated potion, not just a little bit of yummy flavor. It's like if you had a tiny sip

title: Did the Greek Bailout anyhow affect Germanys economy?
text: Imagine your friend Greece had a super-duper big toy that broke, and they didn't have enough money in their piggy bank to fix it. Germany, who is like a big brother with a really full piggy bank, and some other friends decided to help. Germany said, 'Okay, we'll lend you some of our pocket money so you can fix your toy.' So, Germany took some money out of its own big piggy bank (which is like the money all German grown-ups pay when they work) and gave it to Greece. This meant Germany's piggy bank wasn't quite as full as it used to be. It was like sharing your candy – you still have candy, but a little less than before. Germany hoped that Greece would fix its toy and eventually be able to give the money back. So, yes, it did affect Germany a little bit because they shared their money, but they did it to help a friend and keep everyone playing nicely together.

title: Why does a mathematician receive only a $1 million prize for solving an extremely difficult problem that he devoted decades of his life to solve, but an athlete who throws a ball around a court or football field for an hour receives many times more money?
text: Okay, imagine two friends! One friend, the mathematician, is super, super good at solving a very tricky puzzle that only a few smart grown-ups understand how amazing it is. He works on it for a super long time, and when he finally solves it, those few smart grown-ups give him a special, big prize because it's so clever! Now, your other friend, the athlete, plays a fun game that millions and millions of other kids and grown-ups love to watch! They all buy tickets to see him play, or watch him on TV, and buy his special jersey. Because so many people want to watch and pay money to see the game, there's a super, super big pot of money from all those tickets and TV shows, and even from companies who want to show their toys during the game when everyone is watching. So, the athlete gets a much bigger piece of that super big pot of money because he's making so many people happy and excited, and lots of people are paying to be part of the fun show!

title: Why do you have to refrigerate drinks made with powder?
text: Okay, imagine there are super tiny, invisible little critters all around us, like miniature monsters that love to eat! When your drink is just powder in a packet, it's dry and boring for them, so they don't bother it much. But as soon as you add water and stir it up, it becomes a yummy, wet, and warm party for those little critters! They start eating all the good stuff in your drink and making more of themselves, and that's what makes the drink taste yucky and go bad after a while. Putting your drink in the refrigerator is like putting those little critters in a super cold, sleepy bed. They get so chilly that they slow down and don't eat or make more babies very fast. So, your drink stays yummy and fresh for much, much longer because the sleepy critters aren't making it all gross!

title: Why does the throat become so dry when laying in bed/sleeping?
text: Okay, imagine your mouth and throat are like a little garden. Usually, there's a tiny sprinkler (that's your spit!) that keeps everything nice and wet so it feels comfy. But when you're sleeping, especially if you open your mouth a little or breathe through it, it's like leaving the garden gate open. The air comes in and blows all the water away from your little sprinkler much faster, making it dry. Plus, when you're sleeping, your body is super relaxed and doesn't make as much sprinkler water as when you're awake, so there's less to go around. All that air blowing and less water means your throat garden gets super thirsty and feels dry!

title: When you poke a hole in your vein (e.g giving blood) why does it not keep bleeding under your skin?
text: Imagine your vein is like a tiny, soft rubber tube carrying red juice (blood) all around your body. When the doctor puts a tiny needle in, it makes a super small hole in that rubber tube, and some red juice comes out, right? But your body is super clever! As soon as the needle comes out, two things happen really fast: First, the tiny hole in your rubber tube (vein) is very stretchy and tiny, so it tries to close up all by itself, like when you pinch a balloon. Second, your blood has special sticky bits, like tiny little helpers with super glue! They rush super fast to that tiny hole and make a tiny sticky plug, like putting a tiny piece of tape over the hole. So, between the hole trying to close and the sticky helpers making a plug, the red juice stops coming out, even under your skin, because your body fixes that tiny hole super, super fast!

title: Why tint car windows? Is this purely cosmetic or for privacy reasons?
text: Imagine your car is wearing sunglasses! That's what tinting windows is like. First, it helps keep the car from getting too hot inside, just like your sunglasses help your eyes when it's super bright. It's like putting a big shade over the windows so the sun doesn't bake everything, which also helps keep your skin safe from too much sun, and stops the car's seats and other things from getting faded and old-looking too quickly. Then, it makes it a little harder for people outside to peek inside your car, so it gives you some privacy, like having a secret fort! And yes, some people just think it makes their car look extra cool, like a superhero car! So, it's for keeping cool, keeping safe, having privacy, and looking cool all at the same time!

title: why is it that some animals recognize themselves in the mirror, and some do not?
text: Okay, imagine a mirror is like a super shiny window! When you look in it, you see *you*, right? You know it's you because your brain is super smart and knows what you look like and that the shiny window just shows your reflection. Some animals, like big monkeys called chimps or even some birds, have brains that are smart in a similar way. They look in the mirror and go, "Hey, that's ME!" They might even make silly faces or check their teeth, just like you might! But other animals, like your dog or cat, look in the mirror and they don't know it's them. Their brain thinks, "Whoa, another dog!" or "Look, a new cat!" They might bark or hiss at the mirror

title: Why do people sometimes get runny noses when they eat?
text: Imagine your nose and your mouth are like best friends who live in the same house right inside your face! When you eat yummy food, especially warm or spicy stuff, your mouth gets busy. Sometimes, the smell of the food, or the warmth, or if it's a little bit spicy (like a tiny pepper party!), can make your nose think, "Oh, something's happening here! Maybe I need to help wash something away, or maybe it's just a funny smell!" So, your nose makes a little bit of clear, watery snot, like tiny tears for your nose, to help clear things out or just react to all the exciting food smells and tastes. It's just your body being super clever and reacting to what's going on with your yummy meal!

title: Since I'm bald, do you still need to take my temperature on my forehead or would anywhere on my head work?
text: Imagine your body has a special warm feeling inside, like a cozy oven, and the thermometer is like a little detective trying to find out how warm your oven is. Your forehead is a super good spot for the detective because the skin there is thin, and there are lots of tiny little roads where your warm blood flows right under the surface, making it easy to find the warmth. Hair is like a little blanket that could sometimes make it a tiny bit harder for the detective to see the warmth, but if you're bald, it's actually even easier for the detective to find it on your forehead because there's no blanket! Other parts of your head might not have as many of those tiny warm roads, or the skin might be thicker or more bony, so the detective might get confused and not find the right warm feeling. So, yes, your forehead is still the best secret spot for the detective to check your warmth, even without hair!

title: Where do viruses go when they are quarantined, but not deleted?
text: Imagine your computer is like your toy box, full of all your favorite toys and drawings. A virus is like a tiny, invisible, super naughty monster that tries to mess up your toys or scribble on your drawings! When your computer's grown-up helper (that's the antivirus program) catches one of these naughty monsters, it doesn't always throw it in the trash right away. Instead, it puts the naughty monster in a special, super-duper strong timeout box! This box is like a little locked room inside your computer, all sealed off from your other toys. The virus can't jump out, can't play with your files, and can't make anything else sick. It just sits there, all by itself, until a grown-up decides if it should be thrown away for good, or if maybe it was a mistake and can come out (but that almost never happens with real naughty viruses!). So it's safe and can't cause trouble, but it's still there, just locked away!

title: Why will the sun set 15 minutes later in two weeks, but only rise 6 minutes earlier?
text: Okay, imagine our Earth is like a big spinning ball, and it's also going on a giant race around the sun, but it's a little bit tilted, like a toy top that

title: When you win a free game on a Pinball Machine, why it makes that loud popping sound?
text: When you play pinball and do super well, like getting a really high score or hitting special targets, the machine wants to give you a prize: another free game! To tell everyone how awesome you are and that you won, there's a special little hammer inside the machine, like a tiny drumstick. When you win, a secret helper tells that little hammer, 'BAM! Hit this metal plate super hard!' It hits the metal with a big 'POP!' sound so everyone can hear your victory and know you get to play again for free!

title: Why some drunks are mean and violent? What physiological/chemical change occurs in their body after they consume alcohol that makes them violent?
text:
Okay, imagine your brain has a super helpful boss that tells you to be kind, share your toys, and think before you do something silly or mean. This boss is really good at making sure you use your nice words and don't get too angry. Now, when grown-ups drink a special grown-up juice called alcohol, it's like that super helpful brain boss gets really, really sleepy and takes a long nap!

When the brain boss is sleeping, it's much harder for the grown-up to think clearly about what's nice or not nice. Their feelings, especially the grumpy or angry ones that are usually tucked away, can get super big and loud because there's no boss to tell them to quiet down. So, they might say mean things or push people, not because they're always like that, but because their brain's "think before you act" and "be kind" parts are taking a nap, and they can't control their big feelings or choices like they usually can. It's like their "stop and think" button is broken for a little while.

title: If the FDA (US) so strictly vets new drugs for safe use on humans, why then do TV adverts contain so many warnings against side effects?
text: Imagine the FDA is like a super careful grown-up who checks all the yummy snacks and foods before you can eat them. They make sure the food won't make you super sick and is safe for most kids to eat. But even if a snack is super safe and yummy, sometimes a few kids might be allergic to peanuts, or get a tiny tummy ache from too much sugar, right? So, the grown-ups who make the snack have to put *all* the little warnings on the box, like "might contain nuts" or "eat in moderation," just in case, even if most kids are perfectly fine. Medicines are kind of like that! The FDA makes sure they're mostly safe and work to make you feel better. But because every person's body is a little bit different, what helps one person might give another person a little hiccup or a tiny tummy ache. So, the grown-ups who make the medicine have to tell you *all* the possible little things that *might* happen, even if it's only to a few people, so everyone knows everything and can talk to their doctor grown-up if they're worried.

title: In video games, why killing people and violence is ok, but sex and nudity is still controversial?
text: Imagine you're playing with your toy superheroes, and they're having a big pretend fight! Pow! Wham! It's super fun, but no one actually gets hurt, right

title: How does electricity know not to go a route where it can't get back to the negative terminal?
text: Imagine electricity is like tiny little friends holding hands, and they want to go on an adventure! The battery is like their playground. They start on one side (the "go" side) and want to go on a big loop to get back to the other side (the "come back" side). Wires are like their special paths. If there's a path that just stops, like a dead end, the friends won't go down that path because they can't get back to the "come back" side! They only go on paths that make a full circle, so they can start their adventure, go around, and finish right back where they need to be. If the path is broken, they just can't move because they can't complete their trip.

title: Why haven't we switched from copper to fiber for all our video and data connections (hdmi,DisplayPort, USB, etc)?
text: Imagine you have two kinds of special strings to send messages and pictures, like from your toy computer to your toy TV. One string is made of copper, like a regular wire you might see. It's super easy to use, not too expensive, and it can even send a little bit of power, like a tiny battery, to make your toy TV light up! It's perfect for when your toy computer and TV are right next to each other. The other special string is

title: What exactly makes a mathematical argument 'rigorous'?
text: Imagine you're building a super tall tower with LEGOs! To make your math idea 'rigorous' means you have to be super, super careful about every single block you put down. You start with blocks you *know* are strong and stable (like things everyone agrees are true, like 1+1=2). Then, every new block you add has to click perfectly into the ones below it, following all the LEGO rules exactly. There can't be any wobbly bits or gaps where someone could push it over and say, "Hey, that part isn't strong!" If you build your idea like that, step by tiny step, so perfectly that nobody can find a single mistake or say, "How did you get from *that* block to *this* one?", then your tower is super strong and your math idea is 'rigorous'. It means you've shown *exactly* why it stands up, with no cheats or guesses!

title: Why all the companies are now investing in the United States; for example, Fiat?
text: Imagine you have a super cool toy factory, and you want to make lots and lots of toys for kids to buy. You could build your factory anywhere in the world, right? Well

title: Why do we have to learn "some" things in school even though we wouldn't need/use it in the future?
text: Imagine your brain is like a big, empty toy box when you start school. Every time you learn something new, like counting or drawing a circle, it's like putting a new, cool toy

title: What would deep space look like to the naked eye?
text: Okay, imagine you're floating super, super far away from Earth, past the moon and past the sun, in the biggest, emptiest place ever! It would be incredibly,

title: Before I try making one, what's so bad about a cheesecake cracking?
text: Imagine you draw a super pretty picture with all your favorite colors, and then it gets a big tear right in the middle. It's still your picture, and you can still look at it, but it doesn't look as smooth and perfect as it did before, right? A cheesecake cracking is kind of like that! It doesn't mean the cheesecake is yucky or broken inside, it still tastes super yummy! But for grown-ups who want to make it look extra special and super pretty, like a perfect smooth cake for a party, those cracks make it not look as smooth and perfect on top. So it's not "bad" bad like it's broken and you can't eat it, it's just not as "pretty" as they hoped it would be. But don't worry, even with cracks, it's still a delicious treat!

title: Why does one get a weird and somewhat unusual feeling when coming back to their home after a long trip ?
text: Imagine you've been playing at a friend's house all day, and it's a super fun house with different toys and smells and rules. When you come back to *your* house, it's still your house, and it's still super familiar and safe, but your brain just got used to all those *new* things at your friend's house! So, for a little bit, your brain is like, 'Whoa! This is my house, but it feels a little different because I just spent so much time somewhere else!' It's like when you wear new shoes for a while, and then you put your old comfy ones back on – they feel a little different for a second, even though they're your favorite. Your brain just needs a little time to remember all the tiny, cozy things about your home again, and then it feels perfectly normal and happy.

title: Why is there no "Metric vs Imperial" equivalent with how the world measures time?
text: Imagine when you measure how tall you are, some people use "feet and inches" and some people use "centimeters." They're both ways to measure how long something is, but they're different! Now, when we measure time, like how long until playtime or how long until your birthday, almost everyone in the whole wide world uses the *same* way to count it. We all agree that there are 60 tiny "seconds" in one "minute," and 60 "minutes" in one "hour," and 24 "hours" in one "day." It's like everyone decided a super long time ago to use the *same* ruler for time, so it's easy for everyone to understand each other when they talk about when things are happening! There isn't another big, different way that lots of people use every day to count time, so we don't have to pick between two different kinds.

title: Why are there so many different USB Cable connectors?
text: Imagine you have lots of different toys, right? A big toy truck needs a big garage door to drive in, but a tiny LEGO person just needs a little door. USB cables are like the keys and doors for your electronics! We have different ones because some devices are big, like a printer, and need a strong, chunky "door" to plug into so they can get lots of power and send lots of information. Other devices are super tiny, like a little earbud charger, and they need a very small "door" that doesn't take up much space. Also, as grown-ups learn how to make things faster and better, they invent new, fancier "keys" and "doors" that can do more cool stuff, like charge your tablet super fast or send movies really quickly. So, we have old ones because they were the best we had back then, and new ones because they're even better now, and everyone is trying to make one "magic key" that fits everything, but it takes a while for all the toys to get the same new door.

title: What causes some adults to be attracted to children?
text: You know how grown-ups often like other grown-ups, like how your mommy and daddy love each other? Well, sometimes, a grown-up's brain gets a little mixed up, and instead of feeling that special grown-up kind of liking for other grown-ups, their brain makes them feel it for children. It's like their feelings got pointed in the wrong direction by accident. But it's super important to know that even though their brain might feel that way, it's never, ever okay for a grown-up to act on those feelings or try to be close to children in that grown-up way. Grown-ups are supposed to keep children safe and happy, and only like other grown-ups in that special grown-up way.

title: Do viruses and bacteria have a colour?
text: No, not really! Viruses and bacteria are super, super, super tiny, like so tiny you can't even see them with your eyes, not even if you squint really hard! Because they are so incredibly small, they don't have a color that we can see, just like how a single tiny grain of sand is too small to really have a color you can point to. Scientists need special super-duper magnifying glasses and sometimes put colorful "paint" on them just so they can see them better, but that's like adding food coloring to clear water; the water itself didn't have that color.

title: How are qubits more efficient than normal bits?
text: Imagine you have a light switch. It can only be ON or OFF, right? That's like a normal computer bit. It can only be a '1' or a '0' – one thing at a time. Now, imagine a *magical* light switch. This switch can be ON, or OFF, *or even a little bit ON and a little bit OFF at the same time*! It's like it's holding both ideas until you really look at it. This magical switch is like a qubit! Because a qubit can hold many ideas (or

title: Where do currency symbols come from?
text: Imagine you have a special toy, and you want to draw a quick little picture for it so everyone knows it's *your* toy. That's kind of like currency symbols! A long, long time ago, when people started using money like shiny coins, they needed a fast way to write down how much money they had. So, they just started drawing little squiggles and shapes. Sometimes, they would take the first letter of the money's name, like how 'P' starts 'Pound', and they'd draw it super fast or make it fancy. Over many, many years, these quick drawings changed a little bit, like how your drawings might change if you draw the same thing every day. Other times, people just made up a brand new, cool shape, like a special secret club sign, and everyone agreed that shape would mean *that* kind of money. So, they're just old, quick drawings that everyone learned to understand!

title: How are trade agreements like NAFTA and TPP considered bad deals for the U.S. Economy?
text: Imagine you have a special toy-making factory, and you make really cool toys. Sometimes, grown-ups make big promises called "trade agreements" with other countries, which are like saying "let's all share our toys very easily, without any big fences or extra rules." The problem is, sometimes the other countries can make the same toys much, much cheaper than your factory can, maybe because their grown-up helpers don't need as much money, or their materials cost less. So, what happens? Lots of people start buying the cheaper toys from the other countries instead of yours. When that happens, your toy factory might not sell as many toys, which means the grown-ups who work there might not have jobs anymore, or they might have to earn less money because people aren't buying *

title: How are the brains of domesticated animals different from the brains of wild animals?
text: Okay, imagine two friends: one is a wild wolf who lives in the forest all by himself, and the other is your super friendly dog! The wolf's brain is like a super busy detective, always thinking about finding food, running away from dangers, and being very, very strong to survive all alone. So, its brain has lots of space and power for those "wild" jobs. But your dog? You help your dog find food, keep it safe, and play with it! So, your dog's brain doesn't need to be a detective for finding food or hiding from big dangers as much. Instead, it's really good at understanding your voice, being friendly, and learning tricks! Sometimes, because they don't need those "wild" parts as much, those parts of their brain can be a tiny bit smaller, and the parts that help them be good friends with people get really good. It's like their brains changed jobs a little bit!

title: Why does your body temperature increase when you're nauseous and or vomiting?
text: Imagine your body is like a super important castle, and sometimes tiny, invisible little bad guys called germs try to sneak in and make your tummy feel yucky. When you feel nauseous or throw up, it's like your body is ringing an alarm bell and trying really hard to kick those bad guys out! To help fight them better and make it harder for the bad guys to stay, your body sometimes turns up its own heat, just a little bit, like a warm oven. This warmth makes it harder for the yucky germs to live and helps your body feel stronger to get rid of them, so you can feel all better and play again super fast!

title: Why is it recommended that you replace your contact case every three months, instead of just disinfecting?
text: Okay, imagine your contact case is like a little house for your contact lenses. You can clean the house (that's disinfecting!), and it looks super clean to you. But just like a toy that gets tiny, tiny scratches you can't even see after playing with it a lot, your contact case also gets little tiny scratches over time. These scratches are like secret hiding spots for super tiny, invisible bad guys called germs! Even if you try really hard to clean them away, some of these germs are super good at hiding in those tiny spots. If they stay there, they can jump onto your contact lenses and then into your eyes, which can make your eyes feel owie or sick. So, every three months, we get a brand new, super smooth case. It's like giving your contacts a fresh, new, super-safe house with no hiding spots for the invisible bad guys, to make sure your eyes stay happy and healthy!

title: How do birds feet not freeze?
text: Imagine your body is like a warm house, and your feet are like little toes playing outside in the snow! Birds have a super clever trick. When their warm blood goes down to their feet, it gives a little hug to the cold blood coming back up. So, the warm blood gets a tiny bit cooler before it reaches their toes, and the cold blood coming back gets a tiny bit warmer before it goes back to their body. This keeps their feet just chilly enough so they don't get frozen like an ice cube, but not so warm that their whole body gets cold. Plus, their feet don't have much squishy water or fat in them, which are the things that freeze easily, so they're extra tough against the cold!

title: Why do pandas behave so seemingly different from other bears?
text: Imagine your tummy likes candy, apples, and chicken, but your friend's tummy *only* likes broccoli! That's kind of like pandas and other bears. Most bears are like your tummy; they eat lots of different yummy things like berries, fish, and even other animals. This food gives them lots of energy to run, climb, and play all day! But pandas are like your friend who only eats broccoli – except for them, it's bamboo. Bamboo isn't very yummy or strong, so it doesn't give them lots of energy. Because they don't get much energy, pandas are often very sleepy and slow. They spend almost all day just sitting and munching on bamboo, taking naps, and not doing big, energetic things like other bears do. So, they act super different because their food makes them feel super different!

title: How are hoarding and OCD related?
text:
Imagine your brain is like a little house with lots of rooms!

OCD is like when your brain gets a "sticky thought" stuck, like "Uh oh, did I turn off the light?" and then your brain makes you check the light switch ten times to feel okay, even if you know it's off. It's a worry that makes you do something over and over again.

Hoarding is when your brain makes it super, super hard to throw things away, even broken toys or old papers. It feels like throwing something away would make you very sad or that something bad might happen, so you keep *everything*, and your house gets very full.

For a long time, grown-ups thought hoarding was just a special kind of "sticky thought" from OCD. But now they know it's a little bit different. Sometimes, people with OCD might keep things because they worry they'll throw away something important by mistake. And people who hoard feel a very big sad feeling if they try to let go of things, like they're losing a part of themselves. So, they both make it hard to let go of stuff, but for slightly different reasons in their brains. They're like cousins – they have some things in common,

title: Would taking 2 hour naps throughout the day help as much as sleeping 8 hours at once ?
text: No, not really! Imagine your body and brain are like a big house that needs lots of cleaning and fixing every night. When you sleep for a long, long time, like 8

title: Why do we feel warmer when moving our body?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super cool toy robot, and the yummy food you eat is its special battery power! When you run and jump and play, your muscles are like little engines inside you that are working really, really hard to make you move. And just like when you rub your hands together super fast, they get warm, or when a toy car's motor spins, it gets a little toasty, your muscles get warm when they're working hard. All that hard work makes your whole body feel cozy and warm inside!

title: What is HDR on a camera?
text: Imagine you're trying to take a picture of your friend playing outside. The sun is super bright in the sky, but your friend is in the shade under a big tree, so it's a bit dark there. If your camera tries to make the sky look good, your friend might look like a dark blob! But if your camera tries to make your friend look good, the sky might look like a big, plain white sheet. HDR is like your camera taking *many* pictures super fast – one picture for the super bright sky, one picture for your friend in the shade, and maybe one in between. Then, it's like a clever little artist inside the camera takes all the best bits from each of those pictures and glues them together perfectly into *one* amazing picture. So in that one picture, both the super bright sky and your friend in the shade look just right, not too dark and not too bright!

title: How can flight simulators recreate situations that would be dangerous IRL?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper fancy pretend airplane, like a giant video game you can sit inside! It looks just like the real thing, with all the buttons and screens.

title: How far are we looking?
text: When you look at something, you're seeing light that bounced off it and came to your eyes! Light is super, super fast, but it still takes a tiny bit of time to travel. So, when you look at your toy right next to you, the light gets to your eyes almost instantly. But if you look at a big mountain far away, the light from that mountain takes a little longer to get to your eyes. It's like the light has to run a race! The further away something is, the longer its light has been running to get to you. So, when you look at the moon, you're seeing it how it looked a little tiny while ago, because that's how long its light took to get here. When you look at a star, it's even further away, so you're seeing it how it looked many, many years ago, because its light took that long to reach us! The very, very furthest things we can see with super big telescopes, their light has been traveling for almost as long as the whole universe has existed! So, we're looking back super, super far in time, like seeing a picture from when the universe was just a baby.

title: Assuming the giant-impact hypothesis is correct, is there an identifiable remnant of the crater from which the moon formed? Or is it so ancient that it's been long unidentifiable/covered?
text: Okay, imagine our Earth was a big, squishy ball of playdough a super, super long time ago. Another smaller ball of playdough, let's call it Theia, came and gave Earth the BIGGEST high-five ever! It wasn't just a tap, it was a giant, messy splat! Lots of playdough pieces flew off into space from both Earth and Theia, and those pieces eventually stuck together to make our Moon. Now, when you smash two playdough balls together, you don't really see a perfect, neat hole left behind, right? The whole thing gets squished and changed. Earth is like that! That giant high-five was so big it didn't just make a little dent; it melted a huge part of Earth and totally mixed everything up. Plus, Earth is like a giant, slow-moving lava lamp inside, and its outside skin (where we live!) is always moving around, changing, and getting new skin. Mountains grow, oceans move, and old parts get

title: How will automation not create another Great Depression?
text:
Imagine you have a favorite toy, but then you get a super cool new toy that does even more amazing things! When that happens, you don't just stop playing forever, right? You learn to play with the new toy, or you find new games to play. It's a bit like that with robots and jobs.

A long, long time ago, many grown-ups worried when new machines started doing jobs people used to do, like making clothes or driving cars instead of horses. They thought, "Oh no, what will everyone do now?" But guess what? Grown-ups found new jobs!

title: Why are people concerned about the use of antibiotics on farms?
text: Imagine boo-boo germs are like tiny little monsters that can make you or animals feel yucky. Antibiotics are like special superhero juice that helps make those monsters go away! Farmers sometimes give this superhero juice to their animal friends, like chickens and cows, to help them stay healthy and grow big, just like you take medicine when you're sick. But here's the tricky part: if we give the superhero juice too much, some of the boo-boo monsters learn how to hide from it and become super strong monsters! Then, if those super strong monsters accidentally get to us and make us sick, our usual superhero juice might not work anymore, and it's harder for us to get better. That's why grown-ups worry about using too much superhero juice on farms, because we want our superhero juice to always work when we really, really need it!

title: How does induced hypothermia extend the window of treatment for stroke and cardiac arrest?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super busy worker that needs lots of energy (which comes from your blood) to do its job. When someone has a stroke or their heart stops, it's like

title: How do we create saliva in our mouths and where does it come from?
text: You know how a little water fountain squirts out water? Well, your mouth has special little helpers, like tiny secret water fountains hiding in your cheeks and under your tongue! These helpers are like busy little factories that work all the time, making a special watery juice, and that juice is your saliva, or spit! It's made right there inside your mouth by these factories, and it helps make your food squishy so it's easier to swallow, and keeps your mouth from feeling all dry.

title: With regard to "Jailbroken" Amazon Firesticks, who would be the most likely to be sued/punished and who would initiate the charge?
text: Imagine your Firestick is like a special toy box Amazon gave you, and they said you can only put toys (apps) in it that you buy from *their* toy store.

title: Question about developing and genitals ?
text: Okay sweetie, remember how you were a tiny baby and now you're getting bigger and stronger every day? Well, your body is doing amazing things as it grows! You have special parts called genitals, and everyone has them! Boys have a penis, and girls have a vagina. These are like your super private parts, which means they are just for you, and only your mommy, daddy, or a doctor should ever see or touch them, just like your underwear covers them up. When you get much, much older, like a grown-up mommy or daddy, these special parts are what help grown-ups make their own babies someday. But for now, they're just an important part of your amazing growing body, and they also help you pee!

title: What makes your stomach hurt when you are hungry and what causes your stomach to growl?
text: Okay, imagine your tummy is like a little empty balloon or a special bag that loves to hold yummy food! When it's been empty for a while, it starts to get a bit sad and a little bit squished up, because it really, really wants some food to do its job. That squishy feeling is your tummy's way of sending a message to your brain, saying "Hey! I'm empty! Please send some snacks!" That's why it can feel a little bit ouchy or weird – it's just asking for food. And the growling? That's just your tummy's muscles, which are like little strong helpers, moving around and squeezing, getting ready for food to come in. There's also some air and special liquids inside your tummy, and when those muscles squeeze the air and liquids around in an empty space, it makes a funny rumbling sound, just like when you squeeze a half-empty water bottle and it makes a gurgle! It's your tummy making a noise to say, "I'm here and I'm ready to work! Food, please!"

title: How come one of the most common typing errors is to type a word twice in a row without noticing?
text: Imagine your brain is super-duper fast, like a race car! It knows all the words it wants to tell your fingers. Sometimes, your fingers are a tiny bit slower, like a sleepy snail. So your brain tells your fingers to type a word, but because it's so fast, it might think, "Hmm, did my fingers type that word yet? Maybe I should tell them again just in case!" And then your fingers type the same word again. When you read it back, your eyes are also very fast and sometimes they just zoom over the words, looking for the main ideas, like looking for your favorite toy in a big pile. A repeated word doesn't look like a broken toy, so your eyes might not even notice it's there twice because it still makes sense, even if it's a little bit extra!

title: Why do people usually sneeze two times in a row ?
text: Imagine your nose is like a little house, and sometimes tiny bits of tickly dust or a little hair sneak inside! Your nose doesn't like that, so it tries to push them out with a big "ACHOO!" But sometimes, that first big push isn't quite strong enough, or there's still a little bit of tickly stuff left behind. So, your nose takes another big breath and does a second "ACHOO!" just to make super sure all the yucky or tickly things are all gone and your nose is nice and clear again! It's like when you try to sweep all the crumbs off the floor – sometimes you need to sweep twice to get them all!

title: Does Chinese Herbal Medicine work?
text: That's a super good question! Chinese Herbal Medicine is like special drinks or powders made from plants, roots, and flowers that people in China have used for a very, very long time to help them feel better when they have a boo-boo or feel yucky. Imagine if your grandma knew which specific leaves could help your tummy ache! Sometimes, scientists have looked at these plants and found special ingredients inside them that really do help our bodies, just like how the medicine your doctor gives you helps you when you're sick. So for some things, yes, they can really work and make people feel better! But for other things, we don't always know *exactly* how they work, or if they work for everyone, and sometimes they don't help at all. It's super important that if you ever feel sick, a grown-up doctor who knows all about different kinds of medicine helps you pick what's best and safest for your body, okay?

title: how does microwave "crispy" cardboard work?
text: You know how a microwave heats up your food with invisible waves, but sometimes it makes things soft instead of crunchy? Well, that special crispy cardboard has a secret! Inside the cardboard, there's a super-duper thin, shiny sticker, almost like a tiny piece of metal. When the microwave's invisible waves hit this shiny sticker, it gets really, really hot, much hotter than the food itself! It's like having a tiny, secret frying pan right there inside the microwave. This super hot sticker then touches your food and cooks just the outside, making it dry out and get all crunchy and yummy, like a toasted marshmallow or a crispy chip, instead of just warm and soft. It's like a magic trick to make your food crispy!

title: How did Chris Pratt do the magic trick? (Link in description)
text: Chris Pratt is super good at playing pretend, just like when you play superheroes! He didn't *really* do magic, because real magic isn't actually real. What he did was super clever! He practiced a lot, like when you practice drawing your favorite animal, so his hands could move super fast and sneaky. And sometimes, while you were looking at one hand, his other hand was doing something else super quick, like hiding a coin or swapping a card, so you wouldn't even notice! It's like when you hide your toy behind your back and then make it pop out – it looks like magic, but you just hid it really well! Magicians are just very good at playing tricks on our eyes in a fun way.

title: When we feel drowsy, why do our eyes lose focus first before any other senses?
text: Imagine your brain is like the boss of your whole body, and it's getting super sleepy, like when you've played all day! Your eyes are like super-duper cameras that need to work really, really hard to make everything sharp and clear, changing all the time to focus on different things. That's a lot of work for a tired boss! Your other senses, like your ears just hearing sounds, or your nose just smelling things, don't need to work quite as hard or make so many quick changes to do their job. So, when the brain boss gets really tired, it tells the hardest workers (your eyes!) to take a little break first because it's too much effort, and that's why things start to get blurry and fuzzy before you feel sleepy all over!

title: Why do we physically shake our heads to help change our train of thought?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little train, and sometimes it gets stuck going around and around on the same track, thinking about the same thing over and over. When you shake your head, it's like giving that train a tiny, gentle jiggle! It's not magic, but that little shake helps your brain pay attention to something different for just a second, which can help it get unstuck from the old thought and make it a little easier to think about something new, like switching to a different train track. It's a trick your body does to help your brain take a little break and then think about other fun stuff!

title: Why do LCD screens become slow in a temp below 0?
text: Imagine your screen has tiny, tiny little doors inside, and behind those doors is a special kind of super-thick, clear paint, kind of like honey or syrup. When you watch a video or play a game, the screen tells this paint to quickly open and close the doors to make different pictures. But when it gets super, super cold, like when you put honey in the fridge, it gets really thick and gooey, right? It's much harder for it to pour or move. The same thing happens with the special paint in your screen! It gets so thick and slow that it takes a long, long time for it to move and change the pictures, so everything looks like it's dragging its feet, just like you might move slower when you're super cold and bundled up!

title: If our brain can basically hold 'unlimited' memories, why do we forget our younger years? Is it gone forever? Can we bring it back?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper amazing playroom, and memories are all your favorite toys. When you were a tiny baby, your playroom was still being built! The shelves weren't all up yet, and you didn't have all the right boxes to put your toys away neatly. You also didn't know many words then, and words help your brain sort and keep memories. So, even though you had lots of fun, your brain wasn't very good at putting those very early memories (toys) in a place where your grown-up self could easily find them later. They're not really hiding behind a secret door to be found again; it's more like they were little drawings that got smudged away before your brain learned how to keep them safe and clear. So, mostly, those exact baby memories are gone, not really like you can watch them again. Sometimes, if a grown-up tells you a story about when you were little, or shows you a picture, it might *feel* like you remember, but it's more like remembering the story they told you, not the actual moment from when you were a baby. Your brain just wasn't ready to save those kinds of memories in a way you can play with them again now.

title: Why do certain people's voices carry better than others?
text: Imagine your voice is like blowing bubbles! When you talk, you're blowing out little air wiggles that travel through the air to someone's ears. Some people blow really big, strong bubbles that can fly far, far away before they pop. Their voices make those big, strong air wiggles, so their sound travels a long way and is easy to hear, even from far away. Other people blow smaller, softer bubbles that don't go very far before they pop. Their voices make smaller, softer air wiggles, so their sound doesn't travel as far, and you have to be closer to hear them. It's all about how much air they push out and how their mouth and throat are shaped when they talk, making those sound wiggles big and strong or small and soft!

title: What would happen if someone who hasn't lost any blood got a standard blood transfusion (450 mL)?
text: Imagine your body is like a special cup that's already perfectly full with your yummy, important juice (that's your blood!). If you haven't spilled any juice and someone tries to pour *more* juice into your already full cup, what happens? It's like trying to pour more water into a glass that's already full to the brim. The extra juice wouldn't have anywhere to go, and it would make your heart, which is like a pump, have to work extra, extra hard to push all that extra liquid around, which can make it very tired. Also, your body already has exactly the right kind of juice, and if the new juice isn't exactly the same, your body might get confused and not like it very much, which can make you feel really, really sick. Since you didn't need the extra juice, it doesn't help you at all and can actually make your body feel not so good.

title: What's on the other side of your belly button?
text: Your belly button is like a little knot on the outside of your tummy, right? It's a special mark from when you were a tiny baby inside your mommy, and a tube gave you food and air! Now that tube is gone, and your belly button is just a scar. On the *other side*, inside your body, it's not a tunnel to somewhere else. It's just a strong, flat wall of muscle and skin, and right behind that are all your important insides, like your tummy that helps you eat, and your wiggly intestines! So, it's just protecting all the good stuff that's already in your belly.

title: when we get sick and lose our appetite, is it good or bad for us?
text: When you're sick, your body is like a superhero fighting bad germs! All its energy is super busy trying to make you feel better and chase those yucky germs away. Eating food takes a lot of work for your body to digest, and right now, your body wants to save all its power for fighting. So, it tells your tummy, "Hey, let's take a little break from big meals so I can focus on making you well!" It's actually a pretty smart trick your body does to help itself heal faster. It's okay if you don't feel like eating much for a little bit, as long as you drink lots of water to help your superhero body keep fighting. When you start to feel better, your tummy will tell you it's ready for food again!

title: Being near the ocean is cold during winter months. How did our ancestors keep warm out at sea during winter? (I.e: Vikings)
text: Imagine you're going outside when it's super cold, like a snowy day! What do you do? You put on lots of warm clothes, right? Like a big fluffy coat, a hat, and mittens! Well, long, long ago, people like the Vikings who went on big boats in the cold, cold ocean did something very similar. They wore many layers of clothes, just like you wear a shirt, then a sweater, then a jacket! They used special warm wool from sheep, which is super good at keeping you toasty even if it gets a little wet. They also had furry hats and big cloaks that were like super-duper blankets to wrap around themselves. They

title: How is glass made out of sand?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big pile of super special, tiny, tiny rocks – that's what sand really is! Now, we take that sand and put it into an oven that's way, way hotter than the one Mommy bakes cookies in – it's super, super hot! When the sand gets that hot, it doesn't burn, it actually melts and turns into a super gooey, shiny liquid, kind of like really thick, clear syrup or honey. Then, we carefully take that hot, gooey liquid and let it cool down. As it gets cool, it doesn't turn back into sandy grains. Instead, it gets hard and strong, and poof! It turns into the clear, see-through glass we use for windows so you can look outside, or for cups to drink your juice!

title: How and why did humans start smoking anything?
text: Imagine a very, very long time ago, people used to make campfires to keep warm and cook yummy food. Sometimes, they might have thrown certain leaves or plants into the fire, and they would make a special kind of smoke. Someone probably smelled it and thought, "Whoa, that's an interesting smell!" Maybe they noticed that when they breathed in a little bit of that smoke, it made them feel a bit calm or warm inside, like a cozy blanket. Grown-ups also started using it

title: How do game developers make different levels of difficulty in their games?
text: Okay, imagine playing with your toy cars! When it's super easy, maybe there's only one slow car to race against, and you get lots of boost buttons. But when it's harder, maybe there are five super fast cars, and you only get one boost button! Game makers do things like that. For an **easy game**, they might make the bad guys move really slow, or give you lots of magic cookies (like health power-ups!) to make you strong. The bad guys might not be very good at finding you. For a **hard game**, they make the bad guys super fast and strong, so you have to be extra careful! They might give you fewer cookies to make you strong, and the bad guys might be super smart at finding you and hitting you, making you think harder to win. It's like they change the rules a little bit to make it a bigger challenge!

title: Why do kids feel safe sleeping when they have a teddy bear with them? Is there a scientific explanation?
text: Imagine your teddy bear is like a super soft, super quiet friend who stays with you all night long! When you hug your bear, it feels warm and squishy, right? That feeling is like a big, cozy hug from someone you love, like Mommy or Daddy. Our brains, which are like the boss of our feelings, remember that warm, safe feeling. So, even when it's dark and quiet, having your teddy bear there makes your brain think, 'Oh good, my friend is here, I'm safe and sound!' It's like your bear is a little protector and a comfort blanket all rolled into one, always there to give you a snuggle and make sure you feel brave enough to sleep. It helps you feel less alone and more peaceful, just like when you're holding a grown-up's hand.

title: Why are people worried about using growth hormones on animals to be eaten?
text: Imagine animals are like little kids, and they grow bigger every day all by themselves. But sometimes, farmers give them special "grow-big" medicine, like a secret potion, to make them grow super-duper fast. People worry about this for two main reasons. First, growing too fast might not be good for the animals themselves, like if your legs grew so fast they started to hurt! Animals might get boo-boos or feel not-so-good. Second, some grown-ups worry that if the animals have too much of this "grow-big" medicine inside them, a tiny bit of it might get into *our* bodies when we eat their meat. And we don't want anything extra in our bodies that could make us feel funny or sick, or mess up how our own bodies are supposed to grow. So, grown-ups just want to be very careful to make sure our food is super safe and healthy for everyone.

title: What does it mean to be out of tune?
text: Imagine you and your best friend are singing your favorite song together. When you both sing the *exact* right notes, it sounds super pretty and happy, like your voices are holding hands and dancing together perfectly! That's called being "in tune." But sometimes, if one of you sings a tiny bit too high or a tiny bit too low, it sounds a little bit funny, like your voices are trying to dance but keep stepping on each other's toes, or like two different songs playing at the same time and not matching up. When sounds don't quite match up and make our ears feel a little "ouchy" or just "not happy," that's being "out of tune." It means the sounds aren't perfectly lining up to make that beautiful, happy sound they're supposed to make together, and it just feels a little bit... off!

title: Why do we automatically like some music but some has to 'grow' on us?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a little taste tester for yummy things! Some music is like a super sweet, easy-to-eat cookie you already know and love. Your brain tastes it and immediately says, "Yum! This is so happy and fun!" because it's easy to understand and makes your body want to dance right away, like a song with a simple, bouncy beat. But then, some music is like a new kind of food, maybe a funny-looking vegetable or something with lots of different flavors all mixed together. At first, your brain might go, "Hmm, what is this? I'm not sure I like it yet." It's new and a little different, so your brain needs a little time to try it a few times, to listen to all the different sounds

title: Why are professional video cameras so much larger than professional photography cameras?
text: Imagine a photography camera is like a special crayon that draws one really, really beautiful picture. A video camera is like a super-duper fast artist that draws *thousands* of little pictures *every single second* to make a cartoon movie! To draw so many pictures so fast, the video camera needs more brains (computers inside) and needs to work much, much harder. When things work hard, they get hot, so the video camera needs special fans to keep cool, like air conditioning, and those fans take up space. It also needs a giant backpack (storage) to hold all those thousands and thousands of pictures, not just one. And because movies need sound, the video camera often has special ears (microphones) to hear everything, which makes it bigger too. Plus, it needs a much bigger lunchbox (battery) because it's working so much harder for so much longer! All these extra parts to do its super-duper job make it bigger and a bit heavier, like a big toolbox full of cool things, compared to a little crayon box.

title: When DJ's are Djing, what are they doing with all those knobs, buttons, and their laptops?
text: Imagine a DJ is like a special music chef! They have a big cookbook (that's their **laptop**) filled with all their favorite songs. They look at it to pick just the

title: How does hand sanitizer work in making our hands feel clean when it seems that nothing "washes away" like it does with water?
text: Imagine your hands have tiny, invisible little monsters called germs on them that can make you sick. When you use water and soap, it's like giving your hands a big bath and washing all those monsters right down the drain! Hand sanitizer is different. It has a special, invisible super-hero juice inside called alcohol. This super-hero juice doesn't wash the monsters away; instead, it goes *poof!* and makes all those tiny monsters disappear right on your hands, like magic! They just stop being there. So, even though you don't see anything getting washed off, the super-hero juice made all the bad monsters go bye-bye, and that's why your hands feel all clean and fresh afterwards, and the super-hero juice just dries up and vanishes too!

title: What is the psychological reason for intentionally revisiting memories/photos/things/experiences that have hurt us?
text: Imagine you had a really big scrape on your knee, a boo-boo that hurt so much! Even after it starts to get better, sometimes you might gently touch it again, or look at the

title: why is it that long distance shooters tend to use bolt action rifles? Can a magazine fed semi-auto not do the same job?
text: Imagine you have two kinds of toy cars. One car is super simple: you push it once, and it rolls really, really straight. The other car has a little engine inside that makes it go by itself, and that engine has lots of tiny springs and gears that wiggle just a little bit when it's working. When grown-ups want to hit a tiny, tiny target super far away, like trying to hit a tiny apple on a tree way, way across the park, they want the super simple car that rolls perfectly straight. All those tiny wiggles in the car with the engine, even if they're super small, make it much harder to hit something so far away exactly right. So, the simple car (that's the bolt-action rifle) is better for hitting things super, super far away because it doesn't wiggle as much inside, making the shot go exactly where they want it.

title: thorium-fueled molten salt reactors...why can't they have a meltdown and why aren't we using them as a 'green' alternative energy?
text:
Imagine we have big magic machines that make electricity for our lights and toys.

**Why they can't have a meltdown:** Most big machines use special rocks in water. If the water goes

title: How can someone eat a certain food, like shellfish, their whole life but suddenly develop a life threatening allergy to it?
text: Imagine your body has tiny superhero guards inside, who are usually very good at knowing what's safe and what's not. They know that yummy foods like shellfish are your friends! They've seen them come into your tummy many

title: why is celery frequently served with chicken wings?
text: Imagine you're eating yummy chicken wings, and sometimes they're a little bit spicy, like a tiny warm hug in your mouth! Celery is like a cool, crunchy stick of water that helps calm down that warm feeling and makes your mouth feel fresh again. It's also super fun to crunch on something after eating soft wings, which makes your meal even more exciting and yummy!

title: When watching a plane propeller or a car's wheel speed up to the point it looks like it is still again why do the propellers or wheels appear to be in the same position to all observers?
text: Imagine your eyes are like a super-fast camera that takes tiny, tiny quick pictures, one after another! When a plane propeller or a car wheel spins super, super fast, sometimes it spins *just* the right speed that it plays a trick on your eyes. It's like this: your eye takes a picture, and the propeller is right here. Then, just as your eye gets ready to take the *next* picture, the propeller spins *exactly* one full circle (or two, or three!), so it's in the *exact same spot* again! Because it keeps showing up in the same place every time your eyes take a new "picture," your brain gets tricked into thinking it's not moving at all, even though it's spinning super fast! It's like if you had a flipbook, but every page had the exact same drawing – when you flip it, it looks still! Everyone sees it the same way because everyone's eyes and brains work pretty much the same way, taking those quick little pictures, so if your eyes are tricked, my eyes are tricked too!

title: How can peristaltic movements transport liquids?
text: Imagine you have a long, squishy tube, like a toothpaste tube, but it's full of juice instead of toothpaste! When you want the juice to come out, you don't just push the whole tube at once, right? Instead, you squeeze a little bit at the very back, and then you keep squeezing *just in front* of that first squeeze, moving your hand along the tube. Each squeeze pushes the juice a little further forward, like a wave pushing a toy boat, until it comes out the other end! That's exactly how your body, like your food pipe, moves your food and drinks along – it makes little squeezing waves that push everything forward!

title: How are surfers unharmed by "wiping out"?
text: Imagine you're playing in a giant bouncy castle, but instead of air, it's made of water! When surfers fall off their board, called "wiping out," they land in that super soft water, which is like a big, gentle cushion. It's much softer than falling on the hard ground, so it doesn't hurt. Also, surfers are very good at it, kind of like how you learn to roll when you tumble; they know how to fall safely and pop right back up out of the water super fast, like a cork! They also usually pick waves that aren't too, too big or scary for them, so it's mostly just a big splashy game.

title: Why do we wake up a minute or two before our alarm clock? Do humans have some sort of internal clock that makes us wake up at that time?
text: Imagine your body has a special, tiny clock inside, just for you! It's not a clock you can see with numbers, but it's super smart and learns your schedule. When you go to bed and wake up around the same time every day, your body's little clock starts to remember, "Oh, it's almost time for this little person to wake up!" So, sometimes, your body's smart clock is so good at remembering that it nudges you awake just a minute or two before your loud alarm clock even has a chance to shout. It's like your body is saying, "Psst, wakey wakey! I got this, you don't even need that noisy thing!" It's pretty cool how your body knows, isn't it?

title: What's that low rumbling sound you hear when you block your ears?
text: That rumbling sound you hear when you put your hands over your ears is actually your own body making little noises! When you block your ears, it's like closing the door to the outside world, so you can't hear the birds or your mommy talking as much. But inside your head, your heart is going 'thump-thump,' and your blood is flowing like a tiny river, and even your muscles are making tiny wiggles. Usually, the outside sounds are too loud, so you don't notice your body's sounds. But when you make it quiet by blocking your ears, suddenly you can hear all those little sounds from *inside* you, like a secret concert happening just for you!

title: Why do some kids force themselves to gag/puke when they cry?
text: When you cry super, super hard, like when you're really sad or really mad, your whole body gets very busy! You might take big, gasping breaths and your throat gets all tight. Sometimes, when your body is working so hard to cry and make those big noises, it accidentally makes your tummy feel a little funny, like it's trying to push something out. It's not that you mean to, but your body just gets so mixed up and overwhelmed from all the big feelings that it sometimes makes you gag or even throw up a little bit. It's just your body reacting really strongly because you're having such a big, big cry!

title: Why are women prone to extreme depression after giving birth?
text: Sometimes, after a mommy has a new baby, her body goes through super big changes inside, like when you're growing big and strong. These changes, especially some special helpers in her body called hormones, can sometimes make her brain feel very, very sad and tired, even if she loves her baby so much. It's like a cloud comes over her feelings, and it's hard to make it go away. It's not her fault, and it doesn't mean she's a bad mommy. It's a real thing that happens to some mommies, and grown-ups can help her feel happy and like herself again, just like when you feel sick and need medicine to get better.

title: How do video game hacks work?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing with your toy cars, and there's a special rule book that says, "This car can only go this fast," or "You only have three turns." A video game hack is like someone secretly peeking at that rule book *while you're playing* and quickly changing the numbers! So, if the book said your car goes "5" fast, they might change it to "500" fast. Or if it said you have "3" turns, they change it to "999" turns. The computer just reads the rule book, so if someone changed the numbers, it will follow the *new* numbers, making your car super speedy or giving you endless chances, even though that wasn't how the game was supposed to work originally. It's like tricking the game by changing its secret notes!

title: Why do we need the American military to be the size it is?
text: Imagine America is like a super big house, and our military is like a team of really strong, friendly grown-ups who are like big brothers and sisters. Their job is to keep everyone in our big house safe and sound, and make sure no one tries to be mean or break our stuff. Our house is so big, and we also have lots of friends (other countries) who live in houses all over the world. So, we need a really big team of these strong helpers, with lots of different special cars, boats, and planes, so they can be ready to help everywhere – whether it's right here in our house or far away helping our friends. Having a big and strong team means everyone feels safe, and if any bullies ever think about causing trouble, they know our helpers are ready and strong enough to protect us all!

title: Use of Never?
text: "Never" means something that just won't happen, not even a little bit, ever! It's like when Mommy says you can never have candy for every single meal, because that's not good for you. Or, you will never see a real, live dinosaur walking down your street to say hello, because they lived a super, super long time ago and aren't here anymore. It means it absolutely, positively won't happen, no matter what.

title: why are diamonds valuable?
text: Imagine you have a special toy that is super, super hard to find – like only a few kids in the whole wide world have one! And it's not just rare, but it's also super shiny and sparkly, like a tiny star you can hold in your hand, and it's super-duper strong, so strong it can scratch almost anything but it's really hard to scratch *it*. Because diamonds are so special, so pretty, so strong, and so hard to find deep in the ground, grown-ups think they are very, very valuable, like a super special treasure!

title: When they say the bullet matches the ballastic report for this gun, what is the key identifier?
text: Okay, imagine your favorite toy car has a special little scratch on its side. If you push that car through some soft play-doh, that special scratch will leave a matching mark in the play-doh, like a secret message! No other toy car would leave *that exact same scratch mark*. Guns are like that, but inside the long tube where the bullet shoots out, there are tiny, tiny rough spots and scratches, like the gun's own special 'fingerprint' that no other gun

title: How were languages first translated?
text: Imagine you meet a new friend who speaks totally different words than you! How would you understand them? Well, it started with people pointing to things! If you pointed to a yummy apple and said

title: When it is dark, why does it seem like things are easier to see in your peripheral vision versus looking at them straight on?
text: Okay, imagine your eyes have two different kinds of tiny, tiny light-catchers inside, like two teams of superheroes! One team loves bright lights and sees all the pretty colors and tiny details, like the sprinkles on your birthday cake. These color-loving superheroes mostly live right in the middle of your eye, where you look straight. The other team of superheroes is super good at seeing in the dark, like when you're looking for your teddy bear at night. They don't see colors very well, but they're awesome at seeing shapes and movement when it's gloomy. These dark-loving superheroes mostly live on the *sides* of your eye. So, when it's dark, your color-loving superheroes are taking a nap, but your dark-loving superheroes wake up! That's why, if you look *a little bit away* from something in the dark, you're letting those dark-loving superheroes on the sides of your eye do their best work, and it helps you see it better! But if you look straight at it, you're mostly asking the sleepy color superheroes to work, and they can't see as well in the dark.

title: How do huge animals like whales become washed ashore?
text: Imagine a giant, giant fishy friend, like a whale! Sometimes, these big friends might feel super sick, just like when you have a tummy ache or a cold, or maybe they got a boo-boo and can't swim very well. When they're not feeling strong, the big waves in the ocean, which are like the ocean's giant hands, can gently push them closer and closer to the sand until they get stuck on the beach. Other times, they might get a little lost, like when you can't find your way back from the park, or they might be chasing a yummy snack and swim too close to the shallow water without realizing it gets too tiny for them to turn around. And sometimes, the ocean water itself is just super strong and pushes them onto the land, and they can't swim away even if they try really hard.

title: Why are animals not always in heat?
text: Imagine you want to bake a super yummy cake! You need lots of eggs, flour, and sugar, and it takes a lot of work to mix everything and put it in the oven, right? You wouldn't want to bake a cake if you didn't have any eggs or if your kitchen was super messy! Animals are kind of like that. Being 'in heat' means their body is getting ready to make baby animals. Making baby animals takes a *lot* of energy and special things from their body. So, animals only get 'in heat' when it's the very best time, like when there's lots of yummy food to eat and the sun is warm. This way, if they have babies, there will be plenty of food for

title: Why do we find cockroaches so disgusting ?
text: Okay, imagine a little bug that's super fast and likes to hide in the dark, yucky places, like under the trash or in the cracks of the wall. They're often brownish and have wiggly feelers. Now, because they hang out in those dirty spots, they can accidentally carry tiny, invisible 'ickies' (like the stuff that makes you sick) on their little feet. If one of those speedy bugs then scurries across your yummy cookie or your clean toy, it might leave some of those 'ickies' behind. Plus, they can pop out of nowhere and surprise you, which can be a bit scary! So, our grown-up brains, and even your little brain, just know to say, 'Eww, keep that yucky thing away!' because it belongs in dirty places, not near us or our food, and we want to stay safe and clean.

title: What kind of damage can a separated ice shelf do?
text: Imagine a giant, flat piece of ice that's floating on the sea, like a very, very big ice cube. This big ice cube is super important because it's like a big wall or a stopper that holds back even more ice that's sitting on the land, like a giant mountain of snow! When this big floating ice cube breaks off and floats away, it's like someone took away the stopper. Then, the giant mountain of snow behind it can slide much, much faster into the ocean. When all that extra ice goes into the water, it makes the water level go up, just like when you put too many ice cubes in your juice and it overflows your cup! And if the ocean water goes up too much, it can go onto the land where people live, near the beach, and that's not very good because it can make things wet and messy.

title: Why do people piss their pants when they're afraid, as opposed to any other bodily discharge?
text: Imagine you're playing tag and a big, scary monster suddenly jumps out! Your body gets a super-duper alert, like a fire alarm going off inside you. It thinks, "Oh no! I need to be super fast to run away or be super strong to fight!" To be super fast and light, your body sometimes tries to get rid of anything extra that might slow it down, like the water (pee-pee!) in your tummy. It's like emptying your pockets so you can run faster without extra weight. Your body just lets go without asking you, because it's so busy trying to keep you safe! Other things, like poop, are a bit harder for your body to just let go of super fast like that, and things like snot or tears don't make you lighter to run away.

title: Why is it that computers get slower as time goes on, even when you factory reset it?
text: Imagine your computer is like a toy race car! When it's brand new, it zooms super-duper fast, right?
