But as time goes on, even if you clean it all up and make it shiny again (that's like a factory reset), two things happen. First, the little tiny parts inside the computer get a tiny bit older, just like your favorite toy car might not roll *quite* as smoothly after lots and lots of playing. Those parts just don't go as fast as they did when they were brand new. Second, the new games and programs people make are like super-duper big, fancy new race tracks that need a much, much faster car to drive on them. Your old computer was perfect for the old, smaller tracks, but it just can't keep up with the super-duper fast, big new ones, even after a good wash. So, even though it's clean, it's still an older car trying to do very new, very fast things, and it gets a little tired trying to keep up

title: How can we grow fruits and vegetables that are out of season?
text: Imagine fruits and veggies are like little kids who love to play outside when it's sunny and warm! When it's cold or snowy where you live, they can't grow outside. So, to get them anyway, we do two clever things: First, we build them a special, giant glass house called a greenhouse. It's like a sunny blanket that keeps them warm and cozy, even when it's cold outside, and we can even give them extra light with special lamps so they think it's summer! Second, we find places far, far away where it *is* sunny and warm, even when it's cold here. We grow the fruits and veggies there, and then they take a big trip on a truck or a boat or even an airplane to come to your store! So, we either make a summer house for them, or we get them from where it's already summer!

title: How can I think that two people look very much alike but someone else thinks that the same two people don't look alike at all?
text: Imagine you have two toys, like two teddy bears. You might think they look super alike because they both have soft fur and cute button eyes! But your friend might think they look totally different because one is big and one is small, or one is brown and one is white. Our brains are like that too! When we look at people's faces, our brains notice different things. Your brain might zoom in on their happy smiles or the color of their eyes and think 'Wow, so similar!' But your friend's brain might zoom in on the shape of their nose or how their hair curls and think 'Nope, totally different!' Neither of you is wrong, it's just that everyone's special brain decides what parts of a face are most important to notice. So you both see the same people, but your brains are like different detectives, looking for different clues!

title: Why does the tissue on the inside of your cheek heal/regenerate so quickly?
text: Imagine the inside of your cheek is like a very busy road where lots of yummy food travels and you talk all the time! Because it's so busy, it sometimes gets little bumps or scrapes. But don't worry! Your cheek is super-duper special because it has lots and lots of tiny, speedy repair workers, like little builders, living there. They are always ready with their tools and building blocks to fix any tiny owies super fast. They know they have to work extra quickly so you can keep eating your snacks and chatting with your friends without it hurting for long!

title: If espresso is essentially concentrated coffee why is it less acidic?
text: Imagine coffee has different kinds of yummy tastes inside, and some of them are a little bit sour, like when you taste a lemon. When we make regular coffee, the water stays with the coffee grounds for a long, long time, like a long bath. This long bath lets *all* the different tastes come out, including lots of the sour ones. But with espresso, it's like a super-duper quick shower for the coffee! The hot water rushes through so fast that it only has time to grab the really yummy, strong coffee flavors and not as much of the super sour stuff that takes longer to get out. So even though it's super strong and concentrated, it doesn't have as much of that sour taste because the sour bits didn't have enough time to jump into the water.

title: Why does your mouth water like crazy when you're nauseous?
text: You know how sometimes your tummy feels super yucky, like when you've eaten too much candy or you're feeling a bit sick? And then, all of a sudden, your mouth gets super wet, like a little waterfall inside? That's your body being super smart and trying to protect you! Inside your tummy, there's a strong, sour juice that helps squish your food so you can use its energy. If your body thinks that yucky juice might need to come back up, it makes lots and lots of extra spit (we call it saliva!). This extra spit is like a shield and a rinsing machine for your teeth. It helps wash away that strong, sour juice so it doesn't hurt your teeth, and it also helps make your throat feel a little better. It's your body's way of saying, 'Oops, just in case, let's get ready to protect those pearly whites!'"

title: Why don't mitochondria reproduce until they exhaust their host cells to death?
text: Imagine your body is like a big house, and inside your house are lots of tiny rooms, called cells. In each room, there are even tinier little helpers called mitochondria! These helpers are like little power factories, and their job is to make all the energy the room (cell) needs to play, grow, and do everything. Mitochondria are super good friends with the cell! They don't want to hurt the cell or make too many of themselves until the cell breaks. That would be like making so many toys in your room that you can't even walk anymore! No, no. The cell is the boss, and it tells the mitochondria when to make more energy or even when to make a few more little power factories if the cell is growing big or needs extra help. They work together perfectly, like a team, so the cell always has just enough energy and space, and everyone stays happy and healthy.

title: Why is everything so cheap in Thailand?
text: Imagine you have special play money, and people in Thailand have their own kind of play money, and their play money is just a little different from ours. So, when they buy yummy food or cool toys or even pay someone to help them, it doesn't cost them as much of their special play money as it would cost us our play money. Also, lots of things like yummy fruits grow easily there, and many people help make things, so it just doesn't cost as much to make or get things ready to sell. It's like if you have lots and lots of apples in your own garden, they wouldn't cost you much at all, right? That's kind of how it is there!

title: How does mold seemingly grow from out of no where and is mold safe to eat?
text: Mold is like super tiny, invisible seeds that float all around in the air, just like dust! When these tiny seeds land on yummy food that's a little bit wet and cozy, they wake up and start to grow into the fuzzy stuff you see. So it doesn't really come from nowhere, the tiny seeds were already there, just waiting for a good place to live and grow! And no, mold is usually not safe to eat, sweetie. Most kinds of mold can make your tummy feel very yucky and sick, so it's always best to throw away food that has mold on it. Leave the moldy food for the garbage can, not your mouth!

title: How we forget things that were "on the tip of my tongue," or was just said minutes or seconds ago? [Other]
text: Imagine your brain is like a super big playroom with tons of toys! When someone tells you something, it's like they give you a new toy to play with. Sometimes, when something is "

title: Why do certain foods (like cookies) go soft when they've been in the cupboard a while, but other foods like bread become hard?
text: Okay, imagine food is like a little sponge, and water is like tiny, invisible droplets floating in the air, or living inside the sponge. A yummy cookie, when it's new, is like a very dry sponge – it's super thirsty! The air around it often has tiny water droplets floating around. So, the dry cookie sponge quickly drinks up those invisible water droplets from the air, and when it drinks enough, it gets all soft and squishy. But bread is different! When

title: How come alcohol triggers hunger even though its caloric itself?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a little car, and food is the special fuel that makes it go and gives it power. Alcohol is like a *different kind* of fuel that your car can use, but it's a bit tricky. When you put alcohol fuel in, your car's engine gets super busy trying to clean it out and make it go away because it's not the usual good fuel. While your engine is super busy cleaning, it sometimes gets a little confused and makes your "fuel gauge" (which tells you how much good food fuel you have) drop down, even if you still have some. So your body thinks, "Uh oh! I'm running low on my *good fuel*! I need more right now!" And that makes you feel super hungry, even though you just put in some other kind of fuel. It's like your body wants the *right kind* of fuel to feel really strong and happy!

title: Why do we get sick more often, when it's cold outside?
text: Imagine there are tiny, invisible bad guys called germs that try to make us sick! When it's cold outside, we all like to stay inside our warm houses, right? And when lots of people are inside together, those sneaky little germs can jump from one person to another much, much easier, like playing tag! Also, when the air is super cold, your nose

title: What's the deal with Yellowstone?
text: Imagine a super-duper big park, like your backyard but millions of times bigger! In Yellowstone, the ground is like a giant sleepy oven because there's a super big, sleepy volcano deep, deep, deep underground. This sleepy volcano makes the ground super warm, so water shoots up into the sky like a giant sprinkler (we call those geysers, and there's one famous one called Old Faithful that always goes off on time!), and it makes pretty colorful puddles that are super hot, like bathwater that's too hot for a bath. Lots of amazing animals live there too, like big fluffy bison that look like furry cows, and sleepy bears, and speedy wolves. It's a special place that people wanted to keep safe and wild forever, so everyone can visit and see all the cool hot water and animals.

title: What is the difference between luminescence and fluorescence?
text:
Okay, imagine light is like a super cool magic trick!

**Luminescence** is like when something just makes its own light without getting hot, like a glow stick you crack and it just *glows*, or

title: Why would a train driver opening and closing the doors be less safe than the guard doing that?
text: Imagine you're driving a really long toy train from the very front. You can only really see what's right in front of your nose, right? It's super hard to see if your teddy bear is still trying to get on at the very back door! But if your grown-up is standing *next to* the train, they can see *all* the doors and *all* the people getting on and off, making sure everyone is safe and sound before the doors close. So, the guard is like your grown-up who can see the whole long train and make sure no one gets their fingers caught or is still running to get on when the doors close, which makes it much safer!

title: Why do some people struggle with weight loss/gain their whole lives while others are thin without effort?
text: Imagine your body is like a special little engine! Some engines are super speedy and burn through their fuel (which is like the food we eat for energy!) really, really fast, even when

title: how does texture affect the tastiness of food?
text: Imagine your yummy food is like a toy! Sometimes, you like a toy because it's soft and cuddly, right? Other times, you like a toy because it's hard and you can build with it. Food is kind of the same! Texture is how food feels in your mouth – is it crunchy like a chip that goes "CRUNCH!"? Is it smooth and melty like ice cream? Is it squishy like a marshmallow? When food feels just right in your mouth, like a crunchy apple or a smooth banana, it makes your brain think it's extra fun and yummy! But if something is supposed to be crunchy but it's all soft and soggy, or if it's supposed to be smooth but it has bumpy lumps, it can make your brain go "Ew, that's not what I expected!" and even if the taste is okay, the weird feeling can make it not as tasty. So, how food feels is a super important part of why you love some foods and maybe don't like others, just like how you like to play with different kinds of toys!

title: Why do deep-sea fish look so eldritch physiologically? Is it just because "regular" fish is what we've been trained to think of as normal?
text:
Okay, imagine you live in a super, super dark room, way, way down deep under your bed, where it's always nighttime and a giant invisible hand is always pushing on you! You wouldn't need pretty colors because no one can see them, right? And you'd need super big hands to grab any snack that floats by, because food is hard to find.

Deep-sea fish live in a place just like that! It's so dark they don't need bright colors or normal eyes, so they might have tiny eyes or even lights on their heads to help them see in the dark. The water pushes on them *so* hard, their bodies are built to be squishy so they don't get squashed flat, or they have super strong bones. And because food is scarce, they often have huge mouths with long, pointy teeth to catch anything they can! The fish we usually see, like Nemo, live up high where the sun shines and there's lots of food and no giant squishy hand. So their bodies are made for *that* world. It's like how a dog looks normal to us because we see dogs all the time, but if you only ever

title: Is it possible to shrink forever?
text: No, not really! Imagine you have a big cookie. You can break it into smaller pieces, right? And you can break those smaller pieces into even tinier crumbs. But eventually, you'll get to the tiniest, tiniest crumb that you just can't break anymore, because it's already the smallest it can be! Everything in the world, even you and me, is made of super-duper tiny building blocks, like those crumbs. You can get smaller and smaller, like breaking the cookie, but you can't shrink *forever* because you'd eventually reach those very smallest building blocks, and you can't break them into anything smaller than they already are!

title: Why are hackers focusing on the DNC rather than other organizations like the RNC?
text: Imagine the DNC and RNC are like two big treasure chests, filled with important papers and plans. Hackers are like sneaky pirates who want to peek inside those chests to find secrets. Sometimes, one chest might look like it has more *new* and exciting treasures, or maybe its lock isn't as strong right then, making it easier for the pirates to open. When the DNC was super busy making big plans for the country (like picking a team captain), they had lots of fresh secrets that looked very interesting to the pirates. It's not that the other chest (RNC) doesn't have treasures, but at that moment,

title: What would happen to the Earth's climate, if all the ice melted?
text: Okay, imagine Earth has super-duper giant ice cubes, like the biggest ones you've ever seen, up at the very top and bottom and on big mountains! If all those ice cubes melted, all that water would have to go somewhere. It would flow into the ocean, making the ocean get much, much bigger and higher, like when you fill your bathtub too much and the water spills out! This means some of the land where people live, especially near the beach, would get covered by water. Also, because all that cold ice is gone, the whole Earth would get much, much warmer, like a really hot summer day that never ends! This would make the weather go a bit silly; some places would get super hot, some would get too much rain, and some would have big, wild storms. And animals like polar bears, who live on the ice, would lose their homes and have nowhere to go. It would be a very different, much warmer, and wetter world.

title: per the post about diarrhea being the top killer during the civil war.. how can bad Diarrhea kill you?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool water balloon, and that water inside helps everything work – your heart beats, your brain thinks, your muscles move! When you have really bad diarrhea, it's like someone poked a bunch of tiny holes in your water balloon, and all that important water and special "juices" are leaking out super fast. If you keep losing too much water and can't put enough back in, your body starts to get very, very tired, like a plant that's not getting enough water and starts to droop. Eventually, if you lose too much and can't get more, your body just gets too weak and can't keep going anymore. Back in the old days, they didn't have special drinks or magic shots to put the water back in quickly, so it was much harder for people to get better and their bodies just gave up.

title: Why does cold water feel more hydrating than hot - or even room temperature water?
text: Imagine your body is like a little house, and sometimes it gets a bit warm inside, especially when you're running and playing! When you drink cold water, it's like opening a window and letting a super cool breeze come right in. Your mouth and tummy feel that "whoosh" of coldness, and it makes your body say, "Yay! This is making me feel better and cooler right now!" That instant cool feeling makes you *think* it's helping you more and faster. Warm or room temperature water is still super good for you and fills up your "water tank" inside just the same, but it doesn't give you that big, exciting "brrr, that's nice!" cool feeling right away, so it doesn't make your brain feel quite as happy and refreshed in that very first moment. Both waters are good, but the cold one just feels extra special because it's so cool!

title: how do the new robot prosthetic limbs work?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a very special toy arm or leg. The old ones were just like a puppet, and you had to pull strings or push it to make it move. But the new robot arms and legs are super, super smart! They have tiny little computers inside, like a little brain, and tiny little motors that help them move. When you think about moving your hand, or wiggling your fingers, your real muscles in

title: How does Impeachment actually work in the US?
text: Okay, imagine the President is like the grown-up leader of our whole country, kind of like the captain of a very important team. If a lot of other grown-ups think the President did something really, really bad, like breaking important

title: How does a cancer cell come to be and how can it sometimes be too aggressive for treatment like chemo?
text: Imagine your body is like a giant house made of tiny, tiny LEGO bricks called cells. Most of the time, these bricks know exactly when to make new bricks to fix things, like when you get a scrape. They have special rules about when to grow and when to stop. But sometimes, one little brick forgets all the rules! It starts making copies of itself super fast, without stopping, even when it shouldn't. These are like naughty, broken bricks that just keep building and building, and that's how a cancer cell comes to be. Now, doctors have special medicine called chemo, which is like a superhero trying to find and stop these naughty bricks from growing. But sometimes, these naughty bricks are just too fast and too many! They multiply so quickly that the

title: Why do people still smell themselves even they knew is gonna smell terrible?
text: You know how sometimes you see a really muddy puddle, and you know it's going to be squishy and yucky, but you still want to poke it with a stick just to see *how* squishy it is? Or maybe you have a toy that got a little bit dirty, and you know it's dirty, but you just want to give it a quick little look to see *how* dirty it is? Smelling ourselves, even when we think it might be stinky, is kind of like that! Our grown-up brains are just being a little bit curious. We want to take a super quick sniffy-sniff, like a tiny detective, just to see *how* stinky it is

title: What happens to muscle when you don't work out for a long period of six months or more?
text: Imagine your muscles are like little superhero friends living inside your body! When you run, jump, or play, you're giving them lots of exciting jobs to do, and they get super strong and big, like they're training. But if you stop giving them jobs for a very, very long time, like half a year or more, they start to get a little bit bored and sleepy. They don't need to be super strong anymore because they're not doing big jobs, so they decide to take a long nap and shrink down a tiny bit. They become not as big and not as mighty as they used to be, just like how a toy you don't play with for a long time might get a little dusty and forgotten. But don't worry, you can always wake them up again with more play!

title: Why do cities and towns "stagger" stoplights so that no matter your timing you'll always be caught at a light?
text: Imagine all the cars are like little race cars, and the stoplights are like big, friendly traffic cops telling everyone when it's their turn to go! The lights don't

title: Why do people say things like 'Uh' and 'Um' while speaking?
text: Imagine your brain is like a tiny little helper trying to find the perfect toy in a big toy box. Sometimes it takes a second to find just the right one! When we say "uh" or "um," it's like our mouth is just taking a quick little breath or a tiny pause, telling everyone, "Hold on a second, my brain is still looking for the next word!" It gives our brain a super quick moment to think about what to say next, so we don't just stop talking completely, and everyone knows we're not finished yet.

title: Why can't my front windshield have those defroster lines my rear window has that defrost the rear window really quickly?
text: Those squiggly lines on your back window are like tiny, warm helpers that get hot really fast to melt away the cold yucky fog or ice so you can see out the back! But on the front window, where you and Daddy need to look *all the time* to drive safely, those lines would be like trying to look through a spiderweb and would get in the way of seeing the road clearly, which is super important. Instead, your car has a special fan that blows warm, toasty air right onto the front window, like a warm breath that slowly melts the yucky stuff away so you can see everything perfectly! It takes a little longer, but it keeps your view nice and clear, which is the most important thing for driving.

title: What is that pain you get sometimes in your head that feels like something popped and it feels kind of hot for a bit?
text: Imagine your head has lots and lots of tiny, tiny wires and super small muscles, like the ones that help you wiggle your fingers. Sometimes, if one of those tiny wires or muscles gets a little bit tired or grumpy really fast, it can make a quick 'ouch!' feeling. That quick 'ouch!' can feel like a little pop, and because your body is working hard to fix it, it might feel a little warm, like when you run really fast and your cheeks get warm. But don't worry, your body is super good at making those little grumpy spots feel better really quickly, so the feeling goes away!

title: What are the practical living, and political differences, between the USSR and post USSR Russia?
text:
Imagine two big, big playgrounds where lots of kids live, one is the old playground (USSR) and one is the new playground (Russia after USSR).

In the **old playground (USSR)**, there was one very big grown-up (the government) who decided everything for all the kids. They decided what toys everyone played with, what food everyone ate, and what clothes everyone wore. Sometimes, there weren't enough of the fun toys or yummy snacks because the big grown-up decided everything, and people couldn't easily choose what they wanted or even open their own little lemonade stand. For who was

title: How does a mechanical keyboard improve typing speed?
text: Okay, imagine your regular keyboard is like pushing down on a big soft pillow – you have to push it down quite a lot for it to know you've pressed it. But a mechanical keyboard is like each letter button has its own tiny, happy spring underneath! When you push a button, you feel a little bump or hear a little click *right away*, like a tiny "boing!" This means your fingers know they've pressed it super fast, and they don

title: Why do some animal groups, such as birds and mammals, care for their young, while others do not?
text: Okay, imagine some baby animals are like super tiny little seedlings that need lots and lots of help from their mommy and daddy to grow big and strong. Birds and mammals, like us and puppies and kittens, have babies that are born very, very little! They can't find their own food, or keep warm, or run away from big scary things. So, their mommy and daddy animals stay with them for a long time, bringing them yummy food, keeping them safe and warm, and teaching them everything they need to know to grow up. It's like they need lots of lessons

title: Do people who sing off key hear themselves singing on key? Do they hear other off key singing as on key?
text:
Imagine music is like painting with colors. When you sing 'on key,' it's like painting a bright red apple with a red crayon – it looks just right!

When someone

title: Why do females have higher voices than males?
text: Okay, imagine you have two tiny rubber bands, like the ones you use for your hair, inside your throat! These are called your vocal cords, and they wiggle super-duper fast when you talk or sing, making sounds. Now, girls usually have smaller and thinner rubber bands than boys. Think about a tiny little bell – it makes a high, happy 'ding!' sound, right? But a big, heavy bell makes a low, rumbling 'dong!' sound. It's kind of like that with our voices! Because girls' tiny strings are usually smaller and thinner, they wiggle faster and make higher sounds. Boys' strings are usually bigger and thicker, so they wiggle slower and make lower sounds. That's

title: How does our ear detect the sound vertical location ?
text: Imagine your ears are like special little funnels with bumpy insides! When a sound wiggle (that's what sound is!) comes from *up high*, it bumps and bounces off the top part of your ear funnel in a special way before it goes inside. But if the sound wiggle comes from *down low*, it bumps and bounces off the bottom part of your ear funnel in a different special way. Your super-smart brain has learned what these different kinds of bumps and bounces mean! It's like your brain knows, "Aha! That kind of bounce means the sound came from way up there!" or "Oh, that other kind of bounce means it came from way down here!" So, your ear's funny shape helps your brain figure out if a sound is coming from above your head or below your feet, just by how the sound bounces around inside it.

title: Have Any Technologies Peaked?
text: That's a super tricky question, little buddy! Most grown-up toys (technologies) are always trying to get better, like your favorite building blocks getting new shapes or your toy car getting faster. It's like they're always climbing a hill, and there's usually a new peak to reach. But some things are already *really* good at what they do, almost perfect! Think about a spoon. Can a spoon get much better at scooping up yogurt? Not really, it's pretty perfect for that job, right? Or a pencil! It helps you draw pictures, and it's been

title: Why do certain chemical reactions take place almost instantly (ex. Li +H20), while others (ex. Fe+02) take place slowly and gradually?
text:
Okay, imagine some toys are super, super, *super* eager to play with other toys! Like, they just *can't wait* to hold hands and make a new game. So, the moment they even get a tiny bit close, *poof!* They instantly jump together and start playing because they are so excited and want to change right away. That's like the super fast reactions, where the chemicals are very "eager" to mix.

But other toys are a bit lazy, or maybe they just don't feel like playing right away. They need a lot of convincing, or maybe they just slowly, slowly start playing over a long, long time, like building a LEGO castle one block at a time. They don't jump up right away. That's like the slow reactions, where the chemicals aren't as "eager" and take their sweet time to change. So, it's all about how eager and ready the chemicals are to play and change!

title: What's the difference between having a heater on 72 degrees and having an air conditioner on 72 degrees?
text: Imagine your room is a little chilly, like when you just wake up! When you turn on the heater to 72 degrees, it's like putting a big, warm blanket over your room and blowing warm air until it feels super cozy and warm, all the way up to 72. Now, imagine your room is super hot, like after running around outside in the sun! When you turn on the air conditioner to 72 degrees, it's like getting a big, cold drink and blowing cool air until your room feels just right and cool, all the way down to 72. So, the heater makes a cold room warmer *to* 72, and the air conditioner makes a hot room colder *to* 72 – they both want to get to the same comfy number, but one starts cold and adds warmth, and the other starts hot and takes coolness away!

title: When a phone dies how does it still have enough power to tell me it is dead?
text: Imagine your phone is like a toy car that needs batteries to drive. When the batteries are almost all gone, the car can't zoom around and play big games anymore. But sometimes, there's just a tiny, tiny bit of power left, like a super small spark! That little spark is just enough energy to light up a tiny picture on the screen that says "I'm tired!" It's like your phone saying "Phew, I need to rest and get some more energy from my charger!" Showing that little picture doesn't need much power at all, so it can do that even when it's too tired for anything else.

title: How do search engines know how long someone spends on your site?
text: Imagine a website is like a fun playground. When you click to go to a playground, it's like you've just walked through the gate. The playground owner (that's the person who made the website!) has little invisible helpers, like tiny friendly robots, hidden all around. When you come in, one robot whispers, "Someone just arrived!" And when you leave the playground, another robot whispers, "They just left!" These robots send all their whispers to the playground owner's big computer, which then knows how long you stayed to play. Sometimes, the playground owner shares this kind of information with a helpful friend, like a search engine, so the search engine can understand which playgrounds are super fun and keep kids playing for a long time. It's not magic, just clever robots making notes!

title: How is it possible for a sail-powered boat to travel against--or, for that matter, faster than--the wind?
text:
Okay, imagine the wind is like a big, invisible hand trying to push your boat.

First, **going against the wind** is tricky, right? If the hand pushes straight

title: Why does the sound of pouring water change when getting closer to the top of a cup or bottle?
text: Okay, imagine the cup is like a little house for the air inside it! When you first start pouring water, the cup is mostly empty, so there's lots and lots of air in its big house. When the water splashes in, this big amount of air wiggles slowly and makes a low, deep sound, like a big sleepy bear. But as you pour more and more water, the water takes up more space in the house, and the air gets squished into a smaller and smaller room! When the air has less space, it has to wiggle much, much faster. This super fast wiggling air makes a higher, squeakier sound, like a tiny mouse squeaking! So, the sound changes because the air inside the cup has less and less room to wiggle around.

title: How come our body can absorb protein from food like cooked chicken, shouldn't they denature?
text: Imagine your protein is like a big, fancy LEGO creation! When you cook chicken, it's like taking that big LEGO creation and gently pulling it apart a little bit, so it's not a perfect shape anymore – it's a bit "untangled" or "denatured." But guess what? That's actually super helpful! When this slightly untangled LEGO creation goes into your tummy, your tummy has special juices (like a mild acid) and tiny little "LEGO dismantlers" (we call them enzymes). These dismantlers love to break down the untangled LEGOs into super tiny, individual LEGO bricks. Your body can't use the big, fancy LEGO creation as it is, but it can easily pick up and use all those tiny individual LEGO bricks to build new things, like strong muscles or helping you run and play! So, cooking just makes it easier for your tummy to get all those good building blocks for you.

title: Why isn't body language taught like any other language or skill? It's used everyday by everyone in one way or another, but it seems like it's ignored as far as a skill worth developing in school.
text: Okay, imagine when you're super happy, you smile, right? And when you're sleepy, maybe you yawn. Nobody had to teach you how to do that, you just kind of *know* it, and you learned by watching everyone else around you since you were a tiny baby! Body language is like that – it's a natural way our bodies talk, like a secret language everyone already understands without needing a special book or a teacher to give us homework. Schools usually teach us things like ABCs and 123s because those are like special rules we *do* need to learn from a book to read and count. But our bodies already know how to talk in their own special way, like a feeling, so we just pick it up by living and playing and watching people every single day.

title: How did Reddit get so popular? Who were the first group of people to find Reddit, and how did they come across it?
text: Imagine Reddit is like a super big sandbox or a giant show-and-tell! It got super popular because lots and lots of people found something they loved there. It's like if you brought your favorite toy to show, and then your friend brought theirs, and then everyone started bringing their favorite things – stories, funny pictures, cool facts, or even asking questions. Everyone could vote on what they liked best, like giving a thumbs up, and the best stuff got seen by more people. So, it became a really fun place where you could find friends who liked the same things as you, whether it was dinosaurs, drawing, or silly jokes! The very first people who found Reddit were like the first kids to discover a brand new playground. They were mostly grown-ups who loved computers and exploring new things on the internet, almost like internet adventurers! The people who made Reddit told their friends, and those friends told their friends, and they thought it was a super neat way to share cool links and stories they found online and talk about them. So, they were like the first members of a cool secret club, and they helped it grow into the giant fun place it is today!

title: Why is taking an aspirin before the surgery harmful?
text: Imagine your body is like a superhero with special powers to fix boo-boos! When you get a little cut, your body sends tiny little helpers, like sticky glue, to quickly stop the blood and make a scab. But aspirin is like a trickster that makes your body's sticky glue not work very well. When doctors do surgery, they have to make little boo-boos to fix things inside. If you take aspirin before surgery, your body's sticky glue won't be able to stop the bleeding as fast as it should, and that means you might bleed too much. That makes it harder and not as safe for the doctors to do their important work, so they always tell you to stop taking aspirin so your body's helpers are super ready!

title: Why can cameras record 4K-25fps, FHD-50fps but not 4K-50fps or more?
text: Imagine your camera is like a super-fast drawer! When it draws a super-duper big picture with lots and lots of tiny details, that's like 4K. It takes a long, long time and lots of crayons to draw just one of those super big pictures, so the artist can only draw maybe 25 of them in one second. Now, if the artist draws a smaller picture, with fewer details, that's like FHD. It's much quicker to draw each one! So, the artist can draw many, many more, like 50 of those smaller pictures in one second. Trying to draw those super-duper big pictures (4K) super, super fast (50 times in one second) is just too much work for the little artist's hands and brain! It would get super tired and can't keep up, so it just can't draw that many big pictures that fast. It's either big pictures slowly, or smaller pictures quickly!

title: Why Do We Get a Lump in Our Throats Before We Cry?
text: When you're super, super sad and feel like you're about to cry, your body gets really busy inside! In your throat, you have special muscles that help you swallow your food and also help you breathe. When you have big feelings, like being very sad, these muscles get a little bit tight and tense, kind of like when you make a fist with your hand. Your body also wants to take bigger, shaky breaths when you're upset. So, these muscles are trying to do two things at once: stay open for breathing and also get ready for all those big feelings. Because they're trying so hard and getting a little bit squeezed, it feels like there's a little ball or lump stuck right there, but

title: Why are people happy that Obama is finishing up as president? I always thought he was the best thing that happened to America. (I'm Irish, don't know much about politics in the us)
text: Okay, imagine America is like a really big school bus, and President Obama was the driver for a very, very long time, like eight whole years! You thought he was the best driver, and lots of other people thought so too! They liked where he drove the bus and how he kept everyone safe and happy. But even if someone is a super good bus driver, after a long time, some people might want a new driver. Maybe they want the bus to go on a different road, or they think a new driver will pick different songs to listen to, or they just want someone new to try being the driver for a while. So, when President Obama's time was finishing, some people were happy because it meant a new person would get to drive the bus, and they hoped this new driver would do things they liked even more. It's not that Obama was bad, it's just that people have different ideas about who should drive the bus next!

title: What causes the weird taste when you burn your tongue?
text: When you burn your tongue, it's like your little taste helpers, called taste buds, get a big ouchie! Imagine if your favorite crayons got too hot and couldn't draw the right colors anymore. Your taste buds are usually super good at telling you if something is yummy and sweet, or sour, or salty. But when they get burned, they get a little bit sad and confused. They can't do their job properly because they're busy healing. So, when you try to eat something, your confused taste buds send a mixed-up message to your brain, making the food taste all weird and sometimes a little bit yucky, even if it's usually delicious! Don't worry, they usually get better after a little while and can taste yummy things again!

title: why are good shows like firefly and futurama cancelled, while there are tons bad shows running on so many networks ?
text: Imagine your favorite toy, like a super cool spaceship (that's Firefly!) or a funny robot (that's Futurama!). You love playing with it all the time! But the grown-ups who make the TV shows are like the grown-ups who own a big toy store. They need to sell lots and lots of toys to make enough money to buy new ones and keep the store open. They look at which toys *the most* kids are buying and playing with, not just *your* favorite. So, even if *you* think your spaceship is the best toy ever, if not enough *other* kids are buying it or watching it, the toy store might say, "Oops, not enough people are watching this one, so we can't make any more because it costs a lot of grown-up money!" They'll keep making the toys (or shows) that lots and lots of kids (or grown-ups) are buying or watching, even if *you* don't think those toys are as fun, because those are the ones that help the store make enough money to stay open. So, it's all about how many people watch, not just if *you* think it's good!

title: What is the downside to taking out lots of loans, or credit cards and declaring bankruptcy? (UK)
text: Imagine you really, really want lots of cool toys, so you ask all your friends to lend you their best ones, promising you'll give them back soon, plus maybe a little sweetie for letting you borrow them. But then you have *so many* toys, and you can't remember who gave you what, and you just can't give them all back! Saying you can't give them back is kind of like declaring bankruptcy. The big downside is that your friends will be very sad and upset, and they won't trust you anymore. For a very long time, if you ask to borrow a toy again, or if you want to get a new big toy like a bicycle or even a house when you're a grown-up, no one

title: How do viruses and colds form and where do they come from?
text: Imagine there are super, super tiny, invisible little bugs, so small you can't even see them with your eyes! These little bugs are called viruses, and they don't just "form" out of nowhere like magic; they are already out in the world, like tiny little seeds floating around. When someone who has these tiny cold bugs inside them coughs or sneezes, the bugs fly out into the air, like little invisible sprinkles! If those sprinkles land on you, or you touch something they landed on and then touch your nose or mouth, those sneaky little bugs get inside your body. Once they're inside, they're like tiny explorers who want to make lots and lots of baby bugs, and that's what makes you feel yucky and get a cold! So, colds come from these invisible virus bugs, and they usually come from other people who already have them and accidentally share them when they cough or sneeze.

title: Why do some shows have "and ACTOR as CHARACTER" in their opening sequence, while all other actors are named without character?
text: Imagine you're playing with all your friends, and you call out their names, like "Here's Sarah, here's Tom!" But then, if your very best friend or a grown-up who's super important for the game comes, you might say, "And here's Mommy as the super boss!" Shows do that when an actor and their character are extra special or super important in the story, like they're the main person everyone talks about, or a really famous grown-up, or maybe they just want you to remember them extra well because they're listed at the very end. It's like putting a little

title: What are "steel cut" oats/oatmeal and what makes them (apparently) preferable?
text: Okay, imagine an oat is like a whole, tiny little bean. Most oatmeal you might eat, like the quick kind, is made from those beans that got squished super flat, like a pancake! But "steel-cut" oats are different: they just take that whole little bean and chop it into tiny pieces, like when mommy cuts your sandwich into small squares for you. They use

title: Why do we usually put hills or foliage on roundabouts, obscuring the view of other vehicles?
text: Imagine you're playing a game where you have to walk in a big circle. If you can see super far ahead, you might want to run really fast! But if there's a big bush or a little hill right in front of you, you'd slow down to see what's coming, right? It's kind of like that for grown-ups driving cars in those big circles called roundabouts! The hills and plants are there to make the cars slow down, because when they go slower, they have to really look right next to them to see other cars, and it helps them not go too fast so everyone stays safe. It also stops them from trying to drive straight across the middle, which would be silly and dangerous! Plus, sometimes it just makes the middle of the circle look like a pretty garden.

title: How do embassies work?
text: Imagine you have a best friend who lives in a different town, super far away! An embassy is like a special clubhouse or a little house your friend's family built right in your town. It's not *your* house, it belongs to *them*, even though it's on your street. Special grown-ups from your friend's town work there, and their job is to make sure your town and your friend's town stay good friends and help each other. If someone from your friend's town comes to visit your town and gets lost or needs help, these grown-ups are there to take care of them, just like your parents would help you. They also talk to the grown-ups in your town to make sure everyone plays nicely and understands each other, so the two towns can share toys and be happy together!

title: Why is a single 'Horsepower' equal to 550 foot-pounds per second (ft-lbs/sec)? How was this system created and measured?
text: Imagine you have a super strong horse! A very long time ago, a smart man named James Watt wanted to show people how powerful his new engines were, because back then, horses did all the hard work. He needed to compare his engine to something everyone understood, like a horse! So, he watched how much work a really, really strong horse could do. He saw that a strong horse could pull a very heavy bucket, like 550 pounds (that's super heavy, like a small car!), up from a deep hole, just 1 foot high, in only 1 second! So, he said, "Okay, if my engine can do *that much* work, we'll call that 'one horsepower'!" It was like saying, "My engine is as strong as this super strong horse!" That's how we got that special number for horsepower.

title: When feeling anxious/having an anxiety attack, why does it feel like it's so difficult to get enough oxygen?
text: Imagine your body has a special alarm bell! When you feel super worried or scared, like when you're anxious, that alarm bell rings really loudly. Your body thinks there might be a big, scary monster coming, even if there isn't one. So, to get ready to run super fast or be super strong, your body tells you to breathe in and out much, much faster to get lots and lots of air, just in case you need it to be a superhero. But because there's no actual monster and you don't really need all that extra air, your chest can start to feel a bit funny, like it's working super hard for no reason. It's like when you try to blow up a balloon really, really fast – it feels full and a bit tight, even though it has plenty of air. You *are* getting enough air, your body just thinks it needs even more to be a superhero, and that makes it feel like it's not enough, even though it totally is!

title: How do companies like Netflix and HBO know it's worth producing their own shows when they have no way to gauge how much money they earn as a result of each show? If Game of Thrones costs $x, how does HBO know they would lose more than that in subscriber revenue if they cancelled it?
text: Imagine Netflix and HBO are like big toy rooms you pay a little bit of money to visit every month to play with *all* the toys. They have lots of different toys, like regular action figures

title: How does developers input "traps" in their software for pirated copies? How do they distinguish between real and pirate, and why can't someone just upload new copies without it?
text: Imagine your favorite toy car. The people who made it sometimes put a tiny, secret sticker or a special little "oops" inside the cars they *don't* want people to steal. If someone takes a car without paying, that secret "oops" is still hiding deep inside. When you play with the car, it's like it has little eyes

title: how secure / anonymous are texting apps? How easily can cops trace it?
text: Imagine texting apps are like sending little notes to your friends. Some notes are like writing on a big blackboard in the park – everyone can see them, and everyone knows who wrote them. This is like your regular phone messages (SMS); grown-ups (like cops) can usually find out who sent them and what they said pretty easily, because your phone company keeps a list of all those notes. But some texting apps are like sending notes in a super secret code, inside a special locked box, and only your friend has the

title: How do scientists determine what strain of influenza the flu shot will be made for each year?
text: Imagine the flu bug is like a sneaky monster that changes its costume every year! Grown-up scientists are like superheroes who try to guess what costume the monster will wear next. They have special glasses and look all around the world, like seeing what kinds of flu monsters are making people sick in faraway lands right now. They gather all these clues and say, "Hmm, it looks like the red and blue striped monster will be popular next!" Then, they make the flu shot, which is like a little friendly training exercise for your body, teaching it how to recognize and fight off *that specific* red and blue striped monster, so you don't get super sick even if it tries to sneak up on you!

title: In the Pacific Theatre in WWII, why did Japan run out of experienced pilots but the U.S. didn't?
text: Imagine Japan was like a kid who had a small box of really cool, special toy airplanes and only a few friends who knew how to fly them super, super well. When those friends went to play

title: Explain AMD Risen. What's the Hype?
text: Imagine your computer is like a big toy box, and inside it, there's a tiny, super-smart brain that helps it do everything, like play games, watch videos, or show you pictures. This brain is called a "CPU." AMD Ryzen is like a special, super-duper version of that brain made by a company called AMD. For a long, long time, another company made the fastest brains, like having the fastest race car. But then, AMD worked super hard and made these new Ryzen brains that are just as fast, or even faster, and sometimes they don't cost as much money! So, everyone is super excited because now their computers can be super-duper fast and powerful, letting them play amazing games, draw cool pictures, and do lots of things all at once without getting slow. It's like getting a new toy that's super powerful and fun to play with, and maybe even a little bit cheaper!

title: In the past hour, I've accidentally bitten my tongue twice now. Why does this happen?
text: Imagine your mouth is like a busy playground where your food comes to play! Your teeth are like the big swings that chomp the food, and your tongue is like a super fast helper pushing the food around so the swings can do their job. Most of the time, your tongue is super smart and knows exactly where to hide to stay safe. But sometimes, just like when you're running and accidentally trip over your own feet, your tongue might get a little too excited or be in the wrong spot for just a tiny second when your teeth close. It's a little "oopsie" your brain makes, and it happens to everyone sometimes!

title: Why does intense hunger sometimes cause nausea? That seems like the opposite of what should happen.
text: Imagine your tummy is like a little oven that cooks your food. When you're hungry, your oven is saying, "Ding! Time for food!" But if you wait a *really* long time and don't put any food in, your oven still has some special cooking juice inside, called stomach acid. This juice is usually super helpful to break down yummy snacks. But if there's no food for it to work on, this juice can slosh around and make your empty tummy feel a bit upset, like when you spin around too much and feel dizzy! It's not trying to stop you from eating; it's just your tummy feeling a little bit grumpy and saying, "Please, please, *please* put some food in me so I can stop feeling yucky!"

title: Why do we still use Latin to name new species?
text: Imagine you have a special toy, like a dinosaur! You might call it "Dino" but your friend in another country might call it something totally different in their language. To make sure everyone, everywhere, knows *exactly* which dinosaur you're talking about, scientists use a super old language called Latin. It's like a secret code language that doesn't change anymore, so it's always the same for everyone. This way, no matter if you're in America, Japan, or France, when scientists say the Latin name for a new animal, everyone knows *exactly* which one it is, like a special name tag that the whole world understands!

title: What are the rules of cricket -- or at least enough of the rules that I would know what the heck I'm watching?
text:
Okay, imagine two teams playing! One team tries to hit a ball, and the other team tries to get them out. There are two sets of sticks in the middle, called 'wickets.' One person from the hitting team (the 'batsman') stands in front of one set of sticks, trying to protect them. Someone from the other team (the 'bowler') throws the ball really fast at those sticks, trying to knock them over.

If the batsman hits the ball, they can run back and forth between the two sets of sticks to score 'runs' (points)! The more times they run, the more points they get. If they hit the ball really hard and it goes all the way to the edge of the field, that's 4 runs

title: how does my phone calculate how many flights of stairs went up?
text: Your phone has a tiny, tiny little "nose" inside it, like your nose, but it smells the *air* instead of cookies! When you are on the ground, there's a lot of air pushing down on you, like a big, invisible blanket. When you walk up the stairs to a higher floor, you're a little bit higher up, so there's a tiny bit less air above you, and the "air blanket" feels a little lighter. Your phone's special nose feels this tiny change in how heavy the air blanket is! It's super smart and knows that if the air feels lighter by *just this much*, it means you went up one whole floor, and it adds it to your count!

title: I'm allergic to penicillin/amoxicillin. Could there be a point where giving it to me anyways and dealing with the symptoms is a better option than not?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a special club. Penicillin is a guest, but your club says, 'No thank you! We don't like this guest, it makes

title: What neurologically is happening when a song "gets old" from hearing it too often?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super curious little explorer! When you hear a brand new song, your brain gets super excited because it's a new adventure with new sounds and rhythms, like finding a brand new toy you've never played with before! Your brain pays lots of attention, trying to figure out all the cool parts, and it makes you feel happy and bouncy because it's a fun surprise. But if you hear the *same* song over and over and over again, it's like playing with the *same* toy every single day for a very, very long time. After a while, your explorer brain says, "Oh, I know this one! I know exactly what's going to happen next." It's not a surprise anymore, so your brain doesn't need to work hard to figure it out. It stops being as exciting and fun because your brain already knows the whole story, and it wants new adventures! It's not that the song is bad, it's just that your brain gets a little bored because it's heard it so much it knows it by heart.

title: How do snowflakes get their unique shape?
text: Imagine tiny, tiny bits of water way up high in the sky, where it's super, super cold. These tiny water bits get so chilly they freeze and turn into a tiny little ice crystal, like a super small diamond. Now, as this tiny ice crystal falls down from the clouds, it bumps into more tiny water bits and feels different kinds of cold air around it. Each time it bumps into something, it adds a little bit more to itself, like when you build with LEGOs and add a new piece. Sometimes it's a bit warmer, sometimes it's a bit colder, and sometimes it bumps into more water on one side than the other. All these tiny little changes as it tumbles down make it grow in a super special way, adding little arms and patterns, until it has its very own unique, pretty shape! That's why every snowflake is special and different, just like your own drawings are unique.

title: If cochlear implants communicate directly with the brain using electrical signals to fix deafness, why can we not yet use the same principle to correct blindness, or even possibly create virtual reality capable of full cognitive immersion?
text: Okay, imagine your ears are like little microphones that listen to sounds, which are like tiny wiggles in the air! Your ears turn those wiggles into secret spark messages that go right to

title: How does charcoal mellow whiskey?
text: Okay, imagine whiskey is like a grown-up's juice, but sometimes it has tiny, invisible "ouchy" bits that make it taste a bit too strong or pokey. Now, charcoal is like special black rocks made from burnt wood, and these rocks have super-duper tiny holes and bumps all over them, like a sponge! When you let the whiskey slowly drip through a big pile of these charcoal rocks, it's like the charcoal is a friendly gatekeeper. As the whiskey wiggles its way through all those tiny holes and bumps, the charcoal catches and holds onto those invisible "ouchy" bits, like a sticky trap! So, by the time the whiskey comes out the other side, it's left all the "ouchy" bits behind with the charcoal, making it taste much smoother and nicer, like a yummy marshmallow instead of a sour lemon. That's how charcoal makes the whiskey "mellow" – it just cleans out the strong, pokey bits!

title: Why do we have inflation? Is it necessary?
text: Imagine you have a piggy bank full of shiny coins, and you want to buy a yummy cookie. Inflation is when that same yummy cookie costs a little bit more coins next week or next month than it does today. It happens for a few reasons! Sometimes, the grown-ups who make money print a little bit too much, so everyone has lots of coins, but there are still the same number of cookies. When everyone has lots of money, the cookie baker thinks, "Hmm, I can ask for a little bit more for my yummy cookies!" Other times, it's because it gets harder or more expensive for the baker to get the flour and sugar to make the cookies, so they have to charge more. Is it necessary? Well, a little bit of inflation is actually like a gentle push that helps the world keep moving. If prices never, ever went up, people might not feel like working hard to make

title: Why do tired eyes look sunken and dark?
text: When you're super sleepy, your body is tired too, just like how you feel tired! It's like a balloon that's lost a tiny bit of air – it gets a little softer and less bouncy. The skin right under your eyes is super, super thin, like the thinnest tissue paper ever. When your body is tired, that skin can get a little less plump, so the tiny space where your eye sits looks a bit deeper, like a small valley. And because that skin is so thin, you can see the tiny blue lines (which are little blood pipes) underneath a

title: If you want to wear two pairs of socks in cold weather, and one pair is thicker and more insulated than the other, which should you put on first to keep your feet the warmest?
text: Okay, imagine your foot is a super warm little potato! You want to keep all that potato warmth safe and snug. The thick, fuzzy sock is like a super big, puffy blanket that's really good at holding onto warmth. The thin sock is like a smaller, less puffy blanket. You should always put the super big, puffy blanket (the thick sock) right next to your warm potato foot first! That way, it catches all the warmth right away and keeps it trapped inside the best. Then, the thin sock can go on top to add just a little extra hug of warmth, but the thick one does the most important job of keeping your potato foot toasty warm.

title: How street-level drugs are becoming increasingly more sophisticated. Are there real-life Walter Whites?
text: Imagine you have your favorite play-doh, right? Sometimes grown-ups who make bad stuff learn new, super tricky ways to mix different kinds of play-doh together, or even

title: What would it be like swimming in zero gravity?
text: Okay, imagine you're in space where everything just floats, like magic! There's no 'up' or 'down.' So, if you had a big, big ball of water floating there, it wouldn't stay in a pool like it does here; it would just be a giant, wobbly, floating water bubble! If you tried to 'swim' inside it, it would be super funny. When you push the water with your hands and feet, the water doesn't really push back on you very well. Instead, *you* would gently float and drift around inside the big water bubble, and the water you pushed would float away from you too! You wouldn't swim fast or zoom like in a pool; you'd just slowly tumble and spin inside the big water blob, making the water all sloshy and wobbly around you. It would be more like playing with a giant, squishy water balloon from the inside, gently pushing yourself through it, but not really 'swimming' like you do here on Earth!

title: How did Facebook know I might be friends with a person in another city, when I've given them almost no information?
text: Imagine Facebook is like a very clever detective helper that knows lots of people! Even if you don't tell Facebook much, your other friends do. So, if your friend Timmy tells Facebook,

title: That temporary "watermark" on our vision when we look at something bright then either look away or close our eyes?
text: Imagine your eyes are like super special cameras that help you see the world! When you look at something super duper bright, like a really sunny window or a bright light bulb, it's like your camera lens gets a little bit overwhelmed by all that light. One tiny part of your eye that sees the bright spot gets a little tired, like when you run really fast and your legs get tired. So, when you look away or close your eyes, that tired part of your eye still remembers the bright light for a little bit, and you see a tiny, faint "ghost" of it. But don't worry! Your eye just needs a quick little rest, like your legs resting after running, and then it's all better and the ghost goes away!

title: What's the complete process of the milk I buy from cow to bottle?
text: Imagine a happy cow in a big field! First, the cow makes yummy milk inside her. Farmers use a special, gentle machine, like a soft hug, to get the milk out of the cow. This milk is super fresh and warm, so they quickly make it cold, cold, cold in a big tank, like a giant fridge, so it stays good. Then, a big truck, like a milk taxi, takes all that cold milk to a special milk house, which is like a milk kitchen! At the milk kitchen, grown-ups check the milk to make sure it's perfect and healthy. Then, they give it a warm bath, not too hot, just warm enough to chase away any tiny, invisible germs that might make you feel yucky – this makes the milk super safe to drink! Sometimes, they also give it a little spin to make it super smooth so the creamy part doesn't float to the top. Finally, they pour the clean, safe, and yummy milk into all the bottles and cartons you see. Then, another truck takes it to the shop, ready for you to buy and drink! Moooo!

title: Dreams. Why sometimes the dream is so vivid that we get that "Damn it was just a dream" feeling?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper storyteller that works when you're sleeping! It makes up all sorts of adventures for you, like you're flying, or playing with talking animals, or even finding a giant candy castle! While you're asleep, your brain is so, so good at telling these stories that it makes them feel super, super real, just like when you're playing pretend and you *really* believe you're a superhero for a little while. You see, hear, and feel things in the dream as if they are actually happening right now! Then, *poof!* You wake up, and it's like the storybook suddenly closes. Your brain goes, "Oh! That was just a story I was telling myself!" And that's why it feels a little surprising, like, "Wow, that felt so real, but it was just my brain playing a fun (or sometimes silly) movie!"

title: How come we can smell over people's houses and jackets and things, but we can never smell our own houses?
text: Imagine your nose is like a little helper that's really good at finding new things! When you go to a friend's house or put on someone else's jacket, your nose is like, "Wow, what's this new smell?" and it tells your brain all about it. But when you're in your own house all the time, your nose gets used to the smells, kind of like how you get used to wearing your favorite shirt. You don't feel your shirt on you all day long, do you? It's still there, but your body just knows it's there and doesn't need to tell you about it anymore. Your nose does the same thing with your house smells! It's still there, but your nose is like, "Oh, these old smells again," and it stops telling your brain about them so it can be ready to find new, super interesting smells, like a yummy cake baking!

title: why did humans start cooking food?
text: Imagine you have a super tough, chewy piece of candy that's hard to bite! If you warm it up a little, it gets softer and easier to eat, right? Well, a long, long, long time ago, people found out that if they put their food, especially meat or tough plants, near a warm fire, lots of good things happened! The food got much softer, so it was easier to chew and swallow, which meant their tummies didn't have to work so hard. It also often tasted much yummier! And sometimes, raw food had tiny invisible "boo-boos" that could make people feel sick, but the fire's heat would make those boo-boos go away, keeping them healthy. Plus, when food was cooked, their bodies could get all the good energy out of it much easier, like getting all the juice out of a fruit! So, cooking was a super helpful trick that made food easier to eat, tastier, safer, and gave people more energy to run and play and think!

title: How are the new Intel processors better than older ones even if they're running at the same speed and have the same number of cores?
text: Imagine your computer is like a busy kitchen, and the processors are the chefs making yummy food! Old processors are like having a few chefs (that's the 'cores') who are super

title: Why was a VW exec arrested while no bankers faced jail for the housing crisis?
text: Okay, imagine a company that makes toy cars called VW. VW told everyone their toy cars were super clean and didn't make much yucky air. But they had a secret button

title: How do illegal key generators work?
text: Imagine you have a super cool toy, but it only works if you type in a secret magic word. The people who made the toy know the real magic word. An "illegal key generator" is

title: When freezing stuff like vegetables or a chicken with liquid nitrogen, why does it shatter/break like glass?
text: Imagine your veggies or chicken are like a big group of kids holding hands and wiggling around; that's why they're soft and squishy! When you make them cold, like in the freezer, the kids get a little sleepy and don't wiggle as much, so they get harder. But liquid nitrogen is like the *super duper coldest* thing ever! It makes all the kids stop wiggling *completely* and freeze in place, holding onto each other super tight. When they're all stuck like that, they can't bend or move anymore, so if you try to push them, instead of bending, they just break into little pieces, just like a hard toy block or a glass cup would if you dropped it.

title: Why can we recognize so many celebrities and fictional characters if the human mind is only supposed to be able to know about 200-250 people?
text: Imagine your brain has a special little club where you keep all your *real* friends and family, the people you play with, talk to, and know really well, like Mommy, Daddy, and your best friend. That club can only fit about 200-250 people because it takes a lot of brain-power to remember everything about them – what they like, how they feel, and all your secrets! But then, your brain also has a super big picture book, like a TV or a storybook. In that picture book, you can see *lots* and *lots* of people and characters, like the princess from your favorite movie or the superhero on TV. You see their faces and hear their names so many times that your brain just remembers what they look like, even if you don't *know* them personally or play with them. It's much easier for your brain to remember a picture you see often than to remember everything about a real friend you spend time with!

title: How do radio stations broadcast album art?
text: Okay, imagine the radio station is like a big friend sending you a special invisible message through the air, all the way to your house! Most of that message is the wonderful music you love to dance to. But sometimes, with super-duper smart radios, the radio station also tucks in a tiny, secret picture message *right next to* the music message. It's like when you draw a happy picture on a piece of paper and then write a story next to it – the picture isn't the story, but it goes with it! Your smart radio knows how to look for that secret picture message and show it on its little screen. Older, simpler radios only know how to listen to the music part, so they don't even know the secret picture message is there!

title: How does a surface-to-air missile (SAM) distinguish hostile aircrafts from friendly aircrafts?
text: Imagine our special rocket launcher has super-duper eyes that can see all the planes flying in the sky, like you can see all the different toys in your room. Now, our good guy planes have a secret little radio inside them, like a special walkie-talkie that only talks to our rocket launcher. When the rocket launcher sees a plane, it sends out a secret "Hello, are you a friend?" message. If it's one of our planes, its special walkie-talkie quickly sends back a secret "Yes, I'm a friend!" signal, like giving a secret password. But if a plane doesn't send back the secret "Yes," or if it sends back a strange answer, then our rocket launcher thinks, "Hmm, that might not be a friend!" and gets ready to keep

title: Why do lenders prefer people with high credit scores? Won't they make less money?
text: Imagine you have a yummy cookie, and your friend wants to borrow it for a little bit. If your friend *always* gives back everything they borrow, like your toys or crayons, you'd be happy to let them borrow your cookie, right? That friend is like someone with a "high credit score" – it means grown-ups trust them a lot to give things back. Lenders are like you with your cookie! They want to lend money to people who they know will give it back safely. It's like you'd rather get your cookie back for sure, even if they don't give you an *extra* cookie. It's much better than

title: What happens when our lips are chapped?
text: Imagine your lips are like a super soft, squishy blanket that keeps them safe and happy. Sometimes, when it's really windy outside, or super cold, or if you don't drink enough water, that blanket gets very, very dry. So dry that it starts to get little tiny cracks, like dry mud in a puddle when the sun bakes it all up. When your lips get chapped, that just means their soft, protective blanket is all dry and cracked, and sometimes it can feel a little ouchy. That's why putting on special lip balm is like giving your lips a big, yummy drink of water to make their blanket soft and happy again!

title: Is there a reason for the Alphabet to be in order?
text: You know how we sing the ABC song? A, B, C, D... That's the special order the letters like to stand in! No one really *decided* a long, long, long time ago that 'A' *had* to be first and 'Z' *had* to be last. It just kind of happened that way over many, many years, like how you always line up for snack time in the same way. But because everyone learned it in that special order, it makes it super easy for us to learn all the letters, and to find words in books, or names in a list. If everyone had their own different order, it would be very confusing! So, we keep it that way because it helps all of us read and write and understand each other better, like a secret code everyone knows.

title: Why do humans have to have a "side of the bed" to sleep comfortably?
text: You know how you have a favorite spot on the couch, or a special cup that just feels right? Your bed is a bit like that! When you sleep on one side all the time, your brain gets super used to it. It knows exactly where your pillow is, where your feet go, and what the wall looks like from your spot. It's like your very own cozy little nest! Knowing exactly where everything is helps your body relax and feel super safe and comfy, which makes it easier to fall asleep and have happy dreams. If you suddenly sleep on the other side, it feels a little bit new and different, and your brain has to work harder to figure things out, which isn't as relaxing for sleepy time.

title: Why is it when we are younger we like sweeter food and can eat large quantities of them. But as adults we tend to like more fuller and bitter flavors, and sweeter foods can sometimes be "too rich"?
text: Okay, imagine your body when you're little is like a tiny plant that needs lots and lots of sunshine and special plant food to grow super big and strong! Sweet foods are like that super special plant food – they give your body lots of quick energy to build big muscles and a super smart brain really fast. That's why you can eat so much, because your body uses up all that energy super quickly to grow, grow, grow! But when you get to be a grown-up, your body isn't growing taller anymore. It's already big! So, it doesn't need *as much* of that super-duper speedy sweet energy all the time. Grown-

title: Why do we find it hard to breathe when facing towards a strong wind?
text: Imagine your mouth and nose are like a little door for air to come into your body, so you can run and play! When you breathe in, you're trying to open that door and pull fresh air inside. But when a really strong wind blows right at your face, it's like a big, invisible giant is pushing very hard on your air door from the outside! It's trying to push the air *out* or stop new air from coming *in*. So, your body has to work extra, extra hard to pull the air past that pushy wind, and that's why it feels difficult to breathe, like trying to drink juice with a straw while someone is blowing into the other end!

title: Why do large, established companies like Coca-Cola outsource their branding to boutique firms?
text: Imagine Coca-Cola is like a super big toy factory that makes yummy drinks. Inside the factory, lots of people are busy making sure the drink tastes just right. But Coca-Cola also needs to make sure their bottles look cool, and their songs are catchy so that everyone wants to buy their drink – that's called 'branding'! Now, the people inside the big factory are amazing at making the drink, but sometimes they've been doing the same things for a long, long time, and maybe they need fresh, new ideas. It's like if your mom is super good at baking cookies, but sometimes she asks her friend who's really good at drawing to make a new, colorful picture for the cookie box. So, Coca-Cola asks special, smaller groups of super creative people, kind of like a special art club, to come up with brand new, exciting ideas for their bottles or new fun songs. These smaller groups, called 'boutique firms', are really, really good at *just* thinking of new, cool ways to make things look and sound awesome, which helps Coca-Cola get super fresh ideas and makes sure you always love

title: Why is it harder to keep your balance you close our eyes?
text: Imagine you're a super tall tower, and your brain is the builder trying to keep you standing up straight. Your eyes are like the builder's best binoculars! They look all around at the floor, the walls, and everything else, and they tell your brain, "Hey, you're leaning a little this way!" or "You're perfectly straight!" This helps your brain make tiny, quick adjustments to your feet and body to keep you from wiggling. But when you close your eyes, it's like the builder's binoculars suddenly went dark! Your brain can't see all those helpful things anymore. It still tries its best using other clues, like what your feet feel on the floor, but it's much, much harder to stay perfectly steady without its best helper showing it where everything is.

title: How does the Crocodile Dentist toy work?
text: Okay, imagine Mr. Crocodile has a lot of teeth, right? And one of them is super duper sore! When you open his mouth, all the teeth look the same, but inside his head, there's a secret little spinner, like a tiny magic wheel. This spinner decides which tooth is going to be the sore one *this time*. So, you start pressing his teeth gently. If you press a good tooth, nothing happens! But if you press the one that the secret spinner picked, it pushes a tiny button inside Mr. Crocodile. That button makes his mouth go *SNAP!* shut really fast! Then, when you open his mouth again, that secret spinner spins to a different spot, so a *different* tooth becomes the sore one for the next turn! That's why you never know which tooth will make him snap!

title: Why is punching through a wall or smashing a glass object so much more satisfying than squeezing something like a stress ball when you're angry?
text: Okay, imagine your angry feelings are like a big, bouncy balloon inside you that really wants to POP! When you squeeze a soft stress ball, it's like you're just squishing the

title: If I lose 10 lbs, how does it leave my body?
text: Imagine your body is like a special piggy bank that stores little bits of energy as fat. When you run and play a lot, or eat healthy food, your body opens that piggy bank and uses the fat to give you super energy! As your body uses up the fat, it doesn't just disappear. Most of it changes into a special kind of air called carbon dioxide, which you breathe out every single time you exhale, like blowing a gentle puff of air. The rest of the fat changes into water, and that water leaves your body when you go pee-pee, or when you sweat when you're running fast and playing outside. So, when you lose 10 pounds, it's mostly leaving your body as invisible air when you breathe out, and as water when you go to the bathroom or get sweaty!

title: What is the difference between Universities and Colleges?
text:
Imagine you have a big box of LEGOs.

A **College** is like a smaller box of LEGOs where all the pieces are for building one specific awesome thing, like a spaceship or a cool car. You learn exactly how to build that one thing really well so you can go play with it (get a job) pretty soon!

A **University** is like a super duper giant box of LEGOs that has *all* the smaller boxes inside it! It has the spaceship box, the car box, a castle box, and even a box with special pieces nobody has ever seen before so you can invent brand new things! You can learn how to build anything you can imagine, and sometimes you stay a long, long time to learn the hardest builds or even figure out how to make new kinds of LEGOs. So, a university is usually much, much bigger, has way more choices, and helps you learn really deep things or even think up brand new ideas for the world!
