title: What is the difference between Standard and Express shipping?
text: Imagine you ordered a super cool toy! Standard shipping is like when the toy comes to your house in a few days, maybe like waiting for the weekend to come. It's the normal way, and it doesn't cost extra for being super fast. Express shipping is like when you really, really want that toy right now, so it comes super, super fast, maybe even tomorrow! But because it's so quick, it costs a little bit more money for the special speedy trip. So, standard is a bit slower and normal price, and express is super fast but costs a tiny bit extra.

title: Why aren't there psychotherapists who advertise themselves as working after 5pm?
text: Imagine grown-ups who are like special helpers for feelings, who listen to grown-ups talk about sad or worry thoughts to help them feel better. Some of these helpers *do* work after 5 o'clock, when the sun starts to go down and most grown-ups are home from their jobs! It's actually a super popular time for them

title: Why do web pages viewed on mobile devices keep changing layout as they load, and then change again just as you try to tap a link after it seems like they were finished loading?
text: Imagine you're looking at a big picture book, but someone is drawing the pictures right in front of you! First, they draw some words. Then, they draw a big picture, and because

title: Why do Americans not have a problem with moving football teams 100's of miles?
text: Imagine your favorite toy car. A grown-up bought that toy car, and they own it, not the playground. Sometimes, that grown-up thinks the toy car would have more fun, or get more friends to play with, in a different, bigger playground far away! They might move the car because a new city promises to build a super cool new garage for it, or they think more kids will come to watch it play there, which helps the grown-up get more money to buy even more cool toys for the car. It's sad for the kids who loved the car in the old playground, but because grown-ups own the teams like a business, and it's happened many times before, people in America kind of understand that sometimes the grown-up chooses to move their toy to a new, exciting place.

title: Why do men only go bald on their heads and nowhere else? Their beards, for example.
text: Imagine all the hair on your body is like different kinds of little plants. The plants on your head are a special kind, and the plants for your beard are another kind. For some grown-up boys, because of a secret message they got from their mommy and daddy when they were born, there's a special "bossy juice" inside their body. This bossy juice, for *only* the hair plants on their head, tells them, "Okay, time to stop growing and take a long nap!" But it doesn't tell the beard hair plants, or the arm hair plants, or the leg hair plants to do that. They're like different kinds of plants that listen to different rules, so only the head plants sometimes decide to go on a big vacation!

title: how far is the horizon? And how far is it the higher you are on land?
text: Okay, imagine you're standing outside and you look really, really far away, all the way to where the sky looks like it's touching the ground or the water. That line

title: Why are the lanthanum and actinium series not left in with the traditional table of elements?
text: Imagine your periodic table is like a super long train, with lots and lots of train cars! Each car has a special number and a special passenger inside (that's an element). Now, there are two special groups of passengers, the "lanthanum friends" and the "actinium friends." If we put all of these special friends right into the middle of our long train, the train would get SOOOOO long, it wouldn't fit on the tracks anymore! It would hang off the table and look all messy. So, instead, we take those two special groups of friends and we give them their own special little train track right underneath the main train. They're still part of the big train family, but they have their own cozy spot so the main train doesn't get too long and everybody fits nicely!

title: What's the difference between an Uber and an unlicensed taxi?
text: Imagine you want to go to the park! With **Uber**, it's like your mommy or daddy uses a special phone app to call a specific car. The app knows who the driver is, and the company knows too, so it's like they've checked that driver is a good, safe person to drive you, and they follow rules, like wearing a seatbelt and driving nicely. It's like calling a friend who your parents trust to pick you up. But with an **unlicensed taxi**, it's like if your mommy or daddy just waved at *any* car driving by on the street and asked for a ride, without really knowing who the driver is, or if they're even allowed to drive people for money, or if anyone checked if they're a good, safe driver

title: Why there is no remote finder button on TV, to track lost remote?
text: You know how sometimes your favorite toy car gets lost under the couch, and you wish it could just yell "I'm over here!" so you could find it super fast? That's kind of what you're asking for with the TV remote! For your TV to find the remote, both the TV and the remote would need special little computer brains inside them that can talk to each other, and the remote would need a tiny speaker to make a noise. All those extra special parts cost more money to put inside the TV and the remote, and most grown-ups don't lose their remote *all* the time. So, the people who make TVs decided it was better to make TVs that are not too expensive for lots of families, instead of adding those extra parts that only some people would use. It's like how a simple cookie is yummy, but a cookie with sprinkles and chocolate chips costs a little bit more!

title: How are some musicians (ex: Robbie Williams) able to create so many songs and albums without getting creative burnout or having songs that sound very similar?
text: Imagine you have a big box of LEGOs. You can build so many different things, right? A house, a car, a spaceship! Musicians are a bit like that with their ideas. They get ideas from *everywhere* – from playing outside, from talking to friends, from feeling happy or sad, or even from just looking at the sky. Each new idea is like a different LEGO piece. And guess what? They don't always build *all* the LEGOs by themselves! They have special friends who help them, like other musicians who play instruments, or grown-ups who help them write down the words. Plus, they know *lots* of different ways to put their musical LEGOs together – they can sing fast or slow, loud or quiet, use a guitar or a piano. So even if they sing about a similar feeling, they make it sound new and exciting, just like you can draw a dog in lots of different ways! And sometimes, they just need to take a break and play, just like you do, to get fresh ideas for their next big musical LEGO creation.

title: What are the reasons people say communism/socialism does not work with larger populations?
text: Imagine you and all your friends want to share all the toys and snacks in the whole wide world, and everyone says, "Okay, let's make sure *everyone* gets the same amount of everything!" It sounds super fair, right? But when there are only a few friends, like just you and your brother, it's easy for Mommy and Daddy to know what you both need and want. When there are *lots* and *lots* of friends, like everyone in your whole city or even the whole country, it becomes super, super hard for anyone to know what every single person needs, like if one kid really wants a blue car and another wants a red car. Plus, sometimes, if everyone gets the same amount of cookies no matter if they help bake them or just play, some people might think, "Hmm, maybe I don't need to work so hard to bake cookies if I get them anyway!" And then there might not be as many yummy cookies for everyone. It's just very, very tricky to make sure everyone is happy and has enough when there are so, so many people.

title: When you are stretching really intensely, like when you wake up, why does your ability to hear diminish greatly?
text: When you stretch your body really big, like a giant yawn, your muscles squeeze tight, even the ones around your head and neck. This makes a tiny bit of pressure inside your head, like when you blow up a balloon a little bit. Your ears have a special part called an eardrum, which is like a tiny drum that wiggles to hear sounds. When there's that little bit of pressure from your big stretch, it makes your eardrum a little bit busy or pushes on it just a tiny bit. It's like if you were trying to listen to music, but someone was gently pushing on your ear at the same time – it's harder to hear clearly! So, your ears are just busy with the big stretch for a moment, and they take a little break from hearing everything super loud until you're done stretching.

title: Why is it we feel very motivated towards the night and when waking up in the morning we don't have the same drive?
text: Imagine your body is like a little toy car. All day long, it's been busy playing and learning and doing all sorts of things. When nighttime comes, sometimes your car gets a special burst of "last energy" because it knows bedtime is coming soon, and you really, really want to do *all the fun things* before you have to park it for the night! It's like you don't want the fun to end, so you get super excited to do things right before you have to sleep. But then, when morning comes, your little car is still a bit sleepy from being parked all night. It needs some time to warm up and wake up properly, maybe with some yummy breakfast fuel, before it's ready to zoom around and play all day again. It knows there's a whole big day ahead, so it takes a little while to get its super speedy drive back!

title: Why Stephen Hawking is the long-lived person with ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis), what is the difference between Him and the others with same disease?

ALS is like those wires slowly breaking, so the messages can't get through anymore. For most people with ALS, the wires that help with super important things, like breathing or swallowing food, break quite quickly, which makes them very, very sick and unable to live for a long time. title: How do weather stations know the "feels like" temperature of the windchill if thermometers only pick up the windless temperature?
text: Imagine a thermometer is like a little sleepy bear that just sits there and feels how warm or cold the air is around it, like when you stand still. It doesn't care if there's wind! But you know how sometimes when the wind blows on you, even if the sleepy bear says it's not too cold, you feel extra, extra chilly, like when you get out of the warm bathtub and a fan blows on you? That's the "feels like" cold! Weather stations are super smart because they have the sleepy bear telling them the air's temperature, but they also have another special friend that measures how *fast* the wind is blowing, like how fast a superhero runs! Then, they use a secret math recipe that says, "If the air is *this* cold and the wind is blowing *that* fast, then it will *feel like* it's this much colder!" They don't actually *feel* it, they just use their smart tools and a clever trick to tell us what our skin will feel.

title: Why is a video taken from my phone camera a couple GB but a movie which is much longer is about the same size?
text:
Okay, imagine your phone camera is like a very excited little artist. When it draws a picture (takes a video), it tries to draw *every single tiny thing* it sees, like every blade of grass, every tiny speck of dust, and it uses super bright, super detailed colors for everything! It doesn't know what's important yet, so it draws it all out very big and full.

Now, a big movie is like a super clever artist who knows exactly what people want to see. They draw the picture, but then they make it much, much smaller and tidier. They say, "Hmm, do we really need to draw *every single* blade of grass, or can we just make it look like grass?" They squish the picture down very smartly, taking out all the tiny bits that you wouldn't really notice are missing, so it's much easier to carry around, even if it's a super long story! So your phone video is like a big, unsquished drawing, and the movie is a super squished, clever drawing that still looks amazing.

title: How are protein and other supplements refined from food?
text: Imagine your yummy food, like milk or peas, is like a big toy box with lots of different toys inside. Some toys are protein, which helps you grow big and strong, and some are vitamins, which help you stay healthy. Grown-ups want to play with *just* the protein toys or *just* the vitamin toys, but not all the other toys in the box. So, they take the food and use special tricks, kind of like a super-duper strainer, much bigger than the one mommy uses for pasta! This strainer helps them pick out *only* the tiny protein pieces or vitamin pieces, letting all the other parts of the food go away. Sometimes they even wash these special pieces to make them super clean. Then, they gather all those clean protein or vitamin pieces and turn them into a powder or a little pill, so it's easy for your body to get just what it needs without eating a whole mountain of food!

title: While being put "on hold" on the phone, why do songs played have such dreadful quality, while voices come through just fine?
text: Imagine your phone is like a special road, and this road is super good at carrying just your voice, like a very clear path for only one little car, so you can always hear Mommy or Daddy perfectly. But when they play a song, it's like trying to fit a whole big parade with lots of noisy instruments and people onto that same little road! To make it fit, they have to squish all the sounds together a lot, making the music sound a bit messy and not as nice. They do this because it's much more important that your voice, and the voice of the person you're talking to, always sounds super clear, even if the parade music gets a little squished.

title: If there have already been 2 unsuccessful NFL teams in L.A. why do Dean Spanos and Stan Kroenke think that it will work now?
text: Imagine you had a toy a long, long time ago, but it wasn't very fun, and then you put it away. Now, you're much bigger, and there are way, way more kids in your neighborhood! Plus, there's a brand-new, super-duper cool playground just built, way better than the old one. Dean and Stan think that because so many more people live here now, and there's a shiny new place to play, everyone will be super excited to come watch the football games! They also think that because there haven't been any big football teams here for a long, long time, people really, really missed them and are ready to cheer for them again.

title: How does the brain perceive sound while asleep? Can it learn what to listen for?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper house with lots of rooms. When you're asleep, most of the lights are off and many rooms are resting, but there's a special little room, like a listening station, that stays a tiny bit awake! It can still hear sounds outside, like a soft whisper or a loud bang. It doesn't always wake up the whole house, but it definitely notices things. And guess what? Your brain is super smart and can learn what sounds are important! It's like that listening station has a little sleepy guard. If the sound is something super important, like your mommy calling your name or a baby crying, the guard says, "WHOA! Wake up the house!" and you might open your eyes. But if it's just a normal sound, like the fridge humming or a car driving by far away, the guard says, "Nah, that's okay, let's keep sleeping," and just ignores it. Your brain learns over time which sounds are 'wake-up' sounds and which are 'sleep-through' sounds, almost like it's practicing to be a very clever sleepy guard!

title: Why do a lot of singers sound western American when singing in English?
text: Imagine you have a favorite superhero, and when you play, you try to sound just like them, right? So, when singers from all over the world learn to sing in English, they listen to these popular American songs a lot. It's like they learn to "sing in character" for the music, making their voice sound familiar and cool, just like the songs they've heard and loved, so lots and lots of people will enjoy their music too!

title: why do we have eyebrows?
text: Your eyebrows are like little fuzzy helpers for your eyes! They work really hard to stop yucky sweat from your forehead or drippy rain from running right into your eyes, which would make them sting. They're also super good at helping your face show people how you're feeling inside, like when you're surprised, happy, or even a little bit mad!

title: Booleans in C Programming?
text: Imagine you have a light switch in your room. It can be ON, or it can be OFF, right? It can't be both at the same time! Computers need to know things like that too, like "Is this button pressed?" or "Is the game over yet?". When we talk about "booleans" (say boo-lee-ans) in C programming, it's just a fancy word for those simple "yes" or "no" answers. If something is "true" (like the light is ON), the computer often thinks of it as the number 1. If something is "false" (like the light is OFF), the computer often thinks of it as the number 0. So, booleans help the computer make simple choices, just like you choose if your light should be on or off!

title: Why are we afraid of Russia?
text: Imagine Russia is like a really, really big kid on our world's playground. This big kid has lots of big, strong toys, like super fast cars and flying toys, and many friends who play with them. Most of the time, everyone plays together, but sometimes, this big kid has been known to push other kids around, or try to take their toys, or even go into another kid's sandbox without asking. When that happens, the other kids (which are other countries) feel a little bit worried. They're not super duper scared like of a monster, but they feel like they need to be careful and stand up for themselves and their friends so everyone can play nicely and safely. So, we're not exactly "afraid" like we're hiding under the bed, but we are careful and want to make sure everyone follows the rules and stays kind to each other, especially the big kids with lots of toys, so everyone stays safe.

title: What happens if the President of the USA wants to quit because people are too mean or the job is too hard?
text: Okay, imagine the President is like the captain of a very, very big team, like a superhero team for the whole country! If the captain gets super tired, or feels sad because the job is really hard, or if some people are saying mean things, they can totally say, "I quit!" Just like you can stop playing a game if you're not having fun anymore. But guess what? We still need a captain for the team! So, their special helper, who we call the Vice President, steps right up and becomes the new captain, super fast! It's like if the captain of your favorite superhero team went home, the co-captain would immediately take charge so the team can keep saving the day without missing a beat. The big job still gets done!

title: Why radiation is so dangerous and how it sticks around for so long?
text: Imagine your body is built with lots and lots of tiny, tiny LEGO bricks. Radiation is like invisible super-speedy tiny balls of energy that fly around. When these tiny balls hit your LEGO bricks, they can sometimes knock them out of place or even break them! If too many of your body's LEGO bricks get broken, your body can't build itself back up properly, and you can get very, very sick, like when you have a super bad cold, but much worse. Now, why does it stick around? Well, some special rocks that make this radiation are like a super slow-motion popcorn machine. They don't make all their invisible energy popcorn at once. Instead, they just keep making tiny bits of it, slowly, slowly, for a super duper long time – even longer than you'll ever be old! That's why we have to be super careful and keep those special rocks in safe places for a very, very long time, so their invisible energy doesn't hurt anyone.

title: Why does that "insert" key that deletes your text as you type exist?
text: Okay, imagine you're drawing a picture, and you've already drawn a long line of blue dots. Usually, if you want to add a new red dot in the middle, you'd draw it, and all the blue dots after it would scoot over to make room for your new red dot. That's how your computer usually types! But sometimes, you don't want the dots to move. You just want to change one blue dot into a red dot *right where it is*, without pushing any other dots around. The "insert" key is like a magic button that tells your computer, "Hey, now when I type, don't make space for new letters, just write

title: Why is that in all pictures wee see of planets and moons we always see the crater only and never see the meteor, boulder or whatever caused the crater sitting on the collision site?
text: Imagine you have a big, soft mud pie and you throw a tiny, hard pebble at it really, really fast! *SPLAT!* The pebble doesn't just sit on top, right? It goes *smash* into the pie. What happens to the pebble? It probably breaks into super-duper tiny pieces, or it gets pushed deep, deep down into the mud pie, under all the mud that flew up when it hit. Sometimes, the crash is so, so fast and hot that the pebble even melts a little bit, like ice cream on a hot day! So, you're left with a big hole in your mud pie, but the pebble that made the hole is gone – it broke, melted, or got buried. That's just like the big rocks from space hitting planets and moons! They make a huge hole (a crater!), but they break into tiny bits, melt from the super-fast crash, or get buried deep, deep under all the dirt and rocks that got thrown up. All that's left is the big, round hole to show where they hit!

title: Why is the number 'e' so important?
text: Imagine you have a super special magic plant! Most plants grow a little bit every day, right? But your magic plant grows a tiny, tiny, tiny bit *every single second*, all the time, never stopping! The number 'e' (we just call it 'e' because it's a special secret name) is important because it helps grown-ups understand how things grow when they grow like that – smoothly, all the time, without ever stopping. It's like the secret number for how nature likes to grow things, like how a tree gets taller every moment, or how warm milk gets cooler little by little. It helps us guess how big things will get or how long things will take when they change smoothly, like magic!

title: What is a non newtonian fluid and what makes them special?
text: Imagine you have a super cool puddle of goo, like the stuff you make with cornstarch and water, or maybe some slime! Most liquids, like your juice or water in the bathtub, always act the same way: they splash and flow no matter how you touch them. But this special goo, called a non-Newtonian fluid, is a bit of a trickster! If you put your finger in it very slowly, it feels all squishy and wet, just like water. But if you try to punch it really fast, or stomp on it with your foot, suddenly it feels super hard, like a rock! It's special because it changes its mind and decides to be soft or hard depending on how quickly you push or pull on it. It's like magic goo that can be a liquid *and* a solid, just by how you play with it!

title: What are the pros and cons to Globalism, from an (as much as possible) unbiased perspective?
text:
Imagine all the houses in the world are like one giant playground, and all the kids (that's us!) are playing together, sharing toys, snacks, and ideas.

The *good things* about this big playground (we call that globalism!) are:
You get to play with super cool toys and try yummy snacks from *all over* the world, not just your own house, which means more fun stuff and choices for everyone! Sometimes, when lots of people share and make things together, the toys and snacks can even be cheaper for your grown-ups to buy. We also learn new games, songs, and clever ways to build things from friends who live very far away, making everyone smarter and more creative. And if one friend on the playground is sad or needs help, all the other friends can work together to make things better.

But there are also some *not-so-good things*:
Sometimes, if everyone buys toys from very far away, the grown-ups who

title: How would somebody create a new programming language?
text: Imagine you have a toy robot, but it only understands a few boring words like "move left" and "move right." You want to tell it to "dance" or "make a yummy cookie!" So, you decide to make up your very own special language for it! First, you make a list of all your new words, like "dance" and "cookie," and decide exactly what each word means the robot should *do*. Does "dance" mean wiggle its arms, or spin around? You write down all these rules. Then, you build a super-duper smart translator machine. This machine knows *your* new special words and also knows the robot's old boring language. So, when you say "dance" in your new language, the translator machine quickly turns it into all the old boring "move left, move right" commands the robot understands, and the robot starts dancing! You keep adding new words and rules, and teach them to your translator, until you have a whole new way to tell the robot anything you want!

title: why is it that the more I look at a word, it begins to look like its not spelled correctly?
text: Imagine you have a favorite toy car. When you first look at it, you know it's a car, and you think about driving it and playing. But if you stare at just one wheel, or just the door, for a very, very long time, it stops looking like a car part and just looks like a round thing, or a flat thing that doesn't make sense anymore! Your brain usually looks at a whole word and knows what it means super fast, like knowing your toy is a car. But if you keep staring and staring at just one word, your brain gets tired of thinking about what it *means*. Instead, it starts to look at all the little lines and curves that make up each letter, like looking at just the wheel of your car. When it only sees the lines and not the meaning, the word can start to look funny and strange, like it's not put together right, even though it is!
