title: What is the difference between a sociopath and a psychopath?
text: Imagine two kids who sometimes don't play fair and don't seem to feel bad about it. One kid, let's call them the **P-Kid (psychopath)**, was born with a little switch in their brain that helps them feel sad or sorry for others, and that switch just isn't there. They don't *feel* bad, even if they pretend to be your best friend to get what they want, and they're very good at planning sneaky things. The other kid, the **S-Kid (sociopath)**, was born with that feeling switch, but maybe because of really tough or sad things that happened when they were little, their switch got broken or they learned to turn it off. They might get angry really fast and do naughty things without thinking, and they find it harder to pretend to be nice or have many friends. So, the

title: Why hasn't the popularity of Warby Parker lowered the price of any other glasses brand?
text:
Okay, imagine you want a special toy, like a new pair of glasses!

Warby Parker is like a special toy shop that makes its own toys and sells them straight to you, without anyone else in the middle. So, they can sell their toys for less money. Yay!

But other glasses shops are like different toy shops. They buy their toys from a big factory, then a big truck takes

title: Could you ever, in theory, have such a large density of radiation particles that you could see them?
text: No, not really! Imagine you have a tiny, tiny little invisible speck, like a super-duper small ghost that you can't ever see, no matter how close you look. Radiation particles are even tinier than that! Your eyes need something big enough for light to bounce off of so you can see it, like your teddy bear or a big cloud. Even if you had a super, super huge pile of these invisible ghost specks, like all the sand on the beach, they're still too small for your eyes to ever catch them and see them directly. Sometimes, when these invisible specks zip very fast and hit something else, like a special screen or even the air, they can make a tiny flash of light or a little glow, like a mini firefly. But you're seeing the *flash* they made, not the invisible speck itself. So, the tiny radiation bits themselves are always too small and too invisible for your eyes to ever see, no matter how many there are!

title: Why does water taste bitter after eating pineapples?
text: Okay, imagine pineapples have tiny, playful little tickle monsters inside them! When you eat pineapple, these tickle monsters jump onto your tongue and the inside of your mouth, and they start doing little tickles and nibbles. They're not hurting you, but they're so busy tickling that they make your mouth feel a bit funny and confused. So, when you drink plain water right after, your mouth is still feeling all those tickles and nibbles from the pineapple monsters, and it makes the water taste yucky or bitter instead of nice and fresh. Once the tickle monsters go away, your mouth feels normal again, and water tastes yummy!

title: Why can we "feel" someone's gaze on us?
text: You know how sometimes you feel like someone is looking at you, even if you're not looking at them? It's a super interesting feeling! It's not because their eyes have a special superpower beam that tickles you. What actually happens is your brain is like a super-duper detective! Even when you're looking straight ahead, your brain can still see tiny, tiny things out of the corner of your eye, like a little movement, or a shadow shifting, or even hear a super quiet sound like someone turning their head a tiny bit. Your brain puts all these little clues together really, really fast and says, "Hey, someone might be looking!" Sometimes it's right, and sometimes it's just a funny trick your brain plays, but it's mostly your amazing brain being super smart and noticing things you don't even know you're noticing!

title: When a meteorite strikes a planet and leaves a crater, why is there a big hole but no meteorite in it?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super-duper fast toy car, like a rocket car! If you crash that car into a big pile of sand really, really fast, what happens? The car doesn't just sit perfectly in the sand, right? It probably breaks into lots of little pieces, and makes a big splash of sand fly everywhere! Well, a space rock, called a meteorite, is like that rocket car, but it's going even, *even* faster when it hits a planet. When it smashes into the ground, it goes with such a big *WHUMP* that it doesn't just make a hole and stay there. Instead, the space rock itself breaks into a million tiny, tiny pieces, like dust and little pebbles, and gets mixed up with all the dirt and rocks that it throws out to make the big round hole. So, it's still there, but it's all broken up and spread out, almost like it went *poof!* when it made the crater!

title: What happens to all the stuff people leave on graves in cemeteries?
text: You know how when you leave your toys out, sometimes mom or dad helps you put them away to keep your room tidy? Cemeteries are like a big, quiet garden where people go to remember someone they love. When people leave pretty flowers or little toys, it's like leaving a special message. But just like flowers at home eventually get sleepy and droopy, the flowers at the cemetery do too. And sometimes the wind blows things around or they get a bit dirty. So, there are kind people who work at the cemetery, like special gardeners. Their job is to gently pick up the old, sleepy flowers and tidy up any toys that might have gotten messy or broken. They do this so the whole garden stays beautiful and peaceful for everyone who comes to visit and remember their special people. It's all about keeping the garden neat and respectful.

title: Why are rings easier to get on than they are to get off a finger?
text: Imagine your finger is like a soft, squishy marshmallow, and the ring is a little hoop. When you put the ring *on*, your marshmallow finger can squish down just a tiny bit to let the ring slide over the smooth part, easy peasy! But when you try to take the ring *off*, it has to go over a bigger, bumpier part of your marshmallow finger called your knuckle. It's like the marshmallow gets a little fatter there, and sometimes the skin on your finger gets all bunched up, making it feel super tight and tricky to pull over that big bump, like trying to pull a sock off when your heel gets stuck!

title: when sea levels rise, do they do so by an equal amount across the globe?
text: No, it's not like filling up a perfectly flat bathtub where the water goes up exactly the same everywhere! The ocean is super big and has lots of wobbly bits and different

title: Why do women open their mouths when they put on eye makeup?
text: Imagine you're trying to draw a tiny, perfect picture right next to your eye with a little brush. Your eyes naturally want to blink and close whenever something gets super close, right? That would make the picture messy! So, when grown-ups open their mouths really wide, it's like their face muscles stretch out a little bit, especially around their eyes. This stretching makes it harder for their eyes to blink or wiggle around, almost like holding them still. It helps them keep their eyes steady and open just long enough to draw that perfect, tiny picture without making a mistake!

title: How do air-conditioners work?
text: Imagine your house is a big box, and it's too hot inside! An air-conditioner is like a magic helper that takes all the hotness from inside your house and throws it outside. It has special pipes with a special liquid inside, kind of like a secret juice. Inside your house, this juice gets super cold, like an ice pop, and when a fan blows air over it, the air gets cold too! This cold juice actually "drinks" all the heat from your room, turning into a puffy cloud. This puffy cloud then travels to the outside part of the air-

title: Why cant we develop a legitimately healthy cigarette thats as good as a normal one?
text: Okay, imagine a yummy cookie! The part that makes it so yummy is the sugar and chocolate, right? But if you eat too many, it's not good for your tummy. Now, a grown-up cigarette is kind of like that. It has a special "happy dust" inside called nicotine that makes grown-ups feel a certain way, and they like the puffing part. But when you light it up, it makes lots and lots of smoky, yucky stuff, like tiny invisible monsters flying into your body. These smoky monsters are what hurt your body inside, like making your lungs sick. If we tried to make a "healthy" cigarette, it would be like trying to make that super yummy cookie without *any* sugar or chocolate – it just wouldn't be the same cookie anymore! The smoky, yucky stuff *is* part of how the cigarette works and how it gives the grown-up that feeling, even though it's bad for you. So, to make it truly healthy, you'd have to take away all the yucky

title: Why are US troops being deployed to Poland?
text: Okay, imagine your friend lives next door, and there's a big kid down the street who sometimes isn't very nice to his own neighbors. So, your grown-ups (the US) are sending some strong, helpful grown-ups (the troops) to go stay at your friend's house (Poland) for a little while. They're not going there to start a fight, but just to be there to make sure your friend feels safe and strong, and to tell the big kid, "Hey, don't even *think* about bothering our friend, because we're here to help them!" It's like having a big brother watch out for you.

title: How do hard drives get bigger in capacity, but physically smaller in size?
text:
Okay, imagine your hard drive is like a super special tiny library where all your games, pictures, and videos live.

**To make it hold MORE books (bigger capacity):**

title: Why haven't the large space rocks in the Asteroid Belt and Kuiper belt coalesced to form large planets due to their gravity?
text: Imagine you have lots of little LEGO bricks floating in space. For the ones in the Asteroid Belt, there's a super-duper big kid named Jupiter who keeps running past and shaking the whole table! This makes all the little LEGOs bounce around too fast to gently stick together and build one giant LEGO house (a planet). They just keep crashing into each other instead of building. For the rocks in the Kuiper Belt, it's like the LEGOs are spread out *really, really* far apart, like one in your room and one all the way down the street! There aren't enough close together to easily find each other and stick to make a big planet, and there just wasn't as much stuff there to begin with.

title: Why do some substances feel colder than others in the same temperature?
text: Okay, imagine your hand is like a warm, cozy little heater! Everything around you, even things that feel cold, has a little bit of warmth in it, too. Your hand always wants to share its warmth with things that have less. Some things, like a metal spoon, are super good at taking your warmth away really fast, almost like they're sucking it right out! When your hand loses its warmth quickly, it feels chilly. Other things, like a wooden block or a fluffy blanket, aren't very good at taking your warmth away quickly. They let your hand keep its warmth for longer, so it doesn't feel as chilly, even if they're actually the same temperature as the metal spoon. It's all about how fast they can steal your hand's warmth!

title: What would the physical process of gene editing through such things as CRISPR look like?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a giant LEGO castle, and each tiny LEGO brick has a little instruction written on it, like "make a blue wall" or "make a red roof." Sometimes, one of those instructions gets a little messed up, like it says "make a purple roof" when it should be red. What scientists do with special tools like CRISPR is like having super tiny, super smart scissors and a tiny eraser. You can't *see* these tiny scissors working inside the LEGO brick itself because it's so incredibly small – way smaller than a speck of dust! But what you *would* see is a scientist in a special room, looking through a giant magnifying glass called a microscope to see the tiny LEGO bricks (which are called 'cells'). They use a super tiny squirty tool, like a very, very small eyedropper, to put the tiny scissors and a new, correct instruction right next to the messed-up LEGO brick. Then, the tiny scissors snip out the wrong word, or the eraser rubs it away, and a new, correct word pops in. You

title: why does splitting (sub-)atomic particles release SO much energy?
text: Imagine you have a super, super tiny toy, so small you can't even see it! Inside this tiny toy, there are even tinier, tinier bits all squished and stuck together really, really, really tight with super, super strong sticky stuff. It takes a HUGE amount of effort to keep them all squished together like that. Now, if you could somehow break open that tiny toy and pull those little bits apart, all that super strong sticky stuff that was holding them together suddenly lets go! And when it lets go, it makes a really, really big burst of energy, like a huge whoosh of heat and light and zoomy power, because all that effort to keep them squished together just got released all at once, even from just one tiny, tiny toy!

title: Why is 'foo' and 'bar' used so much when explaining programming?
text: Imagine you're playing with your toys, and you want to show your friend how to put them in a box, but it doesn't matter if you use your red car or your blue car, or if the box is for blocks or teddies. You just need *any* toy and *any* box to show the idea! In computer programming, 'foo' and 'bar' are like those "any toy" or "any box" names. They're just silly, made-up words that don't mean anything special, so when grown-ups are showing you how to make computers do things, they can use 'foo' and 'bar' to show you the *idea* without making you think about a *real* name for something. It's like saying "this thingy" or "that whatchamacallit" when you just need a placeholder. They're short, easy to type, and have been used for a super long time, so everyone just knows what they mean: "This is just an example, don't worry about the name right now!"

title: Why do countries (like the US) not include tax in their price tags?
text: Okay, imagine you want to buy a super cool toy car, and the sticker says it costs $10. But then, when your mommy or daddy goes to pay at the big machine, the number actually goes up a tiny bit, maybe to $10.50! That extra little bit is called "tax." The reason it's not on the sticker from the beginning is because the grown-ups who make the rules decided it's easier that way. Sometimes, if you buy the same toy car in a different town or a different state, the extra "tax" money is a little different – like how your friend might have a different amount of cookies than you! Also, sometimes what you buy changes how much tax there is; a yummy snack might have a different "tax" than a toy. So, instead of making hundreds and hundreds of different stickers for every single toy and every single town, they just add that little extra "tax" money at the very end when you pay, so everyone knows exactly how much extra to pay for things like roads and schools, no matter where they are or what they're buying!

title: Why does the sensation of getting your head scratched from someone else feel better than scratching your own head?
text: It's like when you try to tickle yourself – it's not as funny as when someone else tickles you, right? That's because your clever brain knows *you're* going to do it, so it doesn't get as surprised or excited! But when someone *else* scratches your head, your brain is like, 'Wow! What's this new, nice feeling?!' and it feels extra special and super good! Plus, sometimes mommy or daddy can reach those tricky spots you can't quite get, and it just feels really nice when someone else does something kind for you, like a little head massage!

title: Why does the brain tend to constantly play music on its own ?
text: You know how sometimes a song just gets stuck in your head, like a little radio is playing it over and over, even when there's no music on? Well, your brain is like a super special memory box that keeps all the fun things you hear and see! When you hear a song a lot, especially if it has a really happy beat or cool words, your brain thinks, "Wow, that's a super fun song!" And just like how you might want to play with your favorite toy again and again, your brain likes to 'play' that song in your mind. It's not a real radio, but your brain is just practicing remembering the song and having a little sing-along inside your head because it thinks it's a fun tune! Sometimes it gets a little bit stuck because your brain really, really likes it and wants to keep remembering it for you.

title: What causes prolonged drowsiness/grogginess several hours after waking up?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super cool toy that needs to charge its batteries every night when you sleep. When you wake up, you should feel full of energy, like your toy is 100% charged and ready to play! But sometimes, if you didn't sleep for long enough, or if your sleep wasn

title: Why do some people "run hot" while others "run cold?"
text: Imagine everyone has a little oven inside their tummy that makes warmth, just like when you bake cookies! For some people, their oven is just naturally set a tiny bit higher, so their body makes more heat, and they feel warmer all the time. We call this "running hot." For other people, their oven is set a little lower, or maybe they're like a little house with thinner walls, so the warmth escapes a bit faster, and they feel colder easily. We call this "running cold." This can happen because of how fast their body's engine works (like some toy cars go faster than others!), or how big or small they are, or even how much snuggly fat or strong muscle they have, which can act like a warm blanket. So, everyone's body is just a little bit different, like different kinds of comfy houses, and that's totally okay!

title: From a tap, why is a low-pressure stream clear, and a high-pressure stream white?
text: Imagine your tap is like a tiny water slide! When the water comes out *gently* (low pressure), it's like a calm river, and you can see right through it, clear as glass. But when the water comes out *super fast* and strong (high pressure), it's like a big splash! That fast water grabs lots and lots of super tiny, invisible air bubbles, like tiny pieces of air candy. All those tiny air candies mixed in make the water look cloudy and white, just like how milk is white! When those tiny air candies float away and pop, the water goes back to being clear again.

title: why does looking at a bright light cause our eyes to feel pain?
text: Imagine your eyes are like two special cameras that help you see the world, and they have little curtains inside that open and close to let just the right amount of light in, like your bedroom curtains. When it's dark, those curtains open wide to let lots of light in so you can see. But when you look at a super, super bright light, like the sun or a really strong flashlight, it's like someone is trying to pour a whole bucket of water into a tiny little cup really fast – it's just too much! Your eyes get overwhelmed because there's way too much light trying to get in all at once, and they say "Ouch! That hurts!" That pain is your eyes' way of telling your brain, "Quick, look away or close your eyes, because this much light is too strong and can make us feel owie and even break some of our important seeing parts!" It's like a special alarm bell to keep your eyes safe.

title: Who is Brodin and what is /r/swoleacceptance all about?
text: Brodin is like a pretend superhero, a super-duper strong guy who lives in the sky! He loves it when people eat their yummy healthy food, like chicken and vegetables, and play games that make their muscles strong, like lifting big toy blocks or running super fast. He wants everyone to be healthy and strong and proud of their bodies! And /r/swoleacceptance is like a fun club on the internet, a special place where grown-ups who love to get strong and healthy hang out. They pretend Brodin is their helper, and they talk about how much fun it is to make their muscles big and strong, just like when you grow bigger and bigger every year! They cheer each other on to eat good food and play lots of active games so everyone can be healthy and happy with their strong bodies. It's all about

title: Why do your hands tend to shake when you try to hold something still?
text: Imagine your arms have lots of tiny, strong helpers called muscles. When you want to hold a toy super still, like a statue, all those little helpers are working really, really hard. They're trying to pull your arm in just the right way to keep it from moving, even against gravity trying to pull it down. It's like they're having a tiny tug-of-war to stay perfectly balanced! But even strong helpers get a little tired after a while, just like you get tired after running a lot. When they get tired, they can't pull quite as smoothly or steadily anymore. They start doing tiny, quick little wiggles and jiggles instead of one big, steady pull. Your brain is still trying to tell them, "STAY STILL!", but the tired helpers just can't quite listen perfectly, so your hand does a little dance!

title: Why are multiple blades needed for a closer shave?
text: Imagine your tiny hairs are like little blades of grass poking out of your skin. If you only have one scissor blade, it just snips the top of the grass right where it is. But if you have *lots* of blades working together, it's like a clever team! The first blade comes along and gently tugs the hair up just a tiny, tiny bit, like giving it a little stretch. Then, super fast, before the hair can go back down, the *next* blade comes right behind it and snips it off while it's still pulled up! So, when the hair lets go and goes back into its little spot, it's actually cut even shorter than if it was just snipped at the very top, making your skin feel super smooth, like the hair is hiding a little bit inside.

title: Why does water not always act as a lubricant?
text: Imagine you have two toys and you want them to slide past each other super easily, like on a super slippery slide! A lubricant is like a special, super-duper gooey juice, like

title: Toe curling? Why do we involuntarily curl our toes if something feels particularly good?
text: Imagine your body is like a big house with lots of wires, and your brain is the boss of the house! When something feels super, super good, like a yummy cookie or a warm snuggle, your brain gets really, really excited, like it's jumping up and down! When your brain gets that excited, it sends out little happy electricity signals all over your body, like tiny little sparks. Sometimes, those sparks go all the way down to your toes and make them wiggle and squeeze tight, almost like your toes are saying "Yay!" too, or trying to grab onto that super good feeling! It's just your body's way of showing how much it loves something that feels extra special.

title: 'Colon cancer','breast cancer', 'prostate cancer'... Do cancerous growths never originate in muscle tissues like arms or calves?
text: Imagine your body is like a big LEGO castle, and all the little LEGO bricks are your body's tiny building blocks called cells. Sometimes, these little blocks get old or broken, so your body makes new ones to replace them, like a busy LEGO

title: What safeguards are in place, in the U.S.A., to stop a rogue president from using nuclear weapons?
text: Imagine our country has a super-duper powerful toy, like a giant firework that could make a very, very big boom and hurt lots of people and places. It's kept super safe

title: A woman in the U.S. was killed by a superbug resistant to all known antibiotics. Why can't our adaptive immune system fight off bacteria? Isn't that why the immune system is a) there and b) adaptive?
text: Imagine your body has tiny superheroes inside, called your immune system! Their job is to keep you safe from bad guys, like tiny germs that try to make you sick. Your superheroes are super smart because they're "adaptive" – that means when they see a new bad guy, they learn its face and how to fight it extra well, so next time it's easier to catch.

title: Troops in Poland. Why are they needed or why are they so happy we were there?
text: Imagine Poland is your friend, and sometimes there's a big, grumpy kid (Russia) next door who likes to push other kids around. Poland might feel a little bit scared that the grumpy kid might try to push them too. So, your other friends, like us, send some of our strong, grown-up helpers (soldiers) to stand with Poland. These helpers are like big brothers or bodyguards. They don't want to fight, but they stand there to show the grumpy kid that Poland has lots of friends who care about them and will help if needed. This makes Poland feel super safe and happy, because they know their friends are close by, ready to look out for them, just like having your mommy or daddy close when you're scared of a monster under the bed!

title: What's the difference between "I'm stressed" and "I'm anxious"?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big pile of toys to clean up super fast before your friend comes over, and it feels like too much to do – that feeling of having too many things right now that make you feel squished and busy is like being **stressed**. It's usually because of something big happening right now or very, very soon that you know about. Now, imagine you're sitting quietly, and suddenly your tummy feels a bit wiggly and you start to worry about if it will rain tomorrow for your picnic, even though you don't see any clouds right now – that feeling of worrying about things that *might* happen later, even if you don't know exactly what or if it will even happen, is like being **anxious**. So, stressed is usually about a lot of stuff happening *now*, and anxious is more about worrying about things that *might* happen in the future.

title: What is a "Windows X System" in relation to operating systems?
text: Okay, that's a bit of a tricky name, because it's actually two different things that don't usually go together! Imagine your computer is like a big toy box. One kind of toy box helper is called "Windows," and it's the most popular one that makes all the pretty pictures and games show up on your screen, like when you play ABC Mouse or watch Paw Patrol. It's like the main manager of your toy box. The "X System" is a totally different kind of helper, usually for different kinds of toy boxes (like ones called "Linux"), and its job is to help those toy boxes draw their pictures and buttons on the screen. So, "Windows X System" isn't really a thing, because they are two separate big helpers for different kinds of computers, like having two different kinds of teachers for two different schools!

title: Is there any animal in the wild that dies of old age like humans do?
text: You know how Grandma and Grandpa get older and sometimes they get tired more easily, and their bodies don't work as fast as they used to? Animals in the wild get old too, just like people! Their legs get slower, their eyes don't see as well, and it's harder for them to run and jump. But here's the tricky part: wild animals don't have a comfy house, a doctor, or someone bringing them food every day like we do. They have to run super fast to catch their dinner or run away from bigger animals that want to eat *them*. So, when an animal gets really old and slow, it becomes very, very hard for them to find food, or they can't run fast enough to escape a 'bad guy' animal. Most of the time, before their body just completely stops working from being super old, something else happens first because they can't take care of themselves anymore – they might get too hungry, or another animal might catch them because they're too slow. So, while their bodies *do* get old and worn out like ours, they usually don't just die peacefully in their sleep because of old age in the same way a human might; their old age makes them vulnerable to other things happening.

title: How does mutation in bacteria work and what exactly forms superbugs (antibiotic resistent)?
text: Imagine tiny, tiny invisible critters called bacteria living all around us, some make us feel yucky. Inside each critter is like a special instruction book telling it how to be. When these critters

title: who discovered the act of smoking? And why is it that only a handful of plants can be smoked?
text: Imagine a super, super long time ago, before even your great-great-great-grandparents were born! People were exploring the world, just like you explore your backyard. Nobody knows *exactly* who the first person was to try smoking, because it wasn't one single person like how nobody knows who was the first person to try eating a strawberry! People just discovered it over many, many years. They saw smoke from fires and probably tried burning different dried leaves, maybe noticing some made a funny smell or feeling. They found special plants, like the tobacco plant, that when dried and burned, made smoke that people used. Now, why can't we smoke all the plants in the garden? Well

title: Why do we feel extremely weak right before throwing up?
text: Okay, imagine your tummy feels really, really yucky, like there's something inside that needs to come out! Your body is super smart, and it knows a big job is coming (throwing up). So, it tries to save all its power and energy just for that one big push. It's like when you're about to do something hard, your body gets very focused and doesn't want to run around and play. It also makes your blood move around a little differently to get ready, which can make you feel super wobbly and tired, like all your energy just went 'poof!' because your body is busy getting ready to make the yucky stuff go away quickly.

title: How does externally applied "fat burning" gels work?
text: Imagine your body has tiny little energy storage pouches, like small balloons full of fuel. When you run, jump, and play a lot, your body uses that fuel, and the balloons get smaller

title: Why is it sometimes easy to peel a hard-boiled egg, while other times the shell sticks and fragments into bazillions of tiny pieces?
text: Imagine your egg has a super thin, invisible sticker right under its hard shell! When the egg is super, super fresh, that sticker is super, super sticky, like trying to peel a brand new sticker that doesn't want to come off! It's glued so tight to the shell that when you try to peel, it rips everything into tiny pieces. But when an egg is a little bit older, that sticker gets just a tiny bit less sticky. Also, if you make your egg cold really fast after cooking it, like giving it a quick ice bath, it helps that sticker shrink away from the shell a little bit. So, if your egg is older and you cool it fast, the sticker isn't so sticky and shrinks, making the shell just pop right off! But if your egg is super fresh and doesn't get cold fast, that sticker holds on tight, and the shell breaks into a bazillion tiny pieces because it's so stuck!

title: If organic life emerged on Earth from the physical state of the universe to be carbon-based, why do we assume that life elsewhere would be radically different if the rough distribution of elements throughout the universe is the same?
text: Okay, imagine you have a giant box of LEGOs, and those LEGOs are all the little tiny pieces that make up everything in the whole universe, like stars and planets and even you! Our bodies are made mostly out of special LEGO pieces called 'carbon' because carbon LEGOs are super good at sticking together in lots of different ways to build complicated things, like us! Now, it's true that if you look in other parts of the universe, you'll find the same kinds of LEGO bricks, like carbon, everywhere. But even if you have the exact same box of LEGOs, you can build *so many* different things, right? You could build a house, or a car, or a rocket! So, even though carbon is a great builder, maybe on another planet, the LEGO bricks are put together in a slightly different way because it's super hot there, or super cold, or there's different air. They might find a different kind of LEGO brick works even better for *their* special planet, or they just found a totally different, super clever way to build themselves that doesn't use as much carbon, even if carbon is still around. It's like everyone has the same toy box, but not everyone builds the exact same toy!

title: Why Are Cane Fields Burned After A Harvest?
text: Imagine you have a big, tall plant, like a giant grass, called sugarcane! When it's time to pick the yummy sweet parts, there are lots of dry, pokey leaves and messy bits left behind, like old wrappers after you open a present. Sometimes, little bugs or even snakes like to hide in all that mess! So, farmers light a very quick, careful fire that just burns away all the dry leaves and yucky stuff super fast. This makes it much easier and safer for them to get to the good, sweet sugarcane stalks without getting poked or finding any creepy crawlies. It's like cleaning up your room quickly so you can find your favorite toy!

title: How does getting a loan as a nation work? And how can they pay it back?
text: Imagine your mommy or daddy wants to buy a really big, cool new toy for everyone, like a super fast car or a giant slide for the park, but they don't have all the money

title: When singing, what is the difference in how your "head voice" and "chest voice" are produced?
text: Okay, imagine you have two special stretchy rubber bands inside your throat, called your vocal cords, and they wiggle super fast to make sounds! When you sing with your "chest voice," it's like those rubber bands are thick and floppy, and they wiggle *all* the way, making a big, rumbling sound, like a giant truck. You can feel that rumbling buzzing right in your chest, like a drum! This is how you usually talk and sing your low, strong notes. But when you sing with your "head voice," those stretchy rubber bands get thin and tight, and only their very edges wiggle, like a tiny bee buzzing. It makes a lighter, higher sound, like a whistle or a little bird, and you feel that buzzing up in your nose or forehead, like a balloon getting full! This is how you sing high, floaty notes and make soft, pretty sounds.

title: What makes eczema incurable?
text: Imagine your skin is like a super special coat that keeps you safe and sound. For most kids, their coat is super strong and always happy. But if you have eczema, your skin coat is a little bit extra sensitive, like it gets grumpy easily! It's not like a boo-boo that just heals up, or a germ that a doctor can make go away forever with a shot. Instead, it's just how your body is made from the very beginning, like how you have a certain color hair or eyes – we can't change that part of you. So, doctors can give you special lotions that are like soft, cuddly hugs for your skin, and sometimes gentle medicines, to make your grumpy skin coat feel much, much better and stop being so itchy, even though we can't change how your body was built.

title: What is so groundbreaking about the Amiga?
text: Imagine you have a toy box, and all the other toy boxes just have boring old grey blocks and make funny beeps. But then, the Amiga toy box came along, and suddenly, it was full of super bright, colorful blocks, like all the colors of the rainbow! And when you played with it, the pictures moved super smoothly, like a real cartoon, not all jumpy. And it didn't just make beeps, it played real music, like a whole band was inside, and you could hear sounds from two different places at once! Plus, it was super clever, like it had many little brains, so it could draw a picture, play music, and get ready for your game all at the same time without getting tired or slow. It was like magic, making computers do things no one thought they could do before, making games and cool drawings and music way better than any other computer around!

title: How are people able to trick themselves into remembering something that never happened?
text: Your brain is like a super special camera that takes pictures of everything you do and see, but it's also like a storyteller! Sometimes, your brain's camera gets a little blurry or the storyteller gets a bit mixed up and adds parts that didn't really happen, just like when you dream about flying. Or, if someone tells you a story, like "Remember when you saw a giant cookie monster?" and you think about it a lot, your brain might start to build a pretend memory around it! It's like your brain tries to fill in the blanks, but instead of using real memories, it makes up new ones that feel super real to you, even though they were just pretend.

title: Why do museums prohibit taking pictures with flash on even though the artifacts are exposed to natural and other lights the whole day?
text: Imagine your favorite drawing. If you leave it in the gentle sunshine all day, it might slowly, slowly start to lose its bright colors over many, many years, right? That's kind of like the soft lights in the museum – they're gentle, like sleepy sunshine, and the old things are used

title: I know that people are born with perfect pitch, but what causes certain people to have it over others?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a super-duper computer, and for most of us, when we hear a sound, our computer knows if it's high or low,

title: Why do we wake up early when we don't have to but tend to wake up late when we need to be up?
text: Imagine your body has a special clock inside, like the one on the wall, but it's just for you! When you don't have to go to school or do anything important, your body clock just wakes you up naturally when it thinks you've had enough sleep, like a little bird chirping when the sun comes up. It's just doing

title: Why does your brain sometimes refuse to recall something until you stop trying to remember it?
text: Imagine your brain is like a big toy box, and all your memories are like different toys inside. When you're trying really hard to remember something, it's like you're digging super fast and excitedly through the toy box, throwing things everywhere to find one special toy. You're making such a big mess that it's actually harder to see the toy, even if it's right there! Your brain gets all jumbled up and "stuck" in the digging. But if you stop digging, take a little break, and maybe go play with something else for a bit, your brain can quietly and neatly sort through the toys on its own, like a grown-up cleaning up the box. And *poof*! Suddenly, without even trying, your brain finds that special toy and shows it to you! It was there all along, your brain just needed a little quiet time to find it without you making a big fuss.

title: Why does water expire?
text: Water itself is like a superhero that never gets old! It stays water forever. But the *bottle* it lives in can get a bit tired. Sometimes, tiny, tiny bits of the plastic bottle might decide to take a swim in the water, or if the bottle has been open, invisible little 'germs' from the air might jump in and want to play. These tiny bits or germs can make the water not taste super yummy anymore, or even make your tummy feel a bit funny, not because the water changed, but because of its old home or the tiny visitors!

title: What's the difference between a motel and a hotel??
text: Imagine you're going on a sleepover away from home! A **hotel** is usually a really tall building, like a big stack of blocks, and all the rooms are *inside* on different floors. You go through a big front door, maybe ride an elevator, and walk down a long hallway to find your room. They often have fun stuff inside, like a swimming pool or a restaurant. A **motel** is usually a much shorter building, like a long line of little houses all connected. You drive your car right up to your room's door, and your door opens straight to the outside, not into a hallway. It's super easy to get your bags right from your car into your room!

title: ٌWhat is the most important factor someone's larynx have in order to make one have a "powerful voice"?
text: Imagine your voice box (that's your larynx!) is like a tiny musical instrument in your throat. Inside, it has two little rubber bands called vocal cords. When you push air from your tummy, these rubber bands wiggle really fast and make sound. To have a super strong, "powerful" voice, like a superhero, the most important thing is that these little rubber bands are nice and thick and can wiggle really, really hard and fast when you push lots of air. Thicker, longer rubber bands just make a bigger, stronger sound!

title: Why can't we just dump garbage into volcanoes?
text: Imagine a volcano is like a giant, super-duper hot oven, way hotter than mommy's oven! It's so hot and can explode with fiery goo, which makes it super dangerous to get close to, and we don't want anyone to get hurt trying to throw trash in there. Plus, most volcanoes are way, way up high on big mountains or far away, so it would be super hard and take a very long time to drive all our trash trucks there every single day. And when you burn trash, it makes yucky, stinky smoke, right? Well, if we threw trash into a volcano, it would make even more yucky smoke and stinky gas that would go up into the sky and make the air bad for us to breathe and for all the animals. Also, even though volcanoes are big, they're not big enough to eat *all* the trash from *all* the people in the world, and the hot lava doesn't really make the trash disappear nicely; it just makes a big, stinky, smoky mess that's bad for our beautiful Earth.

title: Why we don't create our own energy for free using magnets? youtube video below
text: Imagine you have a really cool toy car. If you push it, it rolls! But it won't roll forever, right? It slows down and stops. You have to push it again. Magnets are super special and can make things move, and even help make a little bit of electricity if you wiggle them around a special wire, like making a tiny light bulb blink! But just like your toy car, magnets don't have an endless secret supply of pushes inside them to give away for free forever. To keep making electricity, you have to keep wiggling the magnet, and that takes *your* energy. You can't get more energy out than you put in, so while magnets are amazing helpers, they don't make their own energy out of nothing for us to just take forever and ever without doing any work!

title: Why is the average work week so much higher in the United States at 34.40 hours per week in comparison to other countries such as Germany where the average person works 26.37 hours per week?
text: Okay, imagine grown-ups have jobs, like going to school every day. In a place called America, grown-ups usually have to go to their jobs for a bit longer each week

title: Why do so many Train tracks run along creeks and rivers?
text: Imagine your toy train! It's super easy for it to roll on the floor, which is nice and flat, right? It would be really hard to make it climb up a big, bumpy mountain or go down into a deep hole. Well, big trains are the same! Rivers and creeks are like nature's bulldozers because as the water flows, it slowly, slowly makes a nice, flat path for itself through the land, like a long, smooth road that just gently curves. It doesn't go up and down huge hills. So, when people wanted to build tracks for trains, they looked for the easiest, flattest place to put them because it made building the tracks much, much easier and cheaper than trying to cut through big mountains or fill in deep valleys. The river's path was already perfect for the train's special road!

title: The Medal of Freedom has been described as the highest honor for a civilian, yet non-Americans and military have won it. Is it not really for civilians but just humans the president likes?
text: Okay, imagine the Medal of Freedom is like the biggest, shiniest, most special gold star you can get! It's usually for regular people, not soldiers or police officers, who do super amazing things that make the whole world better, like inventing something cool, writing a beautiful song, or helping lots and lots of people. That's why they say 'highest honor for a civilian' – it's for people who are just like you and me, but they did something super-duper special. But sometimes, even if someone lives in a different country, or if they *are* a soldier, they do something so incredibly kind or smart that it helps *everyone*, not just their own country or their soldier job. So, the President (who is like the grown-up in charge of giving out these special stars) says, 'Wow! That person deserves a super shiny star too!' It's not just about who the President likes as a friend, but about celebrating people who have done truly wonderful things to help make the world a happier or smarter place for everyone.

title: Why does the tempo of a certain song seem so different depending on activity level when listening?
text: Imagine you have a favorite toy car. When you run super fast, your toy car looks like it's going really slow, right? But if you're walking super slow, that same toy car looks like it's zooming! The car didn't change how fast it was going; *you* changed. It's the same with music! When you're running and jumping, your heart is beating super fast and you feel all speedy inside. The song feels slow next to your speedy self. But when you're just sitting still and quiet, your body feels slow. So, the song, which is always going at the same speed, feels super fast next to your quiet, slow self. The song is like the toy car, always the same, but how *you* feel makes it seem different!

title: Why is it bad to quickly restart an air conditioner compressor?
text: Okay, imagine your air conditioner has a super strong muscle, like a big arm that pushes air around to make it cold. When it's working, it's pushing really, really hard, like when you push a big, heavy toy box across the room. If you stop pushing the toy box, and then someone tells you to push it again *right away* before you've had a tiny rest, it's much, much harder, right? Your arm might get super tired or even hurt! It's the same for the air conditioner's muscle. After it's been pushing hard, there's still a lot of pushy air inside it. It needs a little bit of time, like a few minutes, for that pushy air to settle down and relax. If you try to make it start pushing again *too quickly* when everything is still super tight, it has to work extra, extra hard, uses too much power, gets super hot, and it could get broken or tired out much faster. So, we let it rest a tiny bit so it can start fresh and work well for a long, long time!

title: What is the deal with the newly discovered organ? How come we didn't categorize it before?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big house with lots of different special rooms, like your heart room that pumps blood, or your stomach room that squishes food. This 'new organ' isn

title: How much of an advantage (if any) does being overweight give someone in terms of starvation?
text: Imagine your body is like a little house, and food is like the yummy snacks that give your house energy to run and play! When you eat snacks, your house uses some right away, but if there are extra snacks, your body puts them into a special 'snack drawer' (that's your fat!) to save for later. Now, if you can't get any new snacks for a very, very long time (like if the snack shop is closed forever!), your body starts to use the snacks from its special snack drawer. If someone is a little bit overweight, it means their body has a really big snack drawer with

title: Why does fact checking high ranking officials seem unimportant?
text: Imagine the grown-ups who are in charge are like the principal of your school or the person who decides what we watch on TV. They say lots of things! Sometimes, it feels like checking if what they say is true isn't super important to everyone because: 1. People are super busy, and there are so many grown-ups talking, it's hard to stop and check every single little thing, like trying to listen to all your friends at once on the playground. 2. Some people just trust the big grown-ups because they are big and important, like how you might believe your teacher always knows everything. 3. Sometimes, what the big grown-up says makes people feel happy or makes them think, "Yay! That's what I wanted to hear!" so they don't want to check if it's really, really true, like when someone tells you cookies are a vegetable, and you really want to believe it! But even though it can *seem* unimportant, it's still super important to try and make sure they are telling the truth, so we

title: Sometimes my phone's change with go from say 3% to 7% if I leave it alone for a long time. Is it actually regaining charge?
text: That's a super cool trick your phone does, like a little bit of magic! But your phone isn't actually making new power appear out of nowhere, like a juice box doesn't refill itself. It's more like your phone's little brain gets a bit confused when the battery is super, super low, like 3%. It gets tired and might guess wrong, thinking it has less power than it actually does. When you leave it alone for a while, it gets to rest. During that rest, its brain gets a chance to think, 'Hmm, let me check again, maybe I was wrong before.' And when it checks, it realizes it had a *tiny* bit more power hiding in there than it first thought! So it's not getting more power, it's just getting better at *telling you* how much power it *really* had all along, after a little nap.

title: Why do capacitors make that high pitched sound?
text: You know how sometimes when you tap a tiny glass, it makes a high-pitched *ding*? Well, a capacitor is like a tiny little box inside your electronics that holds electricity. When the electricity goes in and out of it super, super fast, it makes the tiny parts inside the capacitor wiggle and shake just a little bit. Imagine those tiny parts are like super tiny, super fast drumsticks hitting a tiny, tiny drum! Because they're so small and they wiggle so incredibly fast, they push the air around them really quickly, and that makes the air vibrate super fast too, which we hear as that high-pitched *eeeeee* sound. It's like a super tiny, super fast vibration making a tiny little song!

title: How does the media figure out how much money a combination of businesses in an area lost because of being shut down temporarily? (Snow storm, Hurricane, etc.)
text: Imagine all the shops on your street, like the toy store, the candy shop, and the ice cream place. When a big snowstorm or hurricane makes everyone stay home, those shops have to close their doors for a little while, right? So, how do the grown-ups on TV know how much money all those shops together didn't make? Well, it's a bit like this: They ask the grown-ups who own the shops, "How many toys do you usually sell in a day?" or "How many ice creams do you usually scoop?" Then they count how many days the shops were closed. If the toy store usually sells 10 toys a day and was closed for 2 days, that's 20 toys they didn't sell! They do this for lots and lots of shops, and they also think about all the grown-ups who couldn't go to work and make money for their families. They

title: Why do we sometimes experience tremendous mood shifts based upon music?
text: Imagine music is like a special kind of magic sound! When you hear fast, bouncy music, your brain, which is like the boss of your feelings, might think, "Wow, this is fun!" and make you feel super happy and want to dance, just like when you're playing. But if the music is slow and soft, like a lullaby, your brain might think, "Hmm, this feels calm or maybe a little bit quiet," and make you feel sleepy or even a little sad. Sometimes, a song might even remind you of a happy birthday party or a time you missed someone, and your brain remembers those feelings super strongly, making your mood change a lot, like a big switch! It's because the sounds and the memories they bring can make your feelings jump up and down!

title: What happens to a fit, pregnant mother's abdominal muscles during and after pregnancy?
text: Imagine your tummy muscles are like a super strong, stretchy rubber band that goes all the way around your belly. When a mommy has a baby growing inside her, her belly gets bigger and bigger, like a balloon filling with air! So, those strong rubber band muscles have to stretch out *a lot* to make room for the baby. Even if mommy is super strong and fit, those muscles still need to stretch, and sometimes they even move a little bit apart in the middle, like a zipper opening just a tiny bit. After the baby comes out, the belly doesn't need to be so big anymore! So, those stretchy rubber band muscles slowly start to come back together, like the balloon slowly letting air out. It takes a little while, and sometimes they don't go *all* the way back to exactly how they were before, but they get much closer. Being fit helps them be strong and flexible so they can stretch well and then come back nicely, but the biggest job is always making space for the growing baby!

title: What do water towers do?
text: Imagine a really, really big cup of water, super tall, like a giant's drink! That's kind of what a water tower is. It holds lots and lots of water way up high in the sky. When you turn on your faucet at home to get a drink or wash your hands, the water comes out because the water tower is so tall. The water wants to go down, down, down, and that push from being so high up makes it zoom through pipes all the way to your house, so you always have water when you need it!

title: If we as humans exhale CO2, why do some fires like campfires burn more after we blow on them?
text: Imagine fire is like a little hungry monster that needs to eat something special called "oxygen" from the air to get big and strong, just like you need food to grow! When you blow on a campfire, you're like a super strong wind pushing lots and lots of fresh air from all around the fire right into it. This fresh air is full of that yummy oxygen food the fire loves! Even though your breath has a tiny, tiny bit of something called CO2 that the fire doesn't really like, you're bringing a giant pile of its favorite oxygen food along with it. So, the fire gets super excited about all that new oxygen and burns much bigger and brighter, like when you get a big plate of your favorite dinner!

title: Why is it a bad thing if America and Russia become friends?
text: Imagine America and Russia are like two really big kids on a playground, and all the other countries are other kids playing too. If these two really big kids become super-duper best friends and always stick together for everything, sometimes the other smaller kids might start to feel a little bit worried or left out. They might worry that the two big best friends will always decide what games to play or who gets to use the best toys without asking anyone else, or that they might accidentally push other kids around. It's not that being friends is bad, because friends are good, but when two very strong friends are *too* close and always agree on everything, it can sometimes make everyone else feel like they don't have a fair say, or like they might get bossed around. It's usually better when lots of different kids are friends with each other, so everyone feels safe and heard.

title: Why's the Wii U being phased out so early?
text: Okay, imagine the Wii U was like a special toy that Nintendo made. But not as many grown-ups and kids wanted to play with *that specific* toy compared to other toys, or even compared to the old Wii toy. Some grown-ups even got a little confused and thought it was just an add-on for their old Wii, not a brand new toy! And there weren't as many super-duper exciting games that *everyone* just had to play on it. So, after a little while, the people at Nintendo decided, "Hmm, instead of making more of this toy, let's make a brand new, super-duper fun toy that *everyone* will love!" And that's why they made the Nintendo Switch, which got lots and lots of people excited, and they stopped making the Wii U so they could focus on the new, popular one.

title: Why when you have a fever do you feel freezing cold and shiver?
text: Imagine your body has a special thermostat, just like the one in your house that keeps it cozy. When you have a fever, it's like tiny, tricky germs have snuck in and turned your body's thermostat *way up* to a super-hot number! But your body hasn't actually reached that super-hot number yet. So, even though you might feel warm on the outside, your body's thermostat is saying, "Brrr! I'm not hot enough! I need to get hotter!" That's why you feel cold, even when you're already getting warm. And to try and get warmer faster, your body does a little wiggle dance called shivering, which makes your muscles move quickly to try and make more heat, like when you run around and get warm. It's all your body's way of trying to reach that new, higher temperature the tricky germs set!

title: Why are we more creative as children?
text: When you're little, your brain is like a giant, super-duper playground with no rules! You love to make believe, draw purple cats with wings, and build towers out of anything you can find. You don't know all the grown-up rules yet, like "cats aren't purple" or "towers need to be straight," so you just try all sorts of silly, fun things without worrying if it's "right" or if someone will giggle. Grown-ups sometimes learn too many rules and get a little bit scared to try silly things, so their playground gets a little smaller. But your playground is HUGE and full of amazing, brand-new ideas because you're brave and just love to play and imagine!

title: If so many places and products claim to only use "100% Chicken Breast", where does the rest of the chicken go?
text: Imagine a big chicken is like a giant LEGO set! When a restaurant says they only use "100% Chicken Breast," it just means they're picking out that one big, yummy LEGO piece for their food because lots of people really love that part. But don't worry, the rest of the chicken doesn't just disappear! The other parts, like the legs (drumsticks!), wings, and thighs, get sold to other people who love to eat those parts, or they get turned into other yummy things like chicken nuggets, hot dogs, or even used to make chicken soup. Some parts also go to make food for our pets, and even the bones can be used to make things like fertilizer for plants. So, every single part of the chicken is useful and gets used up, just in different ways for different people and different foods!

title: How do chameleons *know* what colour to change to?
text: Chameleons don't really *know* what colour to change to like you know your favorite toy! Instead, their skin has super special tiny little dots, like tiny paint pots, that can open and close. When the sun shines bright, or it gets hot, or if they feel a little bit scared or happy, these tiny paint pots just react all by themselves! It's like their skin is a little robot that automatically changes to help them hide from bigger animals, or sometimes show other chameleons how they're feeling, all without them even thinking about it!

title: How do orchestras know how a song should sound the first time they're playing it?
text: Imagine you have a super special recipe book, but instead of telling you how to make cookies, it tells you how to make music! This book is called "sheet music." It has lots of tiny dots, lines, and squiggly marks, which are like secret codes. These codes tell each musician exactly what sound their instrument should make: "play this note," "play it loud," "play it soft," or "play it fast." But even with a great recipe, you need someone to help everyone cook together, right? That's what the conductor does! They're like the leader with a magic stick (a baton) who shows everyone when to start, how fast to go, and if it should be big and loud or tiny and quiet. So, the musicians read their special music map, and the conductor guides them all, so they know the plan for how the song should sound, even if it's their very first time seeing that particular music! They practice together a few times to make sure everyone is following the map perfectly.

title: Where did the expression "paint the town red" come from? Why the color red?
text: "Paint the town red" means to go out and have a super duper fun party time, like when you run around and play with all your friends and make lots of happy noise! A long, long, long time ago, there was a silly grown-up named Marquess of Waterford, and he went out with his friends in a town called Melton Mowbray. They had so much fun, maybe a little *too* much fun, and they actually got some red paint and painted parts of the town, like doors and gates! They were being a bit naughty, like when you get too excited and make a little mess, but they made a big, red mess! Why red? Well, red

title: Why do we use numerals of base 10 and base 2? Are there any systems with a different base?
text: Imagine you have ten fingers on your hands! That's how we usually count things. We go 1, 2, 3, all the way up to 10, and

title: What is that high pitched tone we get in our ears occasionally for about a second?
text: You know how sometimes your ear makes a little "eeeeee" sound for just a tiny bit? Your ears have super tiny, super delicate hairs inside, like little microphones that help you hear everything. Sometimes, just like how a toy might make a little funny noise when it's turning on or checking if it's working, your ear hairs do something similar. They're just doing a super quick "hello, are we still listening?" check, or maybe one of them got a little sleepy and woke up with a tiny stretch. It's super quick, just a second, and then they go right back to listening to all the sounds around you. It's totally normal and nothing to worry about!

title: Why are the 7 continents when Europe and Asia are basically the same land mass?
text: Imagine the whole world is like a giant playroom with super big carpets! Each big carpet is called a continent. Now, you're super smart to notice that Europe and Asia are like two *really* big carpets that are connected and touch each other, right? You can walk from one to the other without getting wet from the ocean. Even though they're connected, we give them different names because the people who live on the Europe carpet often have different stories, different games, and even speak different sounds than the people on the Asia carpet. It's like how your bedroom and the living room are both in your house and connected, but they have different names because you do different things in them and keep different toys there! For a very, very long time, people just thought of them as different places because the people and their ways of life felt so different, and sometimes big mountains or rivers act like a gentle line between them. So, we keep calling them separate names because of the people, their history, and how they live, even if the land is all one big piece!

title: Why nowadays up to 60% of the people in developed countries have some kind of vision impairment?
text: Imagine your eyes are like two super cool cameras that help you see everything! A long, long time ago, when your grandparents were little, kids spent almost all their time outside. They would run and play, look at birds way up high in the sky, and see trees far, far away. Their eyes got really good at seeing things that were very far away. But

title: How do adult movies film in public places like restaurants or laundromats, or outdoors in the park or the beach?
text: Imagine you want to play a super special game with your friends, maybe at the park or even inside your favorite restaurant. You can't just go and start playing wherever you want, right? You have to ask for permission! Movies are just like that. When people make movies, even grown-up movies, they need to ask the grown-ups in charge. If they want to film in a park or on the beach, they ask the city grown-ups who take care of those places if they can use it for a little while. They usually get a special paper called a "permit" and sometimes pay a little money, like saying "thank you" for borrowing the space. If they want to film inside a restaurant or a laundromat, that's someone's special business, like your house is your family's special place. So, they have to ask the owner of that place, "Please, can we film our movie here?" And usually, they pay the owner some money, like giving them a treat, to say thank you for letting them use their space. So, it's all about asking nicely and getting permission first, no matter what kind of movie

title: How can there be transparent animals, e.g. some fish and frogs. How can they have transparent muscles?
text: Imagine you have a window and a wall. The window is clear because the light from the sun can zoom right through it without bumping into anything! But the wall isn't clear because it's thick and has lots of stuff in it that stops the light. Most animals are like the wall. They have lots of colors in their skin and inside their bodies, and their bones and squishy bits are thick and full of things that block the light. But some special animals are like a super clever window! They don't have many colors in their skin or inside their bodies – they're like plain water, not colorful juice. And even the parts that help them move, their muscles, are made in a very special way. Instead of being thick and bouncy like play-doh, their muscles are super thin and super tidy, almost like clear jelly that's all lined up perfectly. So, when the light

title: What are the benefits of drinking water everyday?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool car, and water is the special, magical fuel it needs every single day! When you drink water, it helps your body work its very best. It helps you run super fast and play without getting too tired. It also helps your brain think clearly so you can learn new things at school and remember all your favorite toys. Water helps your tummy feel good so your food goes down nicely and helps you make good poops. And guess what? It even helps fight off yucky germs so you don't get sick as much! So, drinking water everyday makes your whole body happy, strong, and ready for all your amazing adventures.

title: Why does processed food cost less than organic food when it seems to cost more to produce?
text: Okay, imagine you have two kinds of toys! One toy is made in a giant, super-fast toy factory with big machines that can make a million toys every day! They use special, easy-to-find plastic and paint, and because they make so, so many so quickly, each toy doesn't cost very much. Processed food is like that! Big factories make tons and tons of yummy snacks and meals super fast, using ingredients that are easy to get a lot of and special tricks to make them last a long, long time on the shelf. Because they make so much, each box or bag doesn't cost very much money. Now, imagine another toy that someone makes by hand, very carefully, one at a time, using special wood and natural paints, and it takes them a whole day to make just one! That special toy would cost more, right? Organic food is like that! Farmers grow it very carefully, without special sprays or quick-grow helpers. They have to watch out for bugs and weeds more, and sometimes they don't get as much food from one plant. Because it takes more special care and more time for each apple or carrot, it costs a little bit more money.

title: How do sin, cos, tan and their reciprocals work with angles that are multiples of 90? It seems like the opposite and adjacent wouldn't even be a part of the problem, but that's not what the results say...
text: Okay, imagine you have a magic stick stuck in the ground at one end, and the other end can spin all the way around like a clock hand! When you learned about sin, cos, and

title: In a medium-sized company with computerized accounting systems, why does it take so long to prepare W-2s and get them out?
text: Imagine the company has a giant piggy bank for every single grown-up who works there, and all year long, they put little bits of money into each person's piggy bank for different reasons – some for working, some for doing a super good job, some for their

title: Why can't we draw what we picture in our minds?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper movie projector inside your head! It can play all sorts of cool pictures, like a flying unicorn or a giant ice cream cone. But these pictures are like magic air – you can see them, but you can't *touch* them or *grab* them. When you try to draw, your hand is like a little helper, trying to make the magic air picture turn into a real picture on the paper with crayons. But sometimes, your hand doesn't quite know *exactly* where all the lines and colors go from your magic air picture, because the magic air picture doesn't have real edges for your hand to follow. It's like your brain knows the secret, but your hand hasn't learned *all* the secret steps yet! That's why it's super tricky to make the picture in your head look exactly the same on the paper, even though both are super fun to do!

title: How does soaking in Epsom salts help heal an injury?
text: Imagine you have a boo-boo, like when you bump your leg and it hurts a little. Epsom salts are like special little tiny rocks that you put in your warm bath water, and they melt away! When you sit in the water, some of the special good stuff from those melted rocks goes into your skin, like a tiny little hug for your muscles. It helps your muscles relax and feel less ouchy, and it can make the puffy part of your boo-boo go down a little bit so it doesn't hurt as much. It's like a warm, comfy hug that helps your body feel better and get strong again!

title: Certain blood pressure medications like Nebivolol list "increased weather sensitivity" as their possible side-effects. Is there a known mechanism behind that claim?
text: Okay, imagine your body has lots of tiny, tiny roads where your blood drives around. When you take this special medicine, like Nebivolol, it's like the medicine tells those roads, especially the ones near your skin, to get a little bit wider. This helps your heart not work so hard. Now, when the weather outside changes, like if it gets chilly or rainy, your body usually tries to keep you warm and cozy by making those tiny roads near your skin a little bit smaller, so all the warm blood stays deep inside. But because your medicine is already making them wider, it's harder for your body to squeeze them small. So, it's like your body can't zip up its jacket all the way, and you might feel the cold or the changes in the air a little more strongly than someone whose roads can shrink and grow easily. That's why you might feel the weather more!

title: How can Germany, a country gone to two world wars and severely losing both, still manage to be (comparatively to other countries) one of the richest countries in the world?
text: Imagine Germany was like a big LEGO castle that got broken into tiny pieces, not just once, but twice! It was very, very sad. But after the big fights stopped, some kind grown-up countries, especially one called America, helped Germany get new LEGOs and instructions to start building again. They gave them a lot of help and money to fix their roads, houses, and factories. Then, the people in Germany worked super, super hard, like little busy bees! They were very good at making new, strong things that other countries wanted, like cool cars and big machines. They also learned to be friends with all their neighbours instead of fighting, which is much better for playing and sharing toys. They used their smart brains to make good rules and build things carefully. So, even though their castle was broken twice, they worked hard, got help, learned from their mistakes, and built an even stronger, fancier castle that everyone admired because they were so good at making useful things and being good friends.

title: Why is evidence found illegally by police inadmissible in court?
text: Okay, imagine we're playing a big game, and the police are like special players who have to follow very important rules, just like you have rules at home! If the police are looking for something, like a hidden toy (which is like evidence), but they get it by breaking their own rules – maybe they sneak into your room without asking your parents first, or they peek when they're not supposed to – then even if they find the toy, the judge (who is like the game referee) says, "Whoa, hold on! You cheated to get that toy! Because you didn't follow the rules, we can't use it in our game." It's like if you found a cookie, but you took it from the cookie jar after mommy said "no." Even though you have the cookie, you're not allowed to eat it because you didn't follow the rules. This makes sure that everyone, even the police, always plays fair and follows the rules, so your special private space, like your room, stays safe and private unless they ask nicely first.

title: Is the US actually able to recover from the debt it's in?
text: Imagine the US is like a family, and sometimes they need to buy really big, important things, like building new roads or schools, or helping people. They don't always have all the money right away, so they borrow some from other grown-up friends or big banks. That's what "debt" is – like borrowing your friend's toy and promising to give it back. Now, the US has borrowed a LOT of money, like a super, super big pile of toys! But grown-ups in charge of the country are always working to get more money. People pay a little bit of money when they buy things or when they earn money from their jobs, and that money helps the country. It's like your parents getting their paycheck every week. With that money, they can pay back little bits of what they borrowed, all the time. It's a very, very long process, like a never

title: Why are car manufacturers doing away with traditional gear shifts?
text: Imagine your toy car has a big stick in the middle that you push and pull to make it go faster or slower. That's like the old gear shift! Now, car makers are making it so you just push little buttons or turn a tiny knob instead. Why? Well, it's like magic! When the big stick is gone, there's more space for your juice box or your favorite toy in the car. It's also super easy, just like pushing a button on your tablet, so grown-ups can focus more on watching the road. Plus, new cars are getting super smart and sometimes run on electricity, like a big toy car, and they don't even need that big stick anymore, so little buttons work perfectly! It makes the car feel fancy and modern, like a spaceship!

title: What is Bose Einstein Condensate and how does it look like?
text: Imagine you have lots and lots of tiny, tiny bouncy balls, like super small peas. When it's warm, they all bounce around super fast and bump into each other everywhere, all by themselves! But if you make it *super, super, super* cold, colder than ice cream or even the North Pole, something amazing happens. All those tiny bouncy balls get so tired and cold that they stop bouncing around by themselves. Instead, they all huddle up together and start moving like *one big super bouncy ball*! They all act like one team, doing the exact same thing. That super cold, super team of bouncy balls is called a Bose-Einstein Condensate. It doesn't look like a big solid toy or a puddle of water. It usually looks like a tiny, see-through, hazy cloud or a little blob that just sits there, barely moving, because all the tiny parts are holding hands and moving as one.

title: Is genetic engineering possible to an adult?
text: Imagine your body is like a giant LEGO castle, and each LEGO brick has a tiny instruction on it for what it should do. When you were a tiny baby, your castle was just being built, so it would have been easier to change the main plan for all the bricks. Now that you're a grown-up (or a big 5-year-old!), your castle is already built and all the bricks are in place! It's super, super hard to go back and change *every single instruction* on *every single brick* in your whole body. It would be like trying to rebuild your entire castle, brick by brick, while you're still living in it! But sometimes, if just a *few* bricks are broken or doing something wrong, like a special door that won't open, doctors can sometimes go in and try to fix *just those specific bricks* or add a new, working one. So, we can't really change your *whole* grown-up castle to be totally different, but sometimes we can fix little parts of it if they're not working right.

title: Why haven't all primates entered the stone age yet?
text: Imagine using a special hard rock to help you get yummy food or build a little house – that's kind of like the Stone Age! Not all monkeys and their cousins do this because, well, they don't all *need* to. Some monkeys live where there's so much easy food, like bananas just falling down, that they don't need a rock to help them get it. It's like if your snack was always right there, you wouldn't need to learn to open the cupboard! Also, using rocks is super tricky and takes a lot of practice and thinking. Some monkeys are really good at other things, like swinging super fast through trees, but they haven't learned or needed to learn how to use rocks yet. And just like grown-ups teach kids things, monkey grown-ups teach baby monkeys. If the grown-ups don't use rocks, the babies won't learn that trick either!

title: Why is it sleep deprivation can sometimes be euphoric and other times it's wretched? Is there a way to influence it one way or the other?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool toy car, and sleep is like charging its batteries. Sometimes, when you've just stayed up a *tiny* bit past your bedtime, your brain gets a little silly and giggly, almost like it's trying to trick itself into staying awake! It sends out special happy signals, and you might feel super bubbly and want to laugh at everything. But if you stay up *way, way* too late, like your toy car's batteries are totally flat, your brain gets super tired and grumpy. Everything feels hard, you might feel dizzy, and you just want to cuddle up and sleep. You can't really choose which way you'll feel, because your body really needs that sleep to charge up and be happy and strong! It's always best to get enough sleep so your brain works its best.

title: Why does toast bread keep all the cheese in while normal bread lets the cheese ooze out?
