title: British lawyers and the British legal system - Prosecutors working for private law firms?
text: Okay, imagine there are lots of rules in our big world, like "don't take someone's toy without asking" or "don't push your friend." When someone breaks a really big rule, we need grown-ups to help figure out what happened. First, the police are like super detectives who find all the clues. Then, there are special grown-ups called 'prosecutors' who look at all those clues and decide if someone needs to talk to a judge. In Britain

title: Why is it impossible to decrypt something after it has been encrypted to md5/bcrypt/etc?
text: Imagine you have a super special magic blender. When you put a whole banana and a whole strawberry into it, it whirs and whirs and turns them into a yummy smoothie. Now, once you have that smoothie, can you pick out the whole banana and the whole strawberry again, just like they were before? Nope! They're all mixed up and squished together, and some of the original shape is gone forever. That's kind of what those special computer words like MD5 do! They take your secret word, like "apple," and squish and mix it up into a totally new, short, messy code. They throw away some of the original "banana" and "strawberry" bits when they make the smoothie. Because they throw away so much and mix it so well, there

title: Would death by extreme heat or extreme cold be objectively more painful and why?
text: Okay, imagine you accidentally touch something super, super hot, like a stove. OUCH! It hurts right away, a sharp, burning ouchie, because your body shouts really loud to tell you to move your hand. If your whole body got super, super hot, it would be like that burning ouchie everywhere, all the time, because all your skin and everything inside would be getting hurt really fast and telling your brain 'OUCHIE! OUCHIE! OUCHIE!' without stopping. Now, imagine you're outside in the snow without a coat for a super long time. At first, you'd feel really, really cold, and your fingers and toes might sting and hurt a bit, like a little ouchie. But then, after a while, when you get super, super cold, your body starts to get really sleepy. Your brain gets confused, and the parts that send the 'ouchie' messages from your body start to slow down

title: What is dry drowning?
text: Imagine you're playing in the pool and you accidentally get a tiny bit of water up your nose or down the wrong pipe, and you cough a lot. Usually, you just cough it out and you're totally fine! But *sometimes*, that tiny bit of water can make your body a little bit confused *inside*, even hours later when you're already out of the pool and playing with your toys. Your body might get grumpy and make it a little harder for you to breathe, or you might cough a lot, or feel super sleepy. It's like your body is still reacting to that tiny splash from earlier. That's why grown-ups always watch you after swimming, especially if you coughed a lot, just to make sure your breathing stays easy and happy.

title: What are the differences between a condo, townhouse, and apartment?
text:
Okay, imagine houses are like different kinds of toys!

An **apartment** is like when you live in one special room in a really big building, but someone else, like a grown-

title: Why do only some people seem to be overly sexual whenever they are drunk?
text: Imagine your brain has a special "rule-follower" helper that reminds you of all the grown-up rules, like not talking too loud or keeping some things private. When grown-ups drink special grown-up juice (alcohol), it makes that rule-follower helper get a bit sleepy and fuzzy. For some people, when their helper is extra sleepy, they might forget those rules more easily and start being super-duper friendly, or wanting to hug everyone, or saying things that are usually only for very special grown-up friends. But everyone's brain is a little different, just like how some

title: What does "±" symbol mean?
text: That funny little sign "±" is like when your grown-up says, "You can have about 3 cookies, give or take 1!" It means there are two possibilities! It could mean 3 cookies *plus* 1 more (so 4 cookies!), OR it could mean 3 cookies *minus* 1 (so 2 cookies!). So, when you see "5 ± 2", it means it could be 5 and 2 more (which is 7), OR it could be 5 take away 2 (which is 3). It just tells us a number can be a little bit bigger *or* a little bit smaller than the first number you see, like having two choices!

title: Why are cloth items like towels, rags, etc. tougher to tear when wet?
text: Imagine your towel is made of zillions of super tiny, invisible strings, like lots of little hairs all together! When your towel is dry, these little strings are just hanging out next to each other, but they're not really holding hands very tightly. So, if you try to pull them apart, it's kind of easy to break just a few strings at a time, like picking one noodle from a pile of dry spaghetti. But when you get the towel wet, the water fills up all the tiny spaces between those strings. And guess what? The water makes all those little strings stick together! It's like they all hold hands really, really tightly because the water is helping them. So now, instead of trying to break just a few strings, you're trying to break a *huge team* of strings that are all holding hands super strong! And breaking a big team is much, much harder than breaking just a few separate ones, right? That's why wet towels are super tough!

title: why is Taiwan valuable to China under the "One China" policy? They've been ruled separately for so long, what would the real benefit to controlling it again be?
text: Imagine you have a big country, like a giant puzzle, and China believes Taiwan is one very important missing piece of that puzzle, even though Taiwan has been living and playing by itself for

title: Why do all movies cost the same?
text: Imagine you go to a big bouncy castle! You pay one special ticket to get inside and jump and play, right? It doesn't matter if you jump super high or just a little bounce, it's the same ticket to get in and have fun. Movies are kind of like that! When you go to the movie theater, you're not really buying the movie story itself, you're buying a comfy seat, a super giant TV screen, loud sounds, and a dark room where you can watch any of the cool stories they have playing. The grown-ups who own the movie place decide that it's fair to charge everyone the same amount of money to come in and have that special fun time, no matter if the story is about talking animals, fast cars, or magical princesses. They want it to be super easy for everyone to pick their favorite adventure and enjoy the big screen!

title: Why does it take ~5 seconds to get yourself to pee? Why isn't it instant? Is this an anti leak mechanism?
text: Imagine your pee-pee is like a special water balloon inside your tummy, and it has a little door at the bottom. When you feel like you need to pee, your brain sends a message to that little door. But the door has a secret lock on

title: Why/how do we involuntarily scream when we're scared?
text: Imagine your brain is like the super-fast boss of your body, and it has a special "Danger!" button. When something really big and scary happens, like a loud noise or a monster (not a real one, of course!), your brain presses that button super, super fast, even before you have time to think "uh oh!" It's like when you accidentally touch something hot and your hand jumps away all by itself – you didn't *decide* to move it, your body just did it! Screaming is one of the loud ways your body reacts when that "Danger!" button is pressed. It's like a super loud "HELP!" to tell your grown-ups that something is wrong, or sometimes it's like a big "BOO!" to surprise the scary thing and make it go away. It's just your body's quick way of saying, "Whoa! That was scary!" all at once, without you even having to try.

title: Why is it advisable to block your license plate when sharing a photo of your vehicle?
text: Imagine your car has a special name tag, like your name tag at school, but it's only for your car! This name tag (your license plate) tells grown-ups who owns the car and where it lives, almost like your address. If you show everyone a picture of your car with its special name tag, some not-so-nice people might see it. These people could then try to figure out where your car sleeps at night (your house!) or even pretend to be you to get information about your car. It's like keeping your house number a secret from strangers so they don't know where you live. So, when you share a picture of your car, we cover up its special name tag, just like putting a blanket over it, to keep your car and your family safe and private from people you don't know.

title: why is it that when a lot of people talk at once, the sound is multiplied to a point where, a stadium full of people talking quietly to one another, can be louder than just two people screaming?
text: Okay, imagine sound is like little pushes. When two people scream, they make two really BIG pushes with their voices. Those are loud! But when a whole stadium full of people talk quietly, it's like thousands and thousands of tiny little pushes. Each person makes a little push, but because there are so many of them, all those tiny pushes add up and add up and make one GIANT super-duper push that's even bigger and louder than just the two big

title: Why do most news websites currently have a "Click to expand article"/"Read More" button on mobile?
text: Imagine your phone is like a little helper, and it needs to show you lots of stories from the news! If it tried to show you *all* of every single story right away, it would get super, super tired and slow, like trying to pick up all your toys at once! It would also use up all its special internet 'food' really fast, which makes your phone sad. So, what they do is just show you the very beginning of each story, like a little peek, so your phone can load everything super fast and not get tired. If you see a story you

title: How's it possible to calculate the volume of geometrical bodies ?
text: Imagine you have a toy box and you want to know how many little building blocks can fit inside it – that's what "volume" means, how much space something takes up! To figure it out for a simple box, you just count how many blocks fit along one side (that's the 'length'), then how many fit along another side (that's the 'width'), and then how many layers of blocks you can stack up to the top (that's the 'height'). Then, you just multiply those three numbers together, like saying "I have 2 blocks long, 3 blocks wide, and 4 layers high, so 2 times 3 times 4 gives me 24 blocks in total!" For other shapes, like a round ball or a pointy party hat, it's a bit trickier because they aren't straight boxes, but grown-ups have special secret recipes (they call them "formulas") that help them use those same ideas, just in a fancier way, to still figure out exactly how many little blocks or how much water could fit inside. It's all about counting the space!

title: How does MSG make food more flavorful and less importantly, colorful?
text: Imagine your food has lots of different yummy tastes, like sweet strawberries or salty chips. MSG is like a special "flavor booster" magic dust! It doesn't taste like candy or chocolate by itself, but when you put a tiny bit in your food, it makes all the other yummy flavors in that food taste even stronger and more delicious, like they're having a big party in your mouth! It makes things taste extra savory and satisfying, like a yummy chicken soup or a super tasty mushroom. For the color, MSG is just a tiny white powder, like sugar or salt. When you put a little bit in your food, it's such a small amount that it doesn't change the color at all! Your red tomato soup will still be red, and your green peas will still be green. It only works on making the taste super yummy, not on changing how your food looks!

title: Why do we feel guilty after masturbating?
text: Sometimes, when you touch your private parts because it feels good, you might feel a little bit worried or yucky inside afterward. This feeling happens because grown-ups don't always talk about these things, and sometimes people make it seem like it's a big secret or something you shouldn't do, like when you secretly eat a cookie before dinner. But really, your body is just learning about itself and what feels good, and it's okay to explore when you're by yourself. That worried feeling isn't because you did something bad, it's just because you might *think* it's a secret or that someone might tell you off, even though it's a normal part of growing up and understanding your own body.

title: How do companies like Coca-Cola make money from vending machines and sales located in very rural areas in undeveloped countries?
text: Imagine you have a yummy juice box, and it costs your mommy just a tiny bit of money to make it. But when she sells it to your friend, she sells it for a little bit more money. That little extra bit is how she makes money! Coca-Cola does the same thing with their fizzy drinks. Even in places far, far away where there aren't big shops, people still get thirsty and want something

title: how do 64kb demos work? How is a video generated from such a small file?
text: Imagine you want to show someone a really cool movie with lots of colors and shapes and music. Normally, you'd need a super big box to put that movie in, like a huge pile of drawings, one for every tiny moment. But a 64kb demo is like having a magic little recipe book, super tiny, that tells your computer exactly how to *make* that movie right then and there! It doesn't have all the drawings saved. Instead, it has little instructions that say things like, "Draw a big blue ball here, then make it bounce up and down, and make some sparkly noises while it does." The computer is really good at following these instructions super fast, drawing all the shapes and colors and making sounds, all by itself, as you watch. So, instead of carrying around a giant box full of finished drawings, you just carry a tiny recipe that tells the computer how to *draw* everything fresh, every time. That's why it's so small but still makes amazing moving pictures!

title: What is the difference between being declared clinically dead, and being actually dead?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super special toy car that needs gas (which is air) and a strong engine (which is your heart) to go. When someone is **clinically dead**, it's like their toy car suddenly ran out of gas and the engine stopped. Their heart isn't thumping, and they're not breathing. But! If doctors are super duper fast and brave, they can sometimes quickly put more gas in or fix the engine, and make the car start driving again! You can wake up and be okay. But if the car stays stopped for too, too long, and too many important parts get broken because they didn't have gas or air, then it becomes **actually dead**. That means even if they try to put gas in, the car is too broken inside, and it won't ever drive again, and you won't wake up. So, 'clinically dead' is like a pause button that *might* be undone, and 'actually dead' is when the game is really, really over forever.

title: Why is horse racing such a tossup?
text: Imagine you and your friends are having a running race! Sometimes, even if one friend is usually super fast, they might not win that day. Maybe they had a tiny tummy ache, or they felt a bit sleepy, or the ground was yucky and muddy and they didn't like running in it. Another friend might accidentally get in their way, or the person telling them where to go (that's like the jockey!) might choose a different path. So, even though we think some horses are the very best, lots of little things can happen on the day of the race that make it a big surprise who wins!

title: How does part of a company split off into a sperate company?
text: Imagine you have a big toy box with lots of different kinds of toys inside, like cars, blocks, and crayons. Sometimes, the grown-ups who own the toy box might decide that the crayons are super special and would do even better if they had their *own* little crayon box, with their *own* special name, like "Color Fun Company"! So, they take all the crayons out of the big toy box, give them their very own box and name, and now the crayons get to be their own little company, focused only on coloring. The big toy box still has the cars and blocks, and the crayons are now off doing their own thing, like a grown-up bird leaving the nest to build its own, but they still came from the same family.

title: Why are there different versions of Windows? (ie Windows 10 Home, Pro etc)
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy box! You have lots of different toys, right? Some are for just playing around and having fun, and some are special tools for building big towers or doing important jobs. Windows is a bit like that! Windows Home is like your regular fun toy car – it's super good for playing games and watching cartoons, just what most people need to have fun on their computer. But then there's Windows Pro, and that's like a special big construction truck or a fancy toolbox. It has extra buttons and tools that grown-ups who do very important work on computers, maybe at a big office, might need. Most people don't need those extra fancy tools, so they just get the regular fun one. It just means there's a perfect Windows for everyone, whether they want to play or do super important grown-up computer work!

title: What is the role/ effect of music in human psyche? Why do some songs make us cry or some make us happy?
text: Imagine your brain has a special "feeling box" inside it, like a toy box full of happy toys, sad toys, excited toys, and calm toys. Music is like a magic key that can open that box! When you hear a song, it's like the song is telling your feeling box, "Hey, let's play with the happy toys!" and suddenly you feel like dancing and smiling. Or sometimes, a song might say, "Let's be quiet and gentle with the calm or even the a little bit sad toys," and then you might feel a little quiet, maybe even like you want to cry a tiny bit, like when you miss someone or feel a little bit sleepy. It's because music has special sounds that can make your feelings wake up and move around. Fast, bouncy sounds often make your happy toys come out, and slow, soft sounds might bring out your quiet or gentle toys. So, music helps us feel all sorts of things, like a super cool friend for our feelings!

title: How does "double-jumping" on a trampoline work?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friend are on the big bouncy mat. When one person jumps up high, they go way up, right? While that person is flying in the air, the *other* person jumps down *really hard* on the mat. This makes the mat go down super far and get extra stretchy. So, when the first person comes back down to land, the mat is already super-duper stretched out and springy from the second person's big jump! It's like the mat gives an extra big "BOING!" just for them, pushing them even higher into the sky than they would normally go. It's all about the mat being extra-extra bouncy at just the perfect moment!

title: why do we need to constantly change and adjust laws?
text: Imagine you have rules for playing with your toys, right? Sometimes, you get a brand new toy, or you learn a new way to play a game, or maybe a rule you had isn't fair to everyone anymore. So, you talk with your friends or grown-ups and you change the rules a little bit so it's more fun and works better for everyone playing now! Laws are just like those rules, but for all the grown-ups and kids in a whole town or country. The world keeps changing, new things happen, and people learn new ideas. So, we need to change and adjust the laws sometimes to make sure everyone is safe, happy, and that the rules still make sense for how we live and play together today, just like you change your game rules!

title: If the unreal engine is one of the most realistic and better looking game engines, why isn't it used more often in video games?
text:
Imagine Unreal Engine is like a super-duper fancy box of crayons that can draw pictures so real, they look like photographs! It's amazing, right? But drawing with those super fancy crayons takes a *very* long time, needs lots of grown-ups who are super good at drawing, and costs a lot of money to buy all the special colors and pay the grown-ups.

Sometimes, a game doesn't need to look *super* real, like a game with cartoon animals. For those games, it's like using a simpler, easier box of crayons that's faster and cheaper to draw with, and still makes a really fun picture! Also, sometimes other grown-ups already have their *own* special crayon boxes they made themselves, and they're already super good at using *those* to make their games. So, even though the super fancy crayon box is awesome, it's not always the best choice for *every* single picture they want to draw.

title: Why do drummers generally cross their arms when playing?
text: Imagine you have lots of drums and shiny plates all around you! There's a special drum called the 'snare' right in front, and a noisy shiny plate called the 'hi-hat' on the side. Drummers often want to hit the snare drum with one hand and the hi-hat with the other hand *at the exact same time* to make a cool rhythm. To reach both of them comfortably without stretching too much or bumping their elbows, it's easier to cross their arms over, like making an 'X' shape! It's like when you want to pick up a toy on your left with your right hand, and a toy on your right with your left hand – your arms just naturally criss-cross to reach everything easily so they can play super fast and make awesome music!

title: Why does mold grow on "dead" fruits but not on the ones still on the tree?
text: Imagine the fruit on the tree is like a strong superhero getting lots of yummy food and water from its mommy tree. It has a super tough skin shield and tiny doctor helpers inside that fight off any little germs or mold trying to get in. But when the fruit falls off the tree, it's like our superhero ran out of energy! It doesn't get food or water anymore, its shield gets a bit weaker, and its tiny doctors get sleepy and can't fight as well. That's when the little mold critters, who are always super hungry and looking for an easy snack, see the sleepy, weaker fruit and say, "Yummy! This one is easy to get inside and have a big party!" They can't easily get into the strong, fresh fruit, but they love to munch on the one that's not getting help from its tree anymore.

title: How come you can restart the heart to start pumping again, but you can't do the same to the brain once activity ceases?
text: Okay, imagine your heart is like a super important water pump that moves water all around your house! If the pump stops for a little bit, maybe because the power went out or it

title: How did English become such a prominent language?
text: Imagine you have a favorite toy, and you take it everywhere you go, and all your friends start playing with it too! A long, long time ago, people from a country called England loved to travel on big boats to many, many new places all around the world. When they went, they spoke English. Then, they made new homes in these places, and the people already living there started to learn English so they could talk to them, share toys, and do business together. Over many

title: How do game developers secure their code for their game in that way that it simply won't be copied by any other game company/game developer?
text: It's like when you build a super cool LEGO castle! You don't want another kid to build the *exact same* castle and say they made it, right? First, you tell everyone, "This is *my* castle! I built it!" This is called **copyright**, and it's a grown-up rule that says your idea and your work belong to you. If someone tries to copy your special castle and sell it as their own, grown-ups will tell them that's not allowed. Second, when you let your friends play with your castle, you don't give them *all* your secret instructions on how you built every single part. You just give them the finished castle to play with! Game

title: What did all the billions donated to cancer research over the years achieve?
text: Imagine cancer is like a really sneaky, tricky monster that sometimes grows inside people's bodies and makes them sick. A long, long time ago, doctors didn't know much about this monster, and it was super scary. But because so many kind people gave their piggy bank money – billions of dollars! – to help, lots of smart doctors and scientists became like superheroes! They used that money to buy special magnifying glasses and tools to peek at the monster very closely, and build special playrooms (labs) to try out different ways to make the monster go away. They learned how to spot the monster much, much earlier, even when it's just a tiny little monster. They invented new medicines that are like magic potions or tiny laser beams to zap the monster, and found better ways to carefully take it out with surgery, like a superhero scooping up a bad guy. Because of all this helping, lots more people who get sick with the cancer monster can now get better and live happy, long lives, or at least live much more comfortably with the monster sleeping inside them. The money helped them learn so much that we're much, much better at fighting the cancer monster now than ever before!

title: What was the Mexican Revolution about?
text: Imagine there was a very, very old man who was the boss of a big country called Mexico for a super long time, like when your great-grandpa was a little kid! His name was Porfirio. He was very strict, and he mostly only shared all the yummy candy and fun toys (which were like land and money) with his best friends. Lots and lots of other people were very sad because they didn't have enough food, or a place to live, and they felt things were very unfair. So, different groups of people, like brave cowboys and farmers who wanted their own land, said "No more!" and started a big, big fight to get a new boss and to make things fair for everyone. It was a long, noisy fight with many different leaders trying to help. In the end, they made new rules for the country to try and make sure everyone got a fair share and a chance to be happy, not just the boss's friends.

title: Why does color affect heat absorption?
text: Imagine the sun is like a giant sprinkle machine, sending down tiny, warm, invisible sprinkles of sunshine! When these sprinkles hit something, they can either get eaten up or bounce away. Dark colors, like a black shirt, are super good at eating those warm sprinkles – they gobble up almost all of them! And when you eat lots of warm sprinkles, you start to feel warm too, which is why a black shirt gets hot. But light colors, like a white shirt, are not very good at eating sprinkles; instead, they make most of them bounce right off, like a bouncy ball! Since they don't eat many sprinkles, they don't get as warm. So, dark colors eat more sunshine and get hotter, and light colors bounce it away and stay cooler!

title: Why does online banking (transfers, deposits, etc) cease to operate on the weekends? I would think that me transferring money would be entirely automated and does not require any human involvement at all. And even if it does, why not have some people working on the weekend to help out?
text: Imagine your money is like a special toy in your toy box at home. When you use your tablet to send money to someone else, it's like you're telling your computer, "I want to send this toy to my friend!" Your computer instantly puts a little sticky note on your toy saying where it needs to go. But to actually get your toy from *your* toy box to *your friend's* toy box, it needs to go on a special "toy delivery truck" that moves toys between all the different toy boxes in the world. These toy delivery trucks and the people who sort all the toys only work during the week, like Monday to Friday. So, if you tell your computer on Saturday or Sunday to send your toy, your computer puts the sticky note on it right away, but the toy delivery people are all home resting! They won't even see the sticky note or put your toy on a truck until Monday morning. Your toy is safe and ready to go, it's just waiting for the special delivery people to come back to work. Even though you did your part super fast, the other big part, the *really big job* of moving toys between all the different toy boxes in the world, waits for the weekdays when everyone is working.

title: Why does ice pressed on salt produce temperatures of - 28°C?
text: Imagine ice is like a sleepy block of water that wants to stay frozen. When you put salt on it, the salt is like a super strong alarm clock for the ice! It tells the ice, "Wake up! It's time to melt right now!" But melting takes a lot of energy, like when you run around and get tired. So, the ice starts to gobble up all the warmth it can find from everything nearby – the air, your fingers, the table – to help it melt super, super fast. Because it's taking all that warmth away so quickly, everything around it suddenly feels super, super cold, much colder than just plain ice!

title: Why are USA and Russia still antagonistic against each other in 2017?
text: Imagine USA and Russia are like two very big kids on a huge playground called Earth. A long, long time ago, they had a really big argument about the best way to play games and what rules

title: Why do we have bad dreams? more specifically; bad recurring dreams?
text: Imagine your brain is like a busy little storyteller inside your head, and when you're asleep, it plays all sorts of stories for you! Sometimes, if you've seen something a little bit scary, or felt a little bit worried or sad during the day, your brain might make up a story that feels a bit spooky or makes you feel uncomfortable, and that's a bad dream. It's just your brain trying to figure things out, like watching a pretend monster on TV, but it's not real and you're safe in your bed. Now, if you keep having the *same* bad dream again and again, it's like your brain is trying super hard to understand one specific thing that still feels a little bit tricky or confusing to you. It keeps playing that same story over and over because it wants to practice it or figure out the puzzle until it's not so big or scary anymore. But remember, it's still just a story your brain is telling, and you are always safe!

title: How do Speedometers work?
text: Imagine you're on a bike and your wheels are spinning really fast! A speedometer is like a little helper in your car that watches your wheels. Every time a wheel goes 'round and 'round, a tiny magic sensor counts it. If your wheels are spinning super-duper fast, the sensor knows you're going fast. If they're spinning slowly, it knows you're going slow. Then, it tells a little needle or a number on your dashboard exactly how fast the car is zooming, so Mommy or Daddy knows if they're going too fast or just right!

title: Why does animal tissue smell pleasant while cooking but human flesh smells so badly when burnt?
text:
Okay, imagine you're making yummy chicken for dinner! When Mommy cooks it just right, the heat makes special tiny bits in the chicken change, and we often add yummy spices, so it smells super delicious and makes you hungry, right? It's like when cookies are baking and the kitchen smells so good!

But when something gets *burnt* really, really badly, like if you left your toast in the toaster for too long and it turned all black and smoky, it doesn't smell yummy anymore, does it? It smells yucky and sharp. That's because when things burn too much, the tiny pieces inside them break down in a very messy, smoky way, making a bad, stinky smell that isn't like dinner at all. Human bodies aren't food, and when they burn, it's that yucky, smoky, not-food smell, not the yummy smell of dinner.

title: why do we get itchy?
text: Imagine your skin is like a super smart blanket that covers your whole body. Sometimes, a tiny little bug, or a tiny piece of dust, or even when your skin gets a little dry, it sends a message to your brain saying, "Hey! Something's tickling me right here!" That tickly feeling is what we call an itch. It's like your skin's way of asking you to give it a little scratch, almost like you're shooing away a tiny invisible tickler, to make it feel better and make sure everything is okay.

title: Why does microwaving a lit candle create plasma? (Do not try at home)
text: Okay, imagine your microwave is like a magic oven that makes food super-duper hot really fast, right? And a candle flame? That's already a little bit of very hot, glowy air. Now, when you put that hot, glowy air from the candle inside the microwave, the microwave tries to make *everything* inside it even hotter! It finds that already hot air from the flame and pushes it and pushes it, making it get SO, SO, SO hot, much hotter than regular fire! When air gets *that* incredibly hot, it doesn't just glow like a fire anymore, it changes into something super special called plasma. Plasma is like a tiny, tiny piece of the sun, all glowy and full of super energy! So, the microwave just makes the candle's hot air become even *more* super hot and glowy, turning it into plasma. But this is a very big grown-up science thing and it's very dangerous for the microwave and for you, so we *never* ever try it at home, okay?

title: How do we create "easy" AI in video games?
text: Imagine the bad guys or other characters in a video game are like little toy robots, and we give them a rulebook to tell them what to do. When we want to make them "easy," we just give them a *not-so-smart* rulebook! So, maybe their eyes are a bit blurry, so they don't see you hiding until you're super close. Or maybe their little robot arms get a bit wobbly when they try to shoot, so they miss you a lot. Sometimes, they might even forget to hide or run away and just stand there looking a bit confused. We can also make it so their squishy laser beams don't hurt you very much, even if they *do* hit you. It's like giving them a simpler, sillier set of rules so they're not very good at playing the game, and you can win more easily!

title: How does health insurance work at all if everyone needs it?
text: Imagine you and all your friends have a special piggy bank, but it's a *group* piggy bank, not just yours. Every month, everyone puts in a little bit of their allowance – just a tiny bit, not too much. Most of the time, everyone is happy and healthy, playing and having fun. But sometimes, someone gets a really big owie, like a broken arm, or they get super sick and need to go to the doctor a lot. Going to the doctor and getting better costs a lot of grown-up money, like buying a whole bunch of toys! Instead of just that one friend having to use all their own allowance (which might not be enough!), the money from the *group* piggy bank helps pay for it. So, that friend can get better without their parents worrying too much about the cost. Because everyone puts in a little bit, even when they're healthy, there's always enough money in the group piggy bank for whoever needs it most. If only the friends who were already sick put money in, the piggy bank would be empty super fast! But because everyone helps, it works like magic to help everyone stay safe and get better when they need to.

title: I often see people refer to the US presidency with titles like "the world's most powerful office." Is this just America jacking itself off or is there actually stock in a statement like this?
text: Imagine your school. The principal is like the boss, right? Now, imagine a super-duper big school, the biggest in the whole world, with the most teachers, the most students, the most crayons, and the strongest playground equipment. The US President is like the principal of *that* super-duper big school! They get to tell the biggest army (like the strongest superheroes!) what to do, they help decide how to use lots and lots of money (like a giant piggy bank!), and they talk to all the other principals from other schools (countries) about important stuff. Because their school is so big and has so much stuff, what they say and do can make a really big difference for everyone else in the world, not just their own school. So, it's not just bragging; it's because they're in charge of a really, really big and important place that affects lots of other places too!

title: We can manipulate an organism's DNA to emphasize several traits. What would it take to make a DNA from scratch, creating an entirely new organism?
text: Imagine DNA is like a super special recipe book that tells your body how to grow, like a recipe for you! We can sometimes change a tiny word in an existing recipe, like making a cake

title: How do NFL players play in such cold temperatures without any thermal wear without getting hypothermia/sick?
text: Imagine you're running super fast and playing tag outside – your body gets all warm, right? NFL players are like that, but way more! They run, jump, and tackle so much that their bodies make lots and lots of heat, like a little furnace inside them. Even though you don't always see it, they wear special, tight shirts and pants under their big pads that are like a magic blanket, trapping all that warmth close to their skin. Also, they're super strong and used to the cold, and when they're not running, they get to sit on warm benches or go inside a warm room to get cozy. So, they keep warm by moving, wearing special hidden clothes, and getting warm breaks!

title: How to treat wounds caused by shotguns?
text: Oh no! A shotgun makes a really, really big and scary boo-boo, not like a little scrape you get from falling down. If someone gets hurt by a shotgun, it's super important to call 911 right away so special helpers called doctors and paramedics can come super fast! They are like super-fixers for big boo-boos. First, they put a soft, clean towel on the hurt spot and push hard to make the blood stop, like

title: Why are circuit boards colored green as opposed to other colors?
text: Imagine your circuit board is like a tiny city with lots of very small roads made of copper, and the green part is like a special, tough green paint that covers most of those roads. This paint is super important because it stops the roads from getting dirty or accidentally touching each other, which would make the city stop working! Grown-ups who build these boards found that green was a really good color because it helps their eyes see all the tiny little pieces they need to put on the roads without getting tired. It also helps the special machines that build and check the boards see everything very clearly. Plus, green was one of the first colors they learned how to make really well and cheaply for this special paint, so it just became the most popular choice because it works so nicely! Sometimes you see other colors, but green is like the most common uniform for circuit boards.

title: Why is it illegal to pump your own gas in Oregon?
text: Okay, imagine your car is like a big toy that needs special "juice" to make it go "vroom vroom"! In most places, grown-ups can put the juice in themselves. But

title: How come sometimes we can feel our heartbeat in random parts of our body?
text: Okay, imagine your heart is like a super strong water pump that sends water (which is your blood!) through tiny hoses all over your body, even to your fingers, your toes, and your head! Every time your heart goes 'thump!', it pushes the water, and all the water in those tiny hoses gets a little push too. Most of the time, you don't even notice those little pushes. But sometimes, if a hose is super close to your skin, or if you're very, very quiet and still, or if your heart is working extra hard because you just ran super fast, you might feel that little 'thump-thump' in a random spot, like your finger or your tummy. It's just the water moving inside those hoses, saying 'hello'!

title: Can you really not catch a cold from being cold?
text: It feels like being super chilly makes you sick, right? But it's actually not the cold air itself that makes you catch a cold! What makes you get a cold are super tiny, invisible little "germs" – like tiny, tiny naughty monsters that you can't even see with your eyes! These germs float around in the air, especially when people cough or sneeze, and if they get inside your nose or mouth, *they* are the ones that make you feel yucky. Being cold doesn't make those germs appear, but sometimes, if your body gets too, too cold, it's a little bit busy trying to warm itself up, so it might not be as good at fighting off those sneaky germs if they happen to come along. So, you need the naughty germs to actually catch a cold, not just the chilly air! But wearing a warm coat still helps because it keeps your body cozy and strong, ready to fight anything.

title: If I rewatch a TV series how is it I remember the start more than the end even tho it has been longer since ive seen the start?
text: Imagine your brain is like a big toy box, and watching a show is like playing with all the toys inside, from the first toy to the last. When you rewatch the show, you open the toy box and start playing with the first toy *all over again*. So, that first toy (the beginning of the show) gets played with *many, many times* because you always start there, even if you don't play with all the toys every single time. The toys at the very end of the box (the end of the show) you only get to if you play all the way through. So, even though you just played with those last toys, the very first toy has been touched and played with *so many more times* across all your watches, making it feel super familiar and easy to remember, like an old friend!

title: Why does your lip quiver when you are about to cry?
text: When you're super, super sad, like when your favorite toy breaks, your brain gets all fuzzy inside! Your brain is like the boss of your body, and it tells all the little muscles in your face what to do, like smile or frown. But when you're about to cry, your brain is trying to do lots of things at once – it's trying to make tears, make sad noises, and also keep your face still. It gets a little bit confused and sends too many messages to the muscles around your mouth, like when you try to color with too many crayons at once! So those little muscles get a bit wobbly and jumpy, making your lip quiver before the big tears come out.

title: why do restaurants as a whole have an atrocious failure rate, but chain restaurants consistently stay open?
text: Imagine you want to build a super cool LEGO castle all by yourself! You have to find all the pieces, figure out how to put them together, decide what color the flags should be, and then tell all your

title: Why can't we make our fingers limp when we relax them?
text: Imagine your fingers are like little sticks inside, and around those sticks are tiny rubber bands. The sticks are your bones, and the rubber bands are your muscles! When you want to move your finger, the rubber bands pull the sticks. But even when you're just relaxing and not trying to move them, your body keeps those rubber bands just a tiny, tiny bit tight. It's like they're always ready, or just helping to keep your hand in a nice shape. Because of those hard sticks and the always-a-little-bit-tight rubber bands, your fingers can't ever go totally floppy and wiggly like a wet noodle or a piece of string. They always have a little bit of shape and firmness, even when you're super sleepy!

title: Why do you feel so much worse in the morning and at night when you're sick?
text: Imagine your body is like a little superhero fighting off yucky germs! In the morning, you often feel worse because while you were sleeping, all the runny nose and cough stuff just sat inside you while you were lying down, so it feels extra sticky and y

title: what are birthmarks and why do they appear?
text: Imagine your skin is like a big, plain canvas, but sometimes, when you're just a tiny little baby growing inside your mommy's tummy, a small part of that canvas gets a special mark on it! These special marks are called birthmarks. Nobody knows exactly why they pick certain spots, but it's like a tiny little oopsie or a unique splash of color that happens while your body is busy building itself. Sometimes, a birthmark is like a little extra bit of color, like a pink, red, or brown spot, because the tiny color-making cells under your skin got a bit bunched up in that one place. Other times, a birthmark might be a little bumpy, like a tiny strawberry, because the super tiny blood tubes under your skin grew a little extra in that spot. They just happen while you're growing, and they're totally normal, like how some people have curly hair and some have straight hair! They're just a special part of you, like a unique little sticker you were born with.

title: Why do we sing in the shower?
text: It's like magic! When you're in the shower, it's warm and comfy, like your own little happy bubble. And guess what? The walls in the shower are super special because they make your voice sound extra big and cool, almost like you're a superhero or a famous singer! All those hard, wet walls make your voice bounce around and sound even better than usual, which makes you feel super happy and brave to sing your favorite songs really loud. Plus, no one else is usually listening, so it's your own private concert where you can just have fun and let your happy voice out!

title: If exercise makes your heart beat faster, how come it lowers your heart rate eventually?
text: When you run and play, your body needs extra energy, like a toy car needs more batteries to go super fast! So, your heart goes *thump-thump-thump* really fast to send all the good stuff around your body quickly. But if you play and run a lot every day, your heart gets stronger, just like your muscles get stronger when you lift things! A super strong heart doesn't have to work as hard. So, when you're just sitting still or sleeping, your strong heart can do its job with fewer, slower *thumps* because it's so good at it now, like a very strong water pump that can send out lots of water with just a few big pushes instead of many little pushes.

title: how does a cancer like breast cancer kill the host?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super special house with lots of different rooms, and each room has important jobs to do, like your kitchen helps you eat, and your bedroom helps you sleep

title: What's the difference between just resting (closing your eyes, not moving) and actually going to sleep?
text: Imagine your body is like a toy car! When you just rest, like closing your eyes and being super still, it's like your toy car is parked in the driveway. It's not moving, it's quiet, but you're still inside it, looking out the windows, maybe thinking about playing later. Your brain is still awake, just being very calm. But when you actually go to sleep, it's like your toy car goes into a special garage for the night! You're not inside it anymore. The car gets plugged in to charge its batteries all the way up, and maybe little tiny helpers inside fix anything that got wobbly or dirty during the day. Your brain is doing super important work to clean up all the thoughts from the day and make you feel strong and fresh for tomorrow. That's why sleeping makes you feel so much better than just resting!

title: How can apps like Discord and Skype afford to provide their services for free?
text: Imagine your favorite playground! It's super fun and you don't have to pay to get in, right? But someone still has to build the swings, fix the slide, and keep it clean. For apps like Discord and Skype, it's kind of like that! They let everyone use the basic playground for free because they want lots and lots of people to come and play. But then, if you want something extra special, like a super cool bouncy castle or a fancy toy car to ride, you might pay a little bit of money for those special things (like Discord Nitro for cool stickers, or Skype credit to call a real phone). Also, the grown-ups who run the playground watch what games everyone likes to play and what makes them happy, so they can make the playground even better for everyone, and maybe tell other grown-ups what kids like.

title: Solar panels. How do they work?
text: Imagine the sun is like a giant, happy flashlight way up in the sky, shining its bright, warm light everywhere! Solar panels are like special, super-duper shiny plates that we put on the roof of a house. When the sun shines its light onto these plates, the plates are like little magic catchers! They grab all that bright, warm sunshine and gobble it up. Inside the plates, there's a clever way to turn that sunshine into tiny, invisible "go-power" – like the power that makes your toys move or your lights turn on. Then, little wires take all that "go-power" right into your house so you can watch TV or turn on a lamp! So, the sun gives its light, the panels catch it, and then your house gets power, all from the sun!

title: Why do trees give fruits instead of just dropping the seed like flowers?
text: Imagine a tree wants its baby seeds to go on a big adventure and grow up far away, not just right under its feet. If it just dropped the seeds, they'd all be crowded together! So, the tree is super smart. It wraps its seeds in a yummy, sweet, and colorful present called a fruit! Think of it like a special treat. When an animal, like a bird or a monkey, sees this delicious fruit, they get excited! They eat the yummy part, and then, after a little while, the seed comes out when they poop, far away from the mommy tree. This way, the seed gets a free ride to a new, sunny spot where it can grow into a big, strong tree! It's like the tree is giving the animals a yummy snack to help its babies travel far, far away. Flowers often just let their seeds fall because they don't need a ride as much, or they have other ways to spread, but trees really want their babies to explore and find new homes.

title: Why is NATO obsolete?
text: Imagine you and your friends made a super-duper secret club a long, long time ago. The main reason you made the club was to protect each other from a really big, scary monster that lived far away. NATO is kind of like that club for many countries. Now, the really big, scary monster isn't around anymore! It went away a long time ago. So, some people might say, "Hey, do we still need our super-duper secret club if the monster is gone?" They think maybe the club isn't needed as much now, like a special rain coat you don't need if it's sunny outside. But even if that first monster is gone, it's still nice to have friends who promise to help you, right? Sometimes new little monsters pop up, or sometimes it's just good to have friends so you can all be strong together, so lots of people still think having the friend club is a good idea for other reasons.

title: What does a university accreditation do?
text: Imagine you have a big toy box, and some toys are really strong and fun, and some might be a little wobbly or not work right. A university accreditation is like a special grown-up who

title: Countries and debts. Is this even real?
text: Imagine you want to build a super-duper big LEGO castle, but you don't have all the LEGOs right now. So, you ask your friend if you can borrow some of their LEGOs, and you promise to give them back later, maybe with an extra special LEGO piece as a thank you. That's kind of like how countries work! Sometimes, a country wants to build new roads, or schools, or hospitals, or make sure everyone has enough food and doctors, but they don't have all the money right away. So, they borrow money from other countries, or even from their own grown-ups who have saved some extra money. They promise to pay it back later, usually with a little extra money, just like your extra LEGO piece. So yes, it's super real! Countries really do borrow and pay back, just like you might borrow a toy from a friend.

title: What's the difference between Agnostic and Atheism?
text: Okay, imagine some people believe there's a super-duper invisible friend who made everything, like the sun and the trees and you! An **Atheist** is like someone who says, "Nope! I'm pretty sure that invisible friend isn't real at all. I don't believe in them." They're very sure about it, like when you're sure there isn't a dinosaur hiding in your closet. An **Agnostic** is different; they're like someone who says, "Hmm, I don't know if that invisible friend is real or not. Maybe they are, maybe they aren't, but nobody really knows for sure!" They're okay with not knowing the answer, like when you're not sure what's inside a wrapped present. So, one says 'no' and the other says 'I don't know!'

title: Is it okay to leave your phone (or other electronics thay require charge) plugged in and charged overnight?
text: Imagine your phone is like a little thirsty puppy, and the charger is its water bowl! When the puppy drinks all the water and is full, it stops drinking, right? It doesn't keep drinking and make a big mess. Your phone is super smart now, just like that puppy! When its battery is totally full, it knows to stop drinking electricity from the charger. It just sips a tiny bit sometimes to stay full, but it doesn't keep chugging and get too full or hot. Long, long ago, phones weren't so smart, and they would keep drinking even when full, which could make them a little grumpy or warm. But now, all your new phones, tablets, and toys are super clever, so it's totally okay to leave them plugged in overnight while you sleep. They'll be full and ready to play in the morning!

title: How do blisters form? And whats in a blister?
text: Imagine your skin is like a special sandwich, with an outside bread and an inside bread, all stuck together nicely. Sometimes, when you rub your skin a lot, like when your shoe is a bit too tight or you're holding something rough for a long time, those two pieces of bread start to pull apart just a tiny, tiny bit. Your smart body sees that little gap and says, "Uh oh, we need to protect this sore spot!" So, it quickly sends a special, clear, watery juice, like a tiny water balloon, to fill up that space between the bread layers. This juice is like a soft, bubbly cushion that keeps the tender skin underneath safe and helps it get better. So, a blister is just your body making a protective water balloon, and inside is that special clear, watery juice!

title: Drinking more water makes you retain less water?
text: Imagine your body is like a little sponge! If you don't give the sponge enough water, it gets worried and tries to hold onto every single drop it has, making it feel tight and full. But if you keep giving the sponge lots and lots of water, it knows there's always more coming! So, it doesn't need to hold onto it so tightly anymore, and it happily lets the extra water go, making it feel less puffy. Your body works like that sponge! When you drink plenty of water, your body knows it has enough, so it's happy to let go of the extra, and you don't hold onto it as much.

title: Why are most erasers pink?
text: Imagine your eraser is like a little helper that makes your pencil marks go away! A long, long time ago, when people first started making these helpers, they used a bouncy stuff called rubber. This rubber was naturally kind of brownish. But people wanted their erasers to look clean and pretty, so they added colors to them! Pink was a super popular color to add because it was easy to make and looked bright and friendly. So, many erasers became pink, and even today, lots of companies still make them that color because that's what we're used to seeing. It's just a happy color choice, not because pink works better to clean up your scribbles!

title: For two people who consume the same amount of calories, how/why does the comparatively faster metabolism of one of these people keep them thinner?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a little engine, and the food you eat is the fuel for that engine. Both you and your friend eat the exact same amount of fuel. Now, some engines just naturally run super, super fast! They use up all that fuel very quickly to do all sorts of things, like running around, playing, and even just thinking really hard. Because they use it up so fast, there's not much fuel left over for the body to keep. But your friend's engine might run a little slower. It still uses fuel, but not as quickly. So, sometimes there's extra fuel left over that the body saves and keeps for later, which can make them a little bit

title: Why can't people have purple, red or maybe solid blue eyes?
text: Our eyes get their color from tiny bits of brown stuff called melanin, and how light bounces around inside them! If you have lots of this brown stuff, your eyes look brown, like

title: If the sum of two even numbers is an even number, and the sum of two odd numbers is also an even number, then how are there the same number of even numbers as odd numbers?
text: Okay, imagine numbers are like your toys! Even numbers are like toys that come in pairs, like 2 socks or 4 wheels on a car. You can always share them perfectly with a friend. Odd numbers are like toys that always have one left over, like 1 shoe or 3 l

title: Why are almost all living things symmetrical?
text: Imagine you have a toy car. If one wheel was super big and the other was super tiny, it would be really hard for it to drive straight, right? It would just wobble and spin! Well, lots of living things, like you and me and even most animals, are built a bit like that car, but with two sides that are almost exactly the same. This is called "symmetry!" Having two matching sides helps us do important things. It helps us walk and run in a straight line without falling over, because we're balanced, just like a car needs balanced wheels to go straight. It also helps us see and hear things better because we have two eyes and two ears, one on each side, so we can look all around us and know what's happening. Plus, it's just a really good way for nature to build a body; it's kind of like when you're drawing a picture, it's often easier to draw two things that are the same than two completely different things! So, being symmetrical makes it easier to move, see, and just be a well-built creature in the world!

title: Why is a single Venusian day longer than a Venusian year?
text: Imagine you're a spinning top, and the sun is a giant toy in the middle of the room. Your "day" is how long it takes for you to spin around just one time. Your "year" is how long it takes for you to walk all the way around the giant toy. Now, Venus is a super funny spinning top! It spins around super, super, super slowly, taking a very, very long time to just turn all the way around once. But it walks around the giant toy (the sun) pretty fast! So, before Venus can even finish spinning around *one time* (its day), it has already walked all the way around the giant toy *more than once* (its year)! That's why its day is longer than its year – it's just a very slow spinner but a pretty quick walker around the sun!

title: Why is does our sky have colour when space is pitch black?
text: Imagine the sun makes all sorts of light, like tiny little colorful balls all mixed up! When this light comes to Earth, it first hits a big, invisible blanket of air that's all around our planet. This air blanket is full of tiny, tiny things that are really good at bumping the blue light balls and making them bounce all over the place, like popcorn popping! That's why when you look up, you see blue everywhere – it's all the blue light bouncing around in our air. But when you go way, way up past our air blanket, into space, there's no air! There's nothing for the sun's light to bump into and bounce around. So, because there's nothing to catch and show you the light, it just looks super dark and black, even though the sun is still shining far away!

title: What causes those very short extreme bursts of dizzyness we sometimes randomly experience?
text: Imagine your head has a special little level inside, like the one Daddy uses to hang pictures, or like a tiny water park with little boats floating in it. This level tells your brain if you're standing up straight or wobbly. Sometimes, when you stand up super fast, or turn your head like a speedy race car, those little boats or the water in your head's special level get a bit confused and slosh around for just a tiny second. Your brain goes, 'Whoa, what's happening?!' and it feels like the room is spinning for a blink! It's also sometimes because your brain needs a quick sip of 'brain juice' (that's blood!), and when you stand up too fast, the juice takes a tiny moment to get all the way up there, making you feel a bit wobbly until the juice arrives. But don't worry, your head's level and your brain are super smart and quickly figure it out, so the dizzy feeling zooms away just as fast as it came!

title: When dreaming, why do my punches seem like they're in slow motion?
text: Imagine your brain is telling you a really cool story while you're sleeping, like a movie just for you! When you try to punch in your dream, it feels super slow because your real body is tucked in bed, totally asleep and not moving. Your brain is trying its best to make up the whole story – the people, the places, what you say – and also how your body moves. But since it's not actually *feeling* your muscles move super fast like when you're awake and playing, it's a bit like your brain is just guessing, and sometimes it makes the punching part feel a little bit blurry and slow, like trying to run in really thick mud. It's just your brain being busy making up all the other fun parts of the dream!

title: Why do doctors/etc. squirt out the contents of a syringe before administering it in movies/television?
text: You know how sometimes when you drink juice with a straw, you might get a little bubble of air stuck in it? Well, the doctors use those little sticks called syringes to give you medicine. Before they put the medicine in you, they want to make sure *only* the medicine goes in and no tiny, invisible air bubbles. Air bubbles in your body where medicine should go can be a little bit naughty and cause problems, like making you feel funny or even getting sick. So, they squirt a tiny bit out to push all the air out of the stick, just to be super, super careful that only the good medicine goes in to help you feel better!

title: Why do scarecrows scare crows?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big toy person, like a giant doll, right? Farmers grow yummy food like corn in their fields, and crows really love to eat that yummy food! But the farmer doesn't want the crows to eat all their hard work. So, the farmer puts up a scarecrow. A scarecrow looks like a big, floppy pretend person made of old clothes and straw. Crows are a little bit scared of real people because real people might shoo them away or make loud noises to say "Go away!" When the crows see the pretend person standing still in the field, they get tricked! They think, "Uh oh, a person is there! They're going to tell us to leave!" So, they get scared and fly away, leaving the farmer's yummy food safe.

title: Why do we get goosebumps?
text: You know how sometimes when it's really cold, or maybe you hear a spooky story, your skin gets all bumpy and your little hairs stand straight up? Those are goosebumps! It's like your body has tiny, invisible super-strength muscles connected to each little hair. When you get cold or feel a bit scared, these tiny muscles pull your hairs straight up. Long, long ago, when people had a lot more fur like a cat or a dog, this made them look bigger and scarier to other animals, and it also helped them trap a little extra warm air close to their skin, like a tiny blanket to keep them cozy. We don't have as much fur anymore, so it doesn't really help us much now, but our bodies still remember to do it!

title: If heat makes car windows steam up, why does turning the heater on clear them?
text: Okay, imagine the air inside your car has lots of tiny, invisible water droplets, like little misty fairies floating around. When these warm, misty fairies bump into the *cold* window glass, they get super chilly and decide to stick together and make a big blurry party on the window, so you can't see! That's the steam. Now, when you turn on the heater, it blows warm, *thirsty* air. This thirsty air is like a big warm sponge! It warms up the cold window so the water fairies don't want to stick there anymore, and then the thirsty air drinks up all those little water fairies from the window, making them disappear back into the air so you can see clearly again! It's like the heater air is giving the window a warm hug and then taking all the blurry water away.

title: why do people like to watch pimples being popped?
text: Okay, imagine you have a tiny little bump on your skin, like a tiny balloon filled with a bit of yucky stuff. When it pops, it's like all the yucky stuff comes out, and the bump goes away! Our brains really like to see things get clean and fixed, just like how you might feel happy when your messy toys are all put away. It's also a little bit yucky, but sometimes our brains are super curious and like to watch things, even if they're a little bit gross or silly. It's like seeing a problem get solved, and that can make our brains feel a little bit happy, almost like when you make a big boo-boo feel better!

title: Why is staring ("spacing out") so soothing?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super busy little worker always thinking about your toys, what to eat, or what game to play next. That's a lot of work! Sometimes, even the busiest workers need a little rest. When you stare and "space out," it's like your brain is taking a tiny, quick nap, even though your eyes are open. It's not trying to figure out a hard puzzle or remember something important; it's just... being. And when your brain gets a little break from all that thinking, it feels super good and calm, like when you snuggle up in a warm blanket after playing hard. It's just a little vacation for your busy brain!

title: Why does our eyesight get weaker as we grow older?
text: Imagine your eye has a special, clear window inside, like a tiny magnifying glass. When you're a little kid, this window is super squishy and can bend and change shape really, really fast to help you see things far away and things super close up, like tiny ants! But just like your favorite toy car might get a little stiff after playing with it for many, many years, that special window in your eye also starts to get a little bit stiff and not as squishy when you get much, much older. Because it can't bend and change shape as easily anymore, it becomes harder for your eye to focus on things that are very close, making them look a little blurry. Sometimes, other parts of your eye also get a little tired, like old batteries, so everything just doesn't work quite as perfectly as it used to when you were super young.

title: Why does the tv sound louder in the morning?
text: Okay, imagine when you wake up, the whole world is still a bit sleepy and quiet, like everyone else is still napping. There aren't many cars driving outside, and maybe nobody else is making breakfast noise yet. So, when the TV makes a sound, it's like a little tiny whisper in a super quiet room – it just sounds bigger and louder because there's nothing else making noise at the same time to hide it! Plus, your ears just had a long sleep too, so they're super fresh and good at hearing everything after resting all night.

title: If movement is based on electrical impulses, why can't we create electrical impulses to treat paralysis?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like the boss of your body, and it sends tiny "go!" messages, like little sparks of electricity, down special roads called nerves to tell your muscles to move.

title: Why can bugs/small animals move so fast but we can't?

title: What long term damage does weed have on your body? (Assuming that you smoke 5-6 times per week)
